headline: Behind Lebanon Upheaval, 2 Men's Fateful Clash
abstract: Members of Lebanon's anti-Syrian opposition point to Aug 26 meeting between Prime Min Rafik Hariri and Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad as fateful; Assad is said to have threatened to break Lebanon and ordered Hariri to amend Lebanese constitution to give Syrian favorite Pres Emile Lahoud another three years in office; Druze leader Walid Jumblatt says meeting was Hariri's condemnation to death; Hariri resigned government on Oct 20 and plunged into planning for spring parliamentary elections, but was killed by massive bomb on Feb 14; photos (L)

abstract: Oracle Corp begins sending layoff notices to some of 11,700 employees working for its former rival, PeopleSoft, which it has acquired; is laying off 5,000 employees, or nearly 10 percent of combined Oracle-PeopleSoft work force (M)

headline: Sales Start Strong, but Retailers Are Worried About 2005
abstract: Goldman Sachs retail composite index shows January same-store sales for specialty apparel and accessories rose 2.3 percent; National Retail Federation says its view is guarded about 2005; group's chief economist, Rosalind Wells, predicts slowdown in early part of year that will affect whole year, 'forecasting mild 3.5 percent growth in retail sales for year, compared to robust 6.7 percent gain in 2004; January sales for specific retailers noted; graph (M)

headline: The Germans Bush Wasn't Able to See
abstract: Article contrasts Pres Bush's visit to Mainz, Germany, with his father's visit there as president in 1989 as reflecting how less warm German-American relations are now; elder Bush addressed enthusiastic audience of 3,500 people who cheered when he spoke of Germany and America as partners in leadership; current Pres Bush is entirely sealed off from ordinary Germans during his seven-hour stopover; photo of protesters in Mainz with signs objecting to Bush (M)

Syria Under Pressure: Worse Trouble May Lie Ahead
abstract: News analysis: Syria faces prospect of political and economic tumult as its hold over Lebanon grows weaker; many Syrians say Pres Bashar al-Assad is proving less adept than his father at playing political cat-and-mouse; even as government in Damascus shows signs of strain, years of one-party rule have left no viable opposition capable of filling its shoes; opposition figure claims government will not seek change without international assurances that at end of reform, regime will survive (M)

headline: Bank of America settles
A Chinese Revaluation May Not Help U.S.
abstract: Many Chinese and foreign executives in China say that revaluation of China's currency the yuan, whose exchange value is linked to US dollar, is unlikely to be silver bullet for dealing with American trade deficit with China; say revaluation is unlikely to narrow deficit appreciably, and might even increase it; China's edge in exports goes far beyond low wages paid to Chinese workers; China has learned to build factories and many kinds of equipment at fraction of cost in Western countries; photos (M)

headline: BOEING LOWERS ESTIMATE OF FOURTH-QUARTER CHARGE
abstract: Boeing Co says its fourth-quarter charge for canceling 717 aircraft has been revised to $280 million on pretax basis, from $340 million; will account for remaining $60 million in 2005 (S)

headline: Empire State Building to Update Its Tourist Experience
abstract: It is not easy to change a building that is so famous that mail from around the world finds its way to ''the Empire State Building'' without a city or country in the address.     But the managers of the building have decided that, landmark or not, it is time to update some aspects of the building at 350 Fifth Avenue so that tourists have a better time when they visit.

headline: Families in Northern Ireland Break Silence About Killings
abstract: Families of people killed by Catholic and Protestant paramiliary groups in Northern Ireland are increasingly defying sectarian fighters by coming forward with their stories; Sinn Fein has been unable to dampen outrage over January killing of Robert McCartney, Catholic who was unaffiliated with any paramilitary groups; sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland has claimed more than 200 lives in past 10 years and only 30 people have been successfully prosecuted; McCartney's sisters have given numerous interviews in effort to force IRA into lifting intimidation that has prevented 70 witnesses to killing from testifying; photos (M)

headline: 2 Are Charged Over Trading in ImClone
abstract: Dr Zvi F Fuks, chairman of department of radiation oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, and Sabina Ben-Yehuda, who worked at Scientia, investment company set up by Dr Samuel D Waksal, are charged with securities fraud and conspiracy to commit securities fraud for selling shares in ImClone Systems after receiving tip from Waksal; complaint contends they sold their shares in ImClone in December 2001 after Waksal told them that government was about to deny approval of drug Erbitux; Securities and Exchange Commission also files civil charges against two, contending insider trading; Ben-Yehuda allegedly sold all 1,178 ImClone shares in her UBS PaineWebber account for more than $74,000 one day after learning from Waksal that it was 'highly likely' drug would not be approved by regulators, while Fuks sold 89,173 shares from his Bear Stearns account for more than $5 million; ImClone announced FDA's decision at 6 pm that day; stock fell 16 percent next day; Fuks and Ben-Yehuda plead not guilty and note that after Waksal's arrest, he denied tipping them off when being interviewed by federal investigators (M)

headline: Ex-Chief of WorldCom Convicted of Fraud Charges
Bank to Pay $2 Billion to Settle WorldCom Claims
abstract: JP Morgan Chase agrees to pay $2 billion to settle investors' claims that it did not conduct adequate investigation into WorldCom Inc's financial condition before selling billions of dollars in WorldCom bonds to public year before company filed for bankruptcy; bank reaches its settlement with Alan G Hevesi, comptroller of New York and trustee of New York State Common Retirement Fund, lead plaintiff representing investors who lost money when WorldCom collapsed in 2002; $2 billion J P Morgan agrees to pay amounts to 45 percent premium to settlement formula used by Citigroup when it settled last year; Morgan had rejected that deal; total amount recovered in suit will exceed $6 billion, if court approves settlement; defendants remaining in case include Arthur Andersen, WorldCom's auditor, and 12 former WorldCom directors; jury selection is postopned until Mar 24; photo (M)

abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase, the nation's second-largest bank, reported weaker fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, attributing the decline to unexpectedly large merger-related expenses.    While other leading banks have been posting stronger earnings this week, J.P. Morgan said its profit in the quarter fell 11 percent to $1.7 billion, or 46 cents a share, from $1.9 billion, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Communists of Moldova Appear to Win, Even if They're Weaker
abstract: Communist Party of Moldova, which has turned Westward in recent years, appears to weather split with Russian government in latest elections, maintaining largest block in Moldova's Parliament; survey of voters leaving polls suggests party is much weaker than it was, and that two opposition groups have emerged as potent challenge to incumbent government of Pres Vladimir Voronin, Communist leader; race in Moldova seen as indicator of degree of remaining influence Russian government maintains over former Soviet territory (M)

headline: Cheap Seats Provide View of Troubles at Exchange
abstract: New York Stock Exchange seat sold recently for $1 million, down 63 percent from 1999 peak; drop reveals growing uncertainty about future of exchange's floor model as exchange is about to expand way it trades stock electronically, bypassing floor; some predict exchange's share of trading in NYSE-listed stocks, now at 82 percent, could decline rapidly; seat price graph; drawing (M)

The Movie Midas
abstract: Profile of Lions Gate Enterainment, largest surviving distribution and production company not owned by Hollywood studio; chief executive Jon Feltheimer and vice chairman Michael Burns have forged largest vertically integrated competitor to major studios, with production facility, television unit, foreign sales arm and 8,000-title library; run studio with cost disciple that sets it apart from major studios and other independents; seek out audidences other film companies do not often reach, grossing $302 million in nation's theaters in 2004 without any award nominees; studio's recent success has come as unwelcome surprise to many in Hollywood; revenue graph; photos (M)

headline: Allied Domecq-Pernod Deal Won't Be the Toast of an Industry Consolidation
abstract: Market Place column on lagging interest in global liquor and wine industry consolidation in wake of France's Pernod Ricard's backing away from effort to acquire Britain's Allied Domecq, either by itself or with help of partner; while wine and liquor business is primed for big, transformational deals, strict regulators and concentrated family ownerships make mergers difficult to accomplish (M)

headline: Softer Words for Harder Times?
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Market Week column compares two recent speeches by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan suggesting he is trying to send reassuring message on US's record current-account deficit; notes deficit is expected to rise to $182.8 billion in fourth quarter and by 24 percent to record $659 billion for 2004; graph (M)

Online Retailers Look Overseas
abstract: Growing number of online retailers are ready to seek customers abroad as sales growth in United States Internet market begins to slow; analysts and Internet executives who have experience with foreign retailing warn such forays remain harder than they may seem; photo (M)

headline: Have Frequent-Flier Miles? Use Them or Lose Them

headline: Three Firms Are Said to Buy Toys 'R' Us for $6 Billion
abstract: Toys 'R' Us will be sold to team of two private equity firms and real estate developer--Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Bain Capital Partners, along with Vornado Realty Trust--for about $6 billion; deal is for company's faster-growing baby supplies division Babies 'R' Us, as well as 640 Toys 'R' Us stores; sale may be as much about real estate as toys; Toys 'R' Us holds valuable leases; firms will keep Toys 'R' Us as operating toy business at least for foreseeable future, while seeking to make it leaner and meaner; team is expected to keep president John Barbour (M)

headline: Wyeth Lifts Estimate on Suits
abstract: Wyeth's shares plunge nearly 8 percent after company raises its estimate for total cost of fen-phen ligitation to $21.1 billion and says protracted legal cases continued to drain earnings in 2004; company's fourth-quarter loss was $1.764 billion on revenue of $4.65 billion, compared with earnings of $335.3 million on revenue of $4.33 billion year earlier; earnings were $1.234 billion for all of 2004, on revenue of $17.35 billion, down 40 percent from 2003, when earnings were $2.051 billion, on revenue of $15.85 billion (M)

headline: The Envelopes, Please
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column awards this year's Augustus Melmotte Memorial Prizes, named for charlatan who parades through The Way We Live Now, novel by Anthony Trollope; those honored for dubious achievement include Franklin D Raines, former chief executive of Fannie Mae, Michael D Eisner, chief executive of Disney, and Michael S Ovitz, Disney's former president; New York Atty Gen Spitzer is honored for uncovering corruption in insurance industry; photos (L)

A Paid Endorsement Ignites a Debate in the Public Relations Industry
abstract: Disclosure that Graham Williams, company owned by conservative commentator and columnist Armstrong Williams, was paid $240,000 by Education Department to promote No Child Left Behind Act is shining spotlight on public relations and public affairs agency Ketchum, owned by Omnicom Group, that is far more comfortable letting its clients bask in such attention; Ketchum paid Graham Williams to have Armstrong Williams promote law on his syndicated television program and to other African-Americans in news media; Education Department account is estimated to represent revenue in low seven figures for Ketchum; disclosure of payments intensifies debate over prevalence of political opinion masked as editorial comment in paid public communications of Bush administration; Public Relations Society of America president-chief executive Judith T Phair comdemns decision ty Williams; eight Democratic members holding leadership posts in House of Representatives write David M Walker, comptroller general in Government Accountability Office, requesting that office examine what they describe in their letter as 'the use of covert propaganda by department and agencies under Bush administration; photo (M)

Credit Suisse First Boston and Cititgroup Global Markets.    Alpha Natural Resources, an initial public offering of 29.5 million shares. Morgan Stanley and Citigroup Global Markets.

headline: AT&T Profit 84% Higher in 4th Quarter
abstract: AT&T says profit rose better-than-expected 84 percent in fourth quarter as it cut costs; earned $625 million compared with $340 million year ago; sales fell 10.2 percent, to $7.3 billion; company lost $6.1 billion for all of 2004, compared to profit of $1.9 billion in 2003 (M)

headline: Jews in Gaza Recoil at Idea of Expulsion
abstract: Nearly 9,000 Israelis in 21 settlements in Gaza Strip must leave on their own or Israeli police and armed forces will begin to remove them in late July; many feel paralyzed by future they now detest and cannot believe will come but which they do not know how to avert; many are proud of their accomplishments in desert land that produces 15 percent of Israel's agricultural exports; most are disgusted and disillusioned by Prime Min Ariel Sharon's refusal to hold national referendum on issue; map, ph oto (M)

headline: Mixed Feelings as Treaty on Greenhouse Gases Takes Effect
abstract: Many countries have approved Kyoto Protocol, which is intended to reduce global emissions of heat-trapping gases; only industrial nations that have signed agreement, which takes effect Feb 16, must reduce their emissions; US and Australia are among those that have not approved accord; BASF chairman Jurgen F Strube says pressure should be on US, which generates fifth of world's greenhouse gases but is stying out of Kyoto system, or on nations with rapidly growing economies like China and India, which approved agreement but are not required to reduce emissions, even though together, they already account for 14 percent of world's total; chart lists countries that are bound and not bound by agreement; map; photos (M)

Justices, 7-2, Reject Secrecy at Tax Court
abstract: US Supreme Court, 7-2, rebukes US Tax Court for its adoption of 'bold' and unauthorized procedure that shields essential documents from disclosure to people with cases before court and to federal judges who review tax court's work on appeal; strongly worded decision, with majority opinion written by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, is addressed to court's use of 'special trial jduges,' auxiliary judges who conduct trials and make recommendations to 19 regular judges on how major tax cases should be decided; reports are extremely important to tax court's decision-making process, yet since 1983 court has regarded them as confidential internal documents and has refused to make them available to parties or to appellate judges; Ginsburg writes neither federal law nor tax court's rules authorize such 'concealment'; decision is posthumous victory for prominent tax lawyer Burton W Kanter, who along with two other men was found liable for $30 million tax deficiency in case that dated to 1970's; decision does not overturn tax court's 1999 judgment against Kanter and two others, but court will now have to disclose basis for its adverse finding and will have to change its procedures for future cases; Kanter died in 2001 (M)

headline: BMW proposes a stock buyback
Funds find another way to diversify
Help for Digital Pack Rats
abstract: Growing number of people are depositing computer files in online bank, poising Internet storage market for growth surge; existing storage companies like Xdrive and Streamload face new competition from America Online, which has begun testing service that lets subscribers upload 100 megabytes of files to AOL servers and access that data from any computer with Internet connection; e-mailing files to oneself is also increasingly popular method of backing up important files, but e-mail services limit size of files that can be mailed; photo (M)

headline: Biogen and F.D.A. Issue Drug Warning
abstract: Biogen Idec and Food and Drug Administration warn that multiple sclerosis drug Avonex might cause severe liver damage in rare cases; company is already reeling from halt in sales of its other multiple sclerosis drug, Tysabri, which was linked to rare brain infection; Glaxo-SmithKline says FDA has ordered halt to trial of its multiple sclerosis drug, which is similar to Tysabri; photo (M)

headline: Israel explores closer link to NATO, even membership
U.K. medical journal retracts Eli Lilly claim
Trying for an Over-Counter Cholesterol Drug
abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory panel will consider whether one of oldest of cholesterol-lowering class of drugs known as statins, Mevacor, can be sold without prescription; approval of application, filed jointly by Merck & Co and Johnson & Johnson, could open new market for pharmaceutical industry; fewer than half of estimated 39 million people in US with high cholesterol and other cardiac risk factors who could benefit from statins currently take them in part because of time and expense of visiting doctors and filling prescriptions; idea of shifting Mevacor to over-the-counter status has support from leading cardiologists, who say that benefits of making statin drugs more readily available outweigh risks; some public health authorities and clinicians have questioned whether cholesterol management should be handled by patients without doctor's oversight; some medical specialists and financial analysts place odds at only 50-50 that FDA will approve over-the-counter sale of Mevacor; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Schrder ally quits after setback
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Raises Bad-Loan Provision
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group reclassifies some loans as uncollected and warns that as result it expects net loss of 240 billion yen ($2.3 billion) for fiscal year ending March 31; graph (S)

headline: Some Analysts Expect Job Cuts From Pfizer
abstract: Several drug industry analysts say Pfizer is preparing to cut thousands of jobs as its sales slow; cuts may include both sales representatives and scientists and could total as much as 10 percent of Pfizer's work force of 120,000; Pfizer has begun companywide review that seeks better efficiencies and streamlined decision making; is expected to announce plans at meeting with analysts and investors in New York on April 5; large-scale layoffs from Pfizer may lead to new period of retrenchment among leading drug makers, with many of them under profit pressure as result of rising spending for marketing and failures in last several years to discover medications with blockbuster sales; Pfizer announces positive results from trial of experimental cancer drug; says drug has been so effective in tests on stomach cancer patients that scientists ended them early so that patients receiving placebo could instead be treated with medicine (M)

headline: Funds of funds get mixed review in Europe
Aboriginals Surviving in Highlands
abstract: Aboriginal tribes on Andaman and Nicobar Islands in Bay of Bengal largely survived tsunami that devastated coastal areas of archipelago; isolation of six small tribes in highlands may have protected them; Indian government is bringing in aid but continues to bar foreign relief, citing need to protect indigenous tribes; aid groups seek local partners to get around ban; nearly 7,000 people are confirmed dead out of 350,000 on 36 inhabited islands (M)

headline: Schrder Calls on German Firms to Stop Moving Jobs
2 Fed Officials Offer Different but Upbeat Views on Debt
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and Ben S Bernanke, member of Fed board of governors, argue that United States' record level of foreign indebtedness is unlikely to pose major risk to nation; Greenspan says resolution of current-account deficit and household debt burdens is not worrisome, speech to Council on Foreign Relations; Bernanke attributes United States' huge and rising foreign indebtedness to 'savings glut' in Asia and most other parts of world, speech to Virginia Association of Economists; fairly upbeat Fed assessments run counter to those of some outside analysts, who warn that nation's soaring trade and financial deficits could lead to severe drop in value of dollar and perhaps higher interest rates; photo (M)

headline: World Briefings
Grass-Roots Effort Aims to Upend Mugabe in Zimbabwe
abstract: Underground movements Zvakwana and Sokwanele aim to resist and undermine authoritarian rule of Zimbabwe Pres Robert G Mugabe through anonymous acts of civil disobedience; both names mean 'enough'; Zimbabwean groups and other such groups are driven to remarkable degree by Internet and increasingly global nature of television; Zvakwana insists it is homegrown movement free of foreign control, but not foreign influence; it draws lessons from opposition movements in other countries, as wel l as civil rights tactics; photo (M)

headline: Report From Panel Shows Lapses In U.N.'s Oil-for-Food Program
abstract: Independent commission investigating United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq says UN's auditors did not monitor giant aid effort adequately and that its officials in some cases ignored recommendations that auditors deemed crucial to program's success; commission, lead by Paul A Volcker, issues what it terms 'provisional assessment of auditor performance; release of confidential documents shows loose financial controls over sprawling program, which has become major scandal at UN; there are no allegations of bribery or corruption by UN officials, but audits make clear that many of deficiencies were known in late 1990's, at time when indications of corruption of program by Saddam Hussein and others were also reaching UN; commission notes auditors' failure to monitor in depth New York headquarters of office that administered program, or to monitor contracts for oil sales that provided revenue for program or those for purchase of relief and other goods supposed to ease effect of sanctions on Iraqis; commission notes that program suffered from 'chronic shortage' of auditors (M)

headline: Executives' Thoughts on Financing Content in a Digital Age
Wolfowitz reassures Europeans on his goal
Confronting Civil War
abstract: Several Indonesians were killed in Aceh Province, not by tsunami-borne disease but apparently by soldiers' bullets, caught in the continuing tension between separatists and the army. Many worry that the civil war will hinder aid efforts.      Article, Page A6.

headline: South Korea's 'Sea Women' Trap Prey and Turn Tables
abstract: On a cold, rainy morning, the sea women of this islet donned their black wetsuits, strapped on their goggles and swam out into the waves.     Over several hours, they dove to reach the sea bottom, holding their breath for about a minute before bobbing up to the surface. Sometimes, several dove in unison, their flippers jutting out together for a split second, looking like synchronized swimmers.

AMERADA HESS, New York, the oil and gas company, said it acquired a 65 percent stake in Trabant Holdings, the owner of Russian exploration and production company Samara Nafta, for $25 million.    PETRO-CANADA said it acquired a 51 percent interest in Coastal Petrochemical, Montreal, from El Paso Corp., an energy company in Houston, for about 34 million Canadian dollars ($28 million).    SPIEGEL, Downers Grove, Ill., the mail-order marketer operating under bankruptcy protection, won court approval to continue negotiating the terms of a $300 million loan with three lenders.

headline: Is Norway's Oil Pool Deep Enough?
abstract: Norway has turned income from 3.3 million barrels a day of offshore oil production into government-owned investment fund that recently topped $165 billion; it is one of world's richest funds; Finance Min Per-Kristian Foss says Petroleum Fund will be renamed Pension Fund in 2006; says it should be more of cash reserve for future than source of immediate income; Norway's central bank, which administers fund, says it will be able to meet no more than one-quarter of Norway's pension obligations; says rest must come from taxpayers; photos (M)

abstract: Khabarovsk Gov Victor Ishaev, citing possible impact on cluster of nature reserves near Perevoznaya Bay near Vladivostok, suggests Russia end Pacific oil pipeline at industrial port of De-Kastri; photo (S)

headline: Disaster's Damage to Economies May Be Minor
abstract: Economists say tsunami that has destroyed livelihoods of millions of families in South Asia will shave only few points off region's economic growth this year; note that two industries most heavily hit--tourism and fishing--make up small percentages of overall economy in Sri Lanka, Indonesia, India and Thailand; say true cost of tsunami will be felt in individual lives, as well as countries' infrastructures; Aceh, which bore brunt of damage in Indonesia, accounts for only 2 percent of country's economy; Sri Lanka's economy is heavily agricultural; tourism and fishing make up less than 6 percent of its gross domestic product; in Thailand, tourism around Phuket accounts for 1.3 percent of national economy; Peter Harrold of World Bank warns against using gross domestic product as only measurement of economic impact of disaster; points out huge loss in houses, boats, ports, hotels, clinics, roads and railways; most affected businesses and individuals along rim of Indian Ocean do not have insurance coverage for kind of disaster they have encountered; photo (M)

abstract: Nielsen Media Research's switch to local people meters to replace less advanced set-top boxes and paper diaries to track television viewing is leading some television stations to drop stunts they used in past to boost ratings during sweeps months; people meters make available next day data on how many and what type of people watch show, type of data on which ad rates are based, weakening incentive to inflate ratings during sweeps; Nielsen has so far rolled out new system in only five largest markets, where it has met sometimes vociferous criticism; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Military Personnel Growing Critical of the War in Iraq
A Path to Road Safety With No Signposts
abstract: ''I WANT to take you on a walk,'' said Hans Monderman, abruptly stopping his car and striding -- hatless, and nearly hairless -- into the freezing rain.     Like a naturalist conducting a tour of the jungle, he led the way to a busy intersection in the center of town, where several odd things immediately became clear. Not only was it virtually naked, stripped of all lights, signs and road markings, but there was no division between road and sidewalk. It was, basically, a bare brick square.

headline: 2 Former Top Executives at Impath Are Indicted
abstract: Anu D Saad, former chairman and chief executive of Impath, and Richard P Adelson, former president and chief operating officer, are indicted on charges that they participated in accounting fraud; are accused of leading plan to artificially inflate market price of Impath stock by issuing false financial reports that resulted in shareholder losses of $260 million (M)

headline: When Gray Heads Roll, Is Age Bias at Work?
abstract: Article on age bias in employment, which is becoming larger issue as American work force grows older and companies come under pressure to increase efficiency; federal courts are split on whether deliberate bias must be proved in order for plaintiff to win; Chicago-Kent School of Law Prof Howard Eglit says people who accuse employers of age discrimination win less than one third of their suits but that such suits are likely to proliferate, partly because work force is aging; cases involving Best Buy and Sprint described; photo (M)

headline: Pension Agency Is About to Get a Rescue Plan
abstract: Bush administration officials are close to unveiling rescue plan for federal pension insurance program, which is in rapid decline and bracing itself for another year of record losses; program, under Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, insures pensions in case of failure; program had $23 billion deficit in 2004, compared to $8 billion surplus in 2001, raising questions about its long-term ability to pay retirees their pensions; much of recent loss stems from months-long process of taking over failing pension plans at United Airlines and US Airways, which were underfunded by billions of dollars (M)

abstract: Two groups of investors make offers for control of Wind, telecommunications arm of Enel, Italy's largest utility; Italian officials have valued entire business at 13 billion euros ($16.8 billion); consortium of private equity investors led by Blackstone Group makes offer worth about 11.5 billion euros ($15 billion); others in group are buyout firms Permira and Providence Equity Partners and Goldman Sachs; group led by Naguib Sawiris, Egyptian telecommunications executive, submits counteroffer; Sawiris is head of Orascom Telecom Holdings; two offers are understood to be for about three-quarters of Wind (M)

headline: Recount of Disputed Votes to Delay Results
abstract: A public recount of hundreds of disputed ballot boxes will delay the release of final results for Iraq's elections, election officials said Wednesday, leaving the shape of the nation's first democratically chosen government in doubt for at least a few more days.    The officials displayed a large stack of ballots and ballot boxes that had been ruled invalid. The striking display included boxes that appeared to have been hastily stuffed with forged ballots, as well as heaps of ballots in sacks and cartons that revealed an apparent attempt to falsify votes on a large scale.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: There is life above the ground floor and mezzanine selling areas on Fifth Avenue from 50th to 57th Street in Manhattan. Landlords have been renovating upper-floor office space in two buildings so they can rent it to upscale tenants. [C7.]    The Shorenstein Company is disposing of a substantial portion of its office portfolio in San Francisco as it moves to become a national business, and it is taking advantage of a surprisingly feverish market. [C6.]

abstract: Collins & Aikman Corp, saying improper accounting is likely to force it to restate results for first nine months, delays 2004 earnings report for second time (S)

abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac welcomes his Iraqi counterpart Sheik Ghazi al-Yawar for four-day visit, in important symbolic step toward repairing France's tattered relationship with Iraq; Chirac hopes Yawar's visit will prove French support for Iraq's political process, and eventually re-establish France's historic role there; photo (M)

headline: Kremlin Interference Seen as Critical Factor in Decline of Russia's Oil Output
abstract: Government's tightening grip on oil and gas industry in wake of breakup of oil producing giant Yukos is seen by some analysts as major reason for decline in country's oil production; crude output has declined slightly since October, to 9.28 million barrels a day in January; oil and gas prouduction has been major driver of Russia's stunning economic recovery; government is pinning hopes on government-run Gazprom, which reported 9 percent rise in net profit, to 137.9 billion rubles, for first nine months of 2004; photo (M)

abstract: Correction of March 6 article about Pearson PLC, which referred incorrectly to its 2004 dividend and incompletely to officials who were made available for interviews (S)

headline: Taking Care of Business, His Way
abstract: US Chamber of Commerce has become most visible and effective business lobby in country under leadership of Thomas J Donohue, its president and chief executive; was force behind legislation to move class-action lawsuits out of state courts, succeeded in stalling SEC proposal that would have allowed shareholders more say in how their directors are selected and is challenging provisions of Sarbanes-Oxley corporate reform law; has become deeply involved in political campaigns across country, and 90 percent of Congressional candidates it endorsed have been elected; critics say chamber may be overreaching and question Donohue's work as director at four public companies: Sunrise Senior Living, Union Pacific, XM Satellite Radio and Qwest Communications; photos; graph of chamber's fund-raising (L)

headline: JUDGE RULES AGAINST FORD IN DISCRIMINATION LAWSUIT
abstract: Federal Judge Aleta Trauger rules that Ford's Primus lending unit discriminated against African-American buyers by allowing dealers to mark up interest rates (S)

headline: Marsh Will Cut Dividend 50% and Increase Commissions
abstract: Marsh & McLennan chief executive Michael Cherkasky outlines sweeping plan to rescue company from five-month-old bid-rigging scandal; says company will concentrate on fewer but more profitable clients, lay off 2,500 more workers, cut dividend in half, increase commissions and drop thousands of unprofitable clients; says it will also shed MMC Capital, private equity investment unit that raised conflict-of-interest concerns, and reduce benefits for remaining 54,500 employees worldwide; graph (M)

headline: Europa: EU vs. U.S. vs. China: Partnership paradoxes
Ukraineto pull all 1,600 troops from Iraq
U.S. tries to break deadlock over OSCE
World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Mobile Phone Ruling
abstract: European Commission approves proposals by Ireland's telecommunications regulatory body to promote competition in Irish cellphone market by forcing Vodafone and MMO2, dominant players, to sell wholesale space on their networks to competitors (S)

headline: China tackles abortion issue
Parliamentary committee faults postwar Iraq plans
Technology Briefing | Earnings: Lower Profit For Electronic Arts
abstract: Electronic Arts reports decline in third-quarter profit and earnings; reports 3.2 percent decrease in sales, to $1.43 billion (S)

headline: 2 Leading Canadians Squabble in Scandal Shaking Liberal Party
abstract: Former Prime Min Jean Chretien of Canada has kept silent since leaving office 14 months ago, as scandal implicating some of his closest associates bruises his successor Paul Martin and threatens long-governing Liberal Party's grip on power; now he has attacked judge who leads federal iquirty that was started by Martin five months ago, and in so doing has created new fissures in party between his camp and Martin's; Chretien is scheduled to testify about government program that allegedly fed funds into advertising agencies allied with Liberals for little or no work (M)

headline: 17 Employees Resign From Saatchi New York
abstract: Seventeen employees who worked on Genea

headline: Italians throw millions after unlucky number
Losing a Friend, and Working Through It
abstract: Career Couch column on how to deal with death of a close friend when it affects your ability to do your job; drawing (M)

headline: Interest Rate Turbulence: What's a Bond Investor to Do?
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on Pimco Real Return fund's strategy for dealing with interest rate turbulence (M)

headline: Six Months, and Still Glittering
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Market Week column; price of gold, because of weakening dollar, has been more than $400 an ounce for 170 consecutive days, longest run since February 1987; JPMorgan Funds sends total of 20,000 flash-memory sticks to broker-dealers and other intermediaries that sell its mutual funds; 146,000 new jobs created in January puts Pres Bush's average monthly job creation into plus category for first time, at 1,800; graph (M)

headline: The Internet's Future? It Depends on Whom You Ask
abstract: Pew Internet & American Life Project survey of wide range of technology specialists, scholars and industry leaders on Internet's future finds deep division on some topics; finds widespread agreement that there will be at least one devastating attack on Internet infrastructure in next 10 years; predictions are being added to growing online database developed jointly with Elon University; graphs of responses; photos (M)

headline: DirecTV Machine Will Compete With TiVo
abstract: TiVo receives serious challenge to its digital video recording business when DirecTV announces it will begin offering its own brand of digital video recorder later this year; move ends exclusive relationship between companies that supplied TiVo with two million of its three million subscribers; new DirecTV digital video recorder is being designed by NDS, owned by News Corp, which owns minority interest in DirecTV (M)

headline: Asia embraces free-trade links
Buying an Ad to Defend, Rather Than Promote, a Movie
abstract: Actor Rob Schneider comments on buying full-page ads in Daily Variety and Hollywood Reporter to respond to Patrick Goldstein's article in Los Angeles Times scoring Hollywood studios for bankrolling sequel to his film Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo and deriding his comedic acting, interview; says he sought to embarrass Goldstein in fun way; Goldstein comments; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Jefferies Group, New York, an investment bank, said it had acquired Randall & Dewey, Houston, an advisory firm serving the oil and gas industries. Terms were not disclosed.    First California Bank, Camarillo, Calif., said it had agreed to buy South Coast Bancorp, Irvine, Calif., for about $36 million in cash.    Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold, New Orleans, said it would pay a special dividend of 50 cents a share, or a total of $90 million, to shareholders of record as of March 15.

headline: Campaign for EU charter
Currencies: Dollar loses ground against the euro
Unease, not gloom in world
How to File a Claim for Microsoft's Settlement
abstract: Businesses and individual consumers in California who bought Windows, Word, Excel, Office or certain other Microsoft products from 1995 to 2001 are eligible for rebates on technology purchases under terms of Microsoft's antitrust settlement (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Free Condoms For Carnival
abstract: Brazilian government announces free distribution of 11 million condoms to prevent spread of AIDS during Carnival festival (S)

headline: North Korea Reports It's Ready to Resume Nuclear Arms Talks
abstract: North Korea says it is ready to return to six-party talks on its nuclear weapons programs, and proclaims its desire to become 'friend' of US; announcement follows four-day visit by US Congressional delegation led by Rep Curt Weldon (S)

headline: Israelis cut all ties with Palestinians
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Sales Rise
abstract: Retail sales in Brazil rose in November at their slowest pace in nine months, climbing 6.44 percent from year-earlier period (S)

headline: Shiite Offers Secular Vision of Iraq Future
abstract: Adel Abdul Mahdi, one of the leading candidates to become the new Iraqi prime minister, recalled the day last year when he and other Iraqi leaders were summoned to the holy city of Najaf by the country's senior Shiite clerics.     The topic was the role of Islam in the new Iraqi state. Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the country's most powerful Shiite leader, questioned whether Mr. Mahdi and the others, members of the American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council, had the legitimacy to draft an interim constitution.

headline: Post-Prison Martha Stewart Vows 'to Make Life Better'
abstract: Martha Stewart appears before group of her company's employees, glowing with post-prison message that promises new and different purpose for her media empire; tells Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia staff that their mission is not just to explain nuts and bolts of crafts, cooking and housekeeping, but also why those things are important for building relationships in often uncertain world; photo of Stewart with daught Alexis (M)

headline: China's Oil Diplomacy in Latin America
abstract: Oil industries in Venezuela, Colombia, Brazil, Bolivia, Peru and other Latin American countries have emerged as contenders for China's energy attentions; Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez and Chinese Vice Pres Zeng Qinghong signed 19 cooperative agreements in January to develop oil fields and build boiler-fuel plant and analysts expect further cooperation; China reportedly accounted for 40 percent of global growth in oil demand in last four years and its consumption in 20 years is projected to rise to 12.8 million barrels a day from 5.56 million now; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Rebels Kill 24 Soldiers
abstract: Defense Ministry reports that 24 Colombian soldiers have been killed in heavy fighting with Marxist rebels in northern Antioquia Province (S)

headline: UN prepares to send 10,000 troops to monitor Sudan
Deficits May Be Wearing Thin at the Fed
abstract: Edmund Andrews Economic View column on possibility that Pres Bush's longtime honeymoon with Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan may be ending as Bush moves into his second term; holds measured pace of interest rate increases reflects Fed's increased confidence that economic growth is steady, but concern is rising over federal deficit, low and declining national savings rate, evidence of speculative behavior among investors and consumers and US's enormous trade and financial deficit; graph (M)

headline: Syrian troops pullback by end of March
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Brazil's unemployment rate rose to 10.2 percent in January from three-year low of 9.6 percent in December; real wages rose 2.2 percent in January from December (S)

headline: Law Barring Junk E-Mail Allows a Flood Instead
abstract: Unsolicited junk e-mail on Internet has actually increased since passage last year of sweeping federal antispam law; it now totals 80 percent or more of all e-mail sent, up from 60 percent before law went into effect; antispam crusaders have long argued that law would make spam problem worse by effectively giving bulk advertisers permission to send junk e-mail as long as they follow certain rules; not everyone agrees that law is to blame; lawsuits invoking new law have been mounted by large Internet companies like Microsoft, AOL and Yahoo in name of combating problem; so far, spam trade has foiled most efforts to bring it under control; some so-called bulletproof Web host services offer spam-friendly merchants access to stable offshore computer servers where they can park their Web sites, with promise that they will not be shut down because of spam complaints; Sen Conrad Burns, antispam law's chief sponsor, suggests that Federal Trade Commission, which oversees its enforcement, might simply need some nudging; photo; graph (M)

headline: The Unassociated Press
abstract: Wikinews is experiment in collaborative news gathering and reporting, and latest in collection of Wikis under umbrella of Wikimedia, which cultivates free and open information resources written by its users; Jimmy Wales, founder of Wikipedia and president of nonprofit Wikimedia Foundation, says commitment to neutrality is central to news operation; critics are concerned about effectiveness of collaborative approach to news and question whether it can be credible; photo (M)

headline: A Former Gas Station Attendant's Big Bet on a Refinery Has Paid Off
abstract: Reliance Industries' vast refinery and petrochemical complex in Jamnagar, India, has become one of most profitable bets in global refining industry; its $7 billion a year in sales equals 4 percent of entire revenue of India's corporations; it is one of few refineries in world that can take very thick high-sulfur highly acidic grades of crude oil and process them into extremely pure, low-polluting gasoline and diesel fuel; New York region, with its demanding environmental standards, has become biggest single destination for shipments from Jamnagar; complex is creation of late Dhirubhai Ambani, who as young man in 1950's worked as gas station attendant in Yemen; photo (M)

headline: Growth Pace of Economy Slowed to 3.1% in 4th Quarter
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that American economy slowed to annual growth rate of 3.1 percent in final three months of 2004; that is weakest quarterly pace in nearly two years, held down by surge in imports, which substituted for production at home; consumers provide most of lift, increasing their outlays for goods and services by more than enough to offset weaknesses in other areas; chart (M)

headline: Indonesians protest Malay claim
Pro-Syrian Prime Minister Set to Return in Lebanon
Freud Action Figure? Yeah, We've Got That
abstract: Web site stupid.com carries wide variety of toys and gag gifts; site owner Gary Apple comments; photo (M)

headline: Crowds at St. Peter's Are on Tours, Not a Papal Death Watch
abstract: In wake of Pope John Paul II's tracheotomy, after second trip in one month to hospital, there is sense in Rome that significant corner has been turned in his long public illness, but it has not yet manifested itself openly as vigil; Pope will not take part in today's weekly public Angelus blessing and prayer for what seems to be first time in 26 years, but he reportedly is otherwise in good condition; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard To Introduce  Servers
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co will introduce new high-end and midrange server-computers and related software and services; among products being announced are updated server-computers that use Itanium chip from Intel and new software that will increase efficiency and use of those machines; Hewlett says it will begin offering more pay-as-you-go enterprise computing services, for which customers will pay only for amount of computing power that they actually use (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Children Found Dead In Car
abstract: South African police arrest elderly couple in KwaZulu Natal after local residents find blister-covered bodies of two missing 3-year-olds and three missing 5-years-old in junked car on couple's property; locals contend that children were victims of muti killing in which body parts are used for witchcraft purposes (S)

headline: At A.I.G., It Seems Chief's Departure Was Exaggerated
abstract: Maurice R Greenberg continues to hold powerful sway over management of American International Group just days after stepping down as chief executive; Greenberg's unusual control stems largely from his role as top executive of related, private entities, C V Starr and Starr International Co; Greenberg holds reins over vehicles that dole out compensation to AIG exeutives; is also still chairman of Starr Foundation, one of nation's largest private foundations, which makes contributions to organizations and charities run by company's directors; photo (M)

headline: BRIEFLY: WASHINGTON:
Citigroup Posts 12% Profit Rise and Sees Slowing Growth
House Ties Immigration Bill to Military Appropriations
abstract: House ties up contentious immigration bill to measure to provide additional $81.3 billion for US military operations and foreign aid, mostly for Iraq and Afghanistan; members want to force Senate to take up immigration issue; several lawmakers also object to using emergency spending to seek $590 million for new embassy in Baghdad; House approves $100 million for disaster aid to Africa; $200 million requested for Palestinians gets strings including funneling money through third parties and audit of Palestinian Authority finances (M)

headline: Economy Added Just 146,000 Jobs in January
Russian Legislators Vote to Condemn Anti-Semitism
abstract: Lower house of Russia's Parliament votes to condemn anti-Semitism after group of mostly nationalist and Communist legislators recently demanded that Jewish organizations be investigated and even outlawed for fomenting ethnic hatred and stimulating anti-Semitism themselves (S)

headline: Ted Koppel to Leave 'Nightline' and ABC News
Surf Apparel Retailer Said to Be Buying Ski Maker
abstract: Quicksilver Inc, maker of surfing appparel, reportedly reaches agreement to acquire French ski and snowboard maker Rossignol for $550 million (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | People: PalmSource Names Financial Chief
abstract: PalmSource names Jeanne Seeley to succeed Albert Wood as chief financial officer (S)

headline: Warner Music Plans Public Offering of Up to $750 Million
abstract: Warner Music Group files to sell up to $750 million of stock in initial public offering; expects to sell its stock on either New York Stock Exchange or Nasdaq (M)

headline: Bolivian Chief, Angling for Support, Offers Resignation
abstract: Bolivian Pres Carlos Mesa offers resignation in face of disruptive protests he says make country ungovernable; photos; officials hope televised announcement will be rallying cry for Bolivians tired of relentless protests; demonstrators have closed highways to protest bill they say does not go far enough to tax foreign companies developing Bolivia's huge natural gas reserves (M)

headline: World Briefings
A Wave of Mergers, Not Yet at Its Crest
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Dennis Block, co-chairman of mergers and acquisitions for New York law firm Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, who comments on latest merger trends; drawing (M)

headline: Architect of Russia's privatization survives assassination attempt
New Housing Takes Some Worry Off Military Families
abstract: Article on new housing at Fort Stewart, Ga, Army base, built by team led by GMH Communities Trust; says housing program was established after Defense Department concluded that about 60 percent of housing it owned was inadequate and that it would take 30 years and at least $20 billion for government to rebuild and renovate by itself; operating costs come out of service member's housing allowance, which is based on rank, location and dependents and is often deposited directly with company; photo (M)

headline: KSL Media in New York Takes Over 3 Assignments
abstract: KSL Media in New York is named to handle assignments for Borders Group, Western Union and Turtle Wax (S)

headline: To Stay Competitive, A.P. Gives Clients More Than Just Facts
abstract: Associated Press begins offering its newspaper members optional alternative leads to its news reports, leads that seek to draw reader in through imagery, narrative devices, perspective or other creative means rather than just giving basic who, what, when, where and why (S)

headline: Qwest and Verizon in a Duel of Letters, Trying to Buy MCI
abstract: Qwest Communications chairman Richard Notebaert and Verizon chairman Ivan Seidenberg release letters stating their cases for seeking to acquire MCI; Notebaert's letter says his company's latest bid is being ignored; Seidenberg's letter dismisses Qwest's projected cost savings as 'modern fiction' (M)

headline: At Guantnamo, a grim protest is disclosed
SPOTLIGHT: From horsepower to horses
Brazilian Leader Hears Boos From Unusual Direction, the Left
abstract: Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva of Brazil defends his record before thousands of skeptical antiglobalization activists attending fifth annual World Social Forum in Porto Alegre; says his government is painstakingly laying foundation to eradicate Brazil's gaping social disparities; seeks to answer growing chorus of critics on left who accuse him of abandoning his working-class roots and selling out to global capitalism (M)

headline: Iraqi Governor Slain by Gunmen; Bombing Kills 10
WHY CAN'T WE BE FRIENDS?
abstract: Bernard L Schwartz, newest trustee at New-York Historical Society, rejects notion that Richard Gilder and Lewis F Lehrman are pushing conservative agenda at society (S)

headline: Abbas Takes Office, Already Facing Battles
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas is sworn in as Palestinian president and is already embroiled in crises; Israel has cut off official contacts in response to Jan 13 attack that killed six Israeli civilians, Israeli troops killed seven Palestinians in two confrontations in Gaza and 46 Palestinian election officials have resigned, citing irregularities in last week's vote; Abbas reiterates goal of establishment of Palestinian state, including West Bank and Gaza, with capital in East Jerusalem; says Israelis and Palestinians are destined to live side by side; expresses opposition to Palestinian attacks on Israel; photo (M)

headline: Bull Crashing Through Glass Wall Signals New Direction for Merrill Lynch
abstract: Merrill Lynch will begin new TV ad campaign featuring Dollar the bull, company's well-known ad character; bull's shattering of glass, which stretches ribbon-like across prairie, is meant to signal that Merrill has broken through its traditional role of stock and bond buyer into becoming, through its thousands of advisers, provider of broader financial services; campaign was developed by ad agency Boathouse; photo (M)

headline: Shareholders Who Answer to a Higher C.E.O.
abstract: Article on influence groups of activist Roman Catholic nuns are having in corporate boardrooms and shareholders' meetings; nuns of dozens of orders are seeking to persuade military companies, including Lockheed Martin, General Dynamics and Raytheon, to limit military sales in countries where arms can fall into hands of child soldiers or perpetuate long-running laws and promote code of conduct that holds arms makers accountable for effect of their business on environment and on political and social stability of countries where they operate; photos; graph (M)

headline: Gone Fishing, but Reachable Through E-Mail
abstract: California reaches accord with SBC Communications to provide wireless Internet access points in 85 state parks; deal will allow park visitors with laptop computers and other portable devices to connect to Internet from areas formerly known as 'wilderness'; Wi-Fi access will be available mostly in central spots in parks; SBC will give park visitors free Internet access to California state government Web pages and charge them daily fee to send and get e-mail and reach other sites; photo (M)

headline: Gadgets of the week: Getting the picture
Britain Grants Home Detention to 8 Jailed Terror Suspects
Israel is at crossroads of peace, says Sharon
Italy opens sad pages of history
Palestinian Girl Killed
abstract: Witnesses say shot that killed 11-year-old Palestinian girl standing outside school in Gaza Strip apparently came from Israeli military post 800 yards away, charge Israel denies; militant group Hamas fires mortars at nearby Jewish settlements in retaliation (S)

headline: Police Point at I.R.A. After $50 Million Bank Robbery
abstract: Northern Ireland chief constable Hugh Orde says Irish Republican Army is main suspect in robbery of $50 million from Northern Bank in Belfast on Dec 20; it is largest theft in Britain since 1987; bank says all of its notes in circulation will be reissued in different color, making stolen notes useless; photo

headline: Bush nominates Wolfowitz for World Bank
Judge Finds Pricewaterhouse Withheld Data
abstract: US Magistrate Judge Patricia A Hemann finds that PricewaterhouseCoopers failed to provide documents and other evidence in accounting fraud lawsuit filed by Telxon Corp and its shareholders against firm; writes in nonbinding recommendation to Kathleen O'Malley, US district judge, that she 'considered, but cannot recommend, any lesser sanction than entry of default judgment' against PricewaterhouseCoopers for its failure to turn over evidence sought by Telxon and its shareholders; recommendation is victory for shareholders and company in their lawsuit, which are proceeding jointly against firm; PricewaterhouseCoopers says it respectfully disagrees with Hemann's report and recommendation (M)

headline: News Analysis: The EU's growing pains
Letters warn of French rail bombing
Questions Arise of Possible Bias at Drug Maker
abstract: Memo written by Marion HochbergSmith, director of equal opportunity at Johnson & Johnson, in late 1990's into making improvements in company's employment policies, along with other documents submitted to federal court in New Jersey, emerge publicly in support of motion to certify lawsuit filed in 2001 by several African-American and Hispanic employees as class action; documents open rare window into workings of big company coping with how to hire and promote fairly; HochbergSmith memo expresses concerns about inadequate tracking of promotions, reports of unequal salaries and insufficient outreach to recruit women and minorities; drug company formed diversity task force, but few of proposals, executives later conceded in legal depositions, ended up being put into practice; suit does not claim company refused to hire employees who are plaintiffs, but that executives knew years ago that they were missing their targets for promoting such employees, and did little to solve problem; photo of Linda Morgan and Nilda Gutierrez, who are among plaintiffs in lawsuit (M)

headline: Ryanair places order for 70 Boeing planes
World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Brewery Dispute
abstract: Gambrinus Co, major importer of Corona beer into US, enters into arbitration to settle dispute with Mexican brewer Grupo Modelo over continuation of its import license; Gambrinus says Modelo first sought unsuccessfully to buy it and then told it that its license would not be renewed after end of 2006; Gambrinus is contesting that decision before International Court of Arbitration of International Chamber of Commerce (S)

headline: U.S. and EU end truce on subsidies for aircraft
In New Ads for Baseball,the Fans Are the Stars
abstract: Ad campaign for 2005 Major League Baseball season is all about fans, and its theme is 'I live for this,' same as last year's, when ads featured players instead; agency is McCann Erickson Worldwide; executives say change of focus has nothing to do with steroid scandal; photo (M)

headline: ViewPoints: Less is more when business gives
World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Pipeline To End Near Japan
abstract: Russia confirms that it will build $15 billion, 2,500-mile oil pipeline from Siberia to port in Nakhodka on Sea of Japan, dropping plans to route pipeline to China (S)

headline: Microsoft Yields in Brussels Case
abstract: Microsoft says it will not appeal court ruling in December that requires company to sell in Europe version of its Windows operating system without its media-playing software (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Paris Airport To Rebuild Collapsed Roof
abstract: Paris airport authority announces demolition plans for damaged roof of Terminal 2E at Charles de Gaulle airport, which partially collapsed in 2004 killing four people; design of new structure has not been announced, but is to be completed by winter 2007 (S)

The Book Report: The art of the scam

headline: Savoy No More
abstract: London's landmark Savoy Hotel has disappeared from company name now that Savoy Group has been sold to investment group; new company formed by investors, Maybourne Hotel Group, will own and manage Berkeley, Claridge's and Connaught hotels in London; Savoy Hotel was sold separately last week; America West Airlines will drop flights between San Francisco and Kennedy International, San Francisco and Boston, and Los Angeles and Washington-Dulles, citing fare competition; survey by Innovation Analysis Group for Airguide Magazine finds nearly half of airline passengers say airport security is 'hassle' and is no improvement over pre-Sept 11 security; American Airlines' decision in 2003 to cut nearly half of its flights at Lambert Field in St Louis had serious impact; in 2004, about 7 million passengers boarded commercial flights at Lambert, compared with 10.2 million in 2003 and more than 15 million in 2000 and 1999; US Bureau of Transportation Statistics says 19.4 percent of domestic flights arrived late in first 11 months of last year, up from 15.8 percent during period in 2003; photo (Memo Pad column) (M)
