4 convicted in 2001 Milan plane crash
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Toshiba Ordered To Pay $322 Million To Lexar
abstract: Toshiba Corp is ordered

headline: Key Witness on Worldcom Tells Jury He Broke Law
abstract: Scott D Sullivan, government's star witness in its case against WorldCom's former chief executive Bernard J Ebbers, ends seven days of testimony by admitting he broke law so company could meet financial targets; says he hid billions of dollars in expenses to mask company's deteriorating performance (M)

headline: Indonesia wraps up terror case
World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Maker Lowers Forecast
abstract: Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing of Singapore, citing drop in demand for chips used in communications products and computers, cuts first-quarter sales forecast; says production is at 59 percent of capacity; graph (S)

headline: Bush outlines theme for second term: Spreading liberty
They Even Stole a Backhoe in Broad Daylight
abstract: Construction site thefts, sometimes committed by people working there, cost industry nearly $1 billion annually despite antitheft efforts like offering reward to people who turn in thieves; drawing (M)

headline: Release of Consumers' Data Spurs ChoicePoint Inquiries
abstract: ChoicePoint, which inadvertently sold tens of thousands of consumer records to thieves masquerading as small-business clients, says it is subject of at least two consumer lawsuits, barrage of inquiries from state attorneys general and investigations by Securities and Exchange Commission and Federal Trade Commission; some corporate governance experts have raised questions about transactions of chief executive Derek Smith and president Douglas Curling, who began exercising large numbers of stock options and selling stock in November; photo (M)

headline: I.R.S. Accuses Man of Hiding $450 Million
abstract: Walter Anderson, chief executive of Orbital Recovery, is arrested and chaged with evading taxes by hiding at least $450 million of income through offshore corporations; indictment claims Anderson did not pay over $210 million in federal and local taxes he owed for years 1995 through 1999 alone; IRS Comr Mark W Everson comments; Anderson pleads not guilty; Magistrate Alan Kay orders Anderson held without bail until bond hearing on March 3; Anderson allegedly formed offshore corporation Gold and Appeal Transfer in British Virgin Island in 1992 to hide his profits from deals involving telecommunications company he started in 1980's (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Hate Crimes Double
abstract: National Consultative Commission for Human Rights report to French government cites increase in hate crimes to 1,565 cases in 2004 compared to 833 in 2003; agency secretary general Gerard Fellows asserts that increase is no longer linked to international events and ethnic violence is becoming common event in French society (S)

headline: Shares Gain as Drop in Oil Prices Eases Inflation Worries
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 2.86 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,174.28; Dow Jones industrial average gains 42.78 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,485.65; Nasdaq composite index rises 1.46 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,992.52; price and yield for 10-year US Treasury note noted; graphs; chart on key US interest rates (M)

headline: LABORATORY CORPORATION OF AMERICA TO BUY ESOTERIX
abstract: Laboratory Corp of America agrees to acquire Esoterix for about $150 million in cash (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Outcry At Claims Against Jews
abstract: Group of nationalist and Communist lawmakers withdraw seven-page appeal to Russian prosecutor general, which demanded investigation into wrongdoings by Jewish organizations, after human rights leaders, Russian liberals and Jewish leaders criticize plan (S)

headline: Universal's Second Chance to Make Video Pay
abstract: Universal Music Group of Vivendi Universal says it will not longer provide music videos free, or at nominal cost, to Internet and cable television services that are building potentially giant business by playing videos on demand; Universal does not want to repeat what it considers music industry's ill-fated decision in 1980's to provide free videos to MTV; Universal Music notifies Internet and cable companies that they must negotiate licensing deals for use of Universal's music videos or remove them from their on-demand services; record company also says it will not longer advertise on Internet sites or cable outlets that do not strike such licensing agreements; company struck its first deal under new terms in December with Microsoft Corp, which plays videos on its MSN service; agreed to pay Universal bigger of either fee per video viewed or percentage of advertising revenue; Universal's chairman Doug Morris comments; photos (M)

headline: Behind Those Medical Malpractice Rates
abstract: Legal costs do not seem to be root of recent increase in malpractice insurance premiums; government and industry data show only modest rise in malpractice claims over last decade; trend in payments in 2004 for malpractice claims against doctors and other medical professionals turned sharply downward, falling 8.9 percent, to nationwide total of $4.6 billion; specialists say more important factors for rise in premiums appear to be declining investment earnings of insurance companies and changing nature of completition in inudstry; graph (M)

headline: Vowing bigger pensions, Putin blames officials for turmoil
Revenue Up at Morningstar
abstract: Morningstar Inc reports net income of $9.9 million in first nine months of 2004; revenue rose 28 percent to $130.9 million from $102.4 million in first three quarters of 2003 (S)

headline: 2 Visitors Ask, How Can They Leave Without Their Son?
abstract: Anders Bang-Ericsson and his wife Lise say they will not leave Thailand until they know what happened to their 2 1/2-year-old son Ragnar, who has been missing since tsunami struck on Dec 26; nearly 700 Swedes are confirmed missing or dead, and additional 1,300 are unaccounted for; map; photo (M)

headline: Women's Wear Daily Setting Its Sights on the Luxury Market
abstract: Women's Wear Daily starts new high-end magazine, WWDScoop, which calls itself 'an insider's guide for the fashion jet set'; photo (M)

headline: Another Abrupt Departure of an Executive From an Interpublic Agency
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on unexpected and abrupt departure of chairwoman Marie-Jose Forissier from Initiative Worldwide; notes it is second abrupt departure in week from units of Interpublic Group (M)

headline: STANDARD & POOR'S ISSUES CAUTION ON DEBT OF 4 AIRLINES
abstract: Standard & Poor's places aircraft debt of America West, American Airlines, Continental Airlines and Northwest on CreditWatch with negative implications (S)

headline: I.B.M. Will Buy Ascential to Bolster Software Unit
abstract: IBM will acquire Ascential Software Corp for $1.1 billion in effort to broaden its offerings in market for corporate software (M)

headline: STINGER INTRODUCES STUN GUN TO COMPETE WITH TASER
abstract: Stinger Systems, a maker of electric stun guns, said that it had begun producing a gun exclusively for law enforcement and military use to compete with Taser International. Its weapon, the Stinger, can reach targets as far as 31 feet and comes with video and audio functions that can document use, the company said. It will be sent to about 1,000 police and law enforcement agencies for evaluation, Stinger said. Stock in the company, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., rose $1.98, to $11.68.

headline: European drug-firm deal
About.com, Primedia's Web Venture, Is for Sale
abstract: Primedia, publishing company owned by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, puts Web site About.com on block, and Google, Yahoo, New York Times Co, AOL unit of Time Warner Co and AskJeeves, plan to bid on it; asking price is $350 million to $500 million (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY FINANCE CORP., Omaha, a unit of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., sold $3.75 billion of debt in three parts after boosting the sale from an original $3 billion.    LINCOLN ELECTRIC HOLDINGS INC., Cleveland, a maker of welding equipment, said that it had agreed to buy J.W. Harris Co., Mason, Ohio, a maker of soldering alloys. Terms were not disclosed.    OLD DOMINION FREIGHT LINE INC., Thomasville, N.C., a regional trucking company, said it had agreed to buy Wichita Southeast Kansas Transit Inc., a freight transportation company. Terms were not disclosed.    CARNIVAL CORP., Miami, the cruise ship operator, said it would pay Fincantieri S.p.A. of Italy 474 million euros ($629 million) to build a liner.

headline: Shrink that search
J.P. Morgan Decides to Offer 2 Credit Cards
abstract: Ever since J P Morgan Chase and Bank One merged to b4

headline: EBay's Joy Ride: Going Once ...
abstract: People who sell on eBay protest steep fee increases announced in January, but eBay executives are not concerned, recalling protests that greeted previous increases and saying company wants to restore balance between those using auctions and those selling items for flat price in eBay stores; more worrisome for company are doubts raised by longtime sellers and Wall Street analysts about eBay's ability to keep up its torrid rate of growth; company's fortunes are thought to hinge ultimately less on growth rate of company's American site than on its foreign operations and on use of its PayPal payment system beyond eBay site; graphs; photos (L)

headline: With a Privacy Filter on Your Monitor, You Can Work and Others Can't See
abstract: 3M Co makes privacy filters to fit variety of computers, including laptops; prices start at about $50; photo (S)

headline: More Help Wanted: Older Workers Please Apply
abstract: Growing number of companies, after years of encouraging workers to take early retirement as way to cut jobs, are hunting for older workers because they have lower turnover rates and, in many cases, better work performance; some are recruiting at senior centers, while others send company brochures to churches and libraries and post their attractions on Web sites; AARP, advocacy group for older people, has put on its Web site links to employers recruiting older workers with offers of health benefits, training and flexible work schedules; graph of rising percentage of older Americans in work force; photos (M)

headline: Tiny Loans Stimulate the Appetite for More
abstract: Article on growth in microloan movement, which for almost three decades has created global network of tens of millions of female entrepreneurs and growing subclass of highly sophisticated business women; microloan companies, faced with growing number of women seeking more money--sometimes several thousand dollars--to build small businesses, hire employees and establish themselves in developing marketplace, are rethinking size of their financing packages; photo (M)

headline: Blast in Lebanon May Have Been Suicide Bomber, Officials Say
Japanese Free Bobby Fischer, Now an Icelander
abstract: American chess legend Bobby Fischer is freed after eight months in detention in Japan and leaves for Iceland, where he enjoys hero status and has been awarded citizenship; State Department holds charges against him for violating sanctions against former Yugoslavia by playing exhibition match there in 1992 should be addressed in United States (M)

headline: Before Christmas, Wal-Mart Was Stirring
abstract: Article on sales strategy used by Michael T Duke, president of stores unit of Wal-Mart, as early as day after Thanksgiving, when he realized sales would be down for holiday shopping season; Duke, sensing trouble, visited competition, including Best Buy, Target, Kohl's, Sears and other nearby discount merchants to compare how Wal-Mart was doing; Wal-Mart is expected to announce on Jan 6 that December sales achieved 3 percent gain over sales for December 2003; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Posts Profit
abstract: Vivendi Universal reports higher-than-expected fourth-quarter profit; net income was 1.84 billion euros ($2.46 billion) compared with loss of 642 million euros year ago (S)

headline: Xstrata prowls for 'treasure'
U.S. signals a new effort on Iran
THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices fall on speculation of ample supplies when consumption peaks later this year; futures for May delivery decline 79 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $54.05 a barrel in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Lopsided Win Is Seen in Tajikistan
abstract: Preliminary results in parliamentary elections in Tajikistan gives lopsided victory to ruling party of Pres Emomali Rakhmonov and draws failing grade from world's largest election-monitoring body and storm of protests from five other parties; opposition leaders announce lawsuit seeking to have results overturned (M)

headline: Rice warns N. Korea standoff can't last
Riggs Pleads Guilty in Money-Laundering Case
abstract: Riggs Bank pleads guilty to repeatedly failing to report suspicious transactions in accounts held by leaders of Equatorial Guinea and former Chilean dictator Gen Augusto Pinochet; agrees to pay $16 million penalty as part of deal to avoid prosecution of bank and holding company, Riggs National Corp, on charges related to money laundering; agrees to continue to cooperate with Justice Department investigation (M)

headline: GM, wooed by Germany and Sweden, makes its choice
World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: U.S. Jewish Group Wants Inquiry On World War II Children
abstract: Rabbi Shumel Herzfeld, Coalition of Jewish Concerns Vice President, announces that group is calling for Vatican to open records regarding Jewish children harbored by Catholic families during World War II; contends that some children may not have been allowed to return to their families and religious communities after war (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Guard Shot To Death Outside British Envoy's Home
abstract: Greek police officer, who was guarding home of British envoy Col Mark Blatherwick in Kifissia, is shot and killed; Blatherwick's predecessor Brig Stephen Saunders was killed four years ago while driving to work (S)

headline: FREUDIAN SIDE-SLIP
abstract: Quiksilver's 2005 proxy statement refers to Sarbanes-Oakley Act rather than Sarbanes-Oxley Act in explaining why company, manufacturer of surfer gear, has stopped making loans to executives (S)

headline: AES TO ACQUIRE A WIND ENERGY PRODUCER, SEAWEST
abstract: Electric power producer AES Corp agrees to buy SeaWest Holdings, privately held wind energy company, for about $60 million (S)

headline: Seoul allows mass suits against fraudulent firms
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ex-WorldCom Chief Denies Knowing of Wrongdoing  Prosecutors tried to show that Bernard J. Ebbers, the former WorldCom chief executive accused of securities fraud, had to have known about the company's doctored books.      Mr. Ebbers, however, said during his nearly six hours on the stand that he was unaware of any wrongdoing and that he trusted Scott D. Sullivan, WorldCom's former chief fiscal officer, to handle the financial matters. [Page C2.]    Martha Stewart's Publisher Quits  Suzanne Sobel, left, the longtime publisher of magazines at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, has resigned. The company said Lauren Podlach Stanich, the president of publishing, would take over for Ms. Sobel during the search for a successor. The timing struck some investors and analysts as odd, given the recent rise in the company's fortunes and Ms. Stewart's release from prison in a few days. Ms. Sobel, who oversaw advertising sales, helped guide the company through the difficulties it encountered as a result of Ms. Stewart's legal troubles. [C2.]    Take 2 Aspirin and E-Mail the Doctor  Doctors are being paid by health plans and medical groups to answer e-mail messages, providing them with more time to spend with patients who need to be seen. [A1.]    Marsh Rescue Plan Unveiled  Marsh & McLennan, which reported a loss of $676 million for the fourth quarter, is laying off 2,500 employees, cutting its dividend, increasing the commissions it charges, and dropping unprofitable clients. Market Place. [C9.]    F.D.A. Official Admits Lapses  After months of the Food and Drug Administration insisting that it did nothing wrong in its oversight of the withdrawn pain pill Vioxx, an agency official acknowledged before a Senate panel ''lapses'' in the agency's actions. [A15.]    The Los Angeles Times Scales Back  The Los Angeles Times has scaled back its national edition, which circulates in Washington and New York, into a 24-page format without paid advertising. [C5.]    Qwest Questions Verizon's MCI Bid  The chief executive of Qwest Communications, Richard C. Notebaert, told investors that Verizon Communications would and should face serious regulatory hurdles in its bid to acquire MCI. Mr. Notebaert made his remarks as part of an effort to persuade Wall Street investors and analysts that MCI would be better off rejecting Verizon as a suitor and accepting Qwest as a merger partner. [C4.]    Official Criticizes Pension Rules  The assistant Treasury secretary for economic policy told a Senate panel that current pension funding rules are inaccurate. [C8.]    Telecom Battle Waged in Poland  A dispute between French and German companies over the ownership of a Polish mobile telephone company has led to new managers being barred from the building. [C8.]    Strong Growth in Brazil in 2004  The Brazilian economy expanded in 2004 at its fastest pace in a decade, with booming exports and a sharp increase in consumer spending helping it rebound. [C8.]    Stocks Move Up as Oil Price Falls  Stocks were higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 63.77 points, to 10,830.00; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 6.81 points, to 1,210.41, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 19.53 points, to 2,071.25. [C9.]    COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE    ENCLOSED MALLS are trying to find a way to survive now that department store chains continue to merge and open-air shopping centers proliferate. [C7.]  A NEW JERSEY DEVELOPER has moved away from residential rentals. [C6.]

headline: China Reins in Producer Prices
abstract: China's producer prices rose 5.8 percent in January, the slowest pace in nine months, as lending restrictions helped rein in an investment boom that has strained supplies of energy and raw materials.    The January figures, announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Statistics in Beijing, followed a 7.1 percent rise in December over December 2003. Producer price inflation has slowed from 8.4 percent in October.

headline: Vote puts Sinn Fein to test
Palestinian vows to reshape cabinet
Tyco's Ex-Chief Was Not Told of Bylaw Violation, Jury Is Told
abstract: Former Tyco International director Stephen Foss testifies that board never told former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski that paying $20 million finder's fee to former finance chief Mark Swartz in connection with 2001 purchase of CIT Group Inc violated company bylaws (M)

headline: Abuse outraged navy at Guantnamo Bay
Zoellick to tour NATO countries
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MODTECH HOLDINGS, Perris, Calif., which manufactures modular buildings, said it would close a plant in Northern California, cutting about 140 jobs.    CEDAR SHOPPING CENTERS, Port Washington, N.Y., said it had agreed to buy 27 retail properties in four states, most of them anchored by drugstores, for about $90 million.    NAUTIC PARTNERS, Providence, R.I., a buyout fund, said it planned to begin raising about $1 billion for its sixth fund next year to make manufacturing, telecommunications and media acquisitions.

headline: Tsunami aid arriving with rare speed
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush Picks Acting Chief To Be Leader of F.D.A.  President Bush said he would nominate Dr. Lester Crawford, the acting commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, to be the agency's permanent commissioner.    Dr. Crawford has made priorities out of speeding drug approvals, protecting drugs and food from terrorist attacks and improving the manufacture of medicines. [Page A1.]    Research into new ways of fighting pain has been given new impetus by the withdrawal of Vioxx and questions about similar pills. [F1.]    Air Force Contract Inquiry Widens  The Pentagon is investigating eight more Air Force contracts as part of a broader investigation into influence-peddling involving a former Air Force official and Boeing. [C2.]    Top Executive of OfficeMax Resigns  Christopher C. Milliken, the chief executive of OfficeMax, resigned in the wake of accounting problems at the company involving improprieties in the way it accounted for rebates from a large supplier. OfficeMax said it had fired six employees as a result of an internal investigation which confirmed that workers had fabricated documents. [C3.]    Show Contestant Kills Himself  A contestant in a new NBC reality series about boxing scheduled to start next month has committed suicide, network executives said. They said the show would go on as planned. [C10.]    Stocks Are Mixed; A.I.G. Stumbles  The Dow fell 4.88 points, to 10,791.13, retreating from its high for the year, as shares in American International Group dropped. The Nasdaq composite climbed 6.25 points, to 2,082.91, and the S.&P. 500 rose 0.84 point, to 1,206.14. [C11.]    Ads for Splenda Are Criticized  Two unusual partners are saying that a unit of Johnson & Johnson should stop implying that its artificial sweetener, Splenda, is natural because it is made from sugar. [A12.]    Judge Instructs Jury in Zoloft Case  The judge in the trial of Christopher Pittman, who killed his grandparents while taking Pfizer's drug Zoloft, gave the jury an option to acquit him without finding him insane. [A10.]    Traveling Is Tough for the Hefty  Plus-sized travelers can run into demoralizing situations. Nadine Thompson, left, the chief executive of a direct sales company, is suing Southwest Airlines because she says it asked that she buy the seat next to her or leave the plane. The treatment large people get on the ground is often not much better. [C9.]    One athlete who weighs more than 400 pounds has developed techniques for surviving flights. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C9.]    Nokia to Use Microsoft Formats  Nokia, the leading cellphone manufacturer, agreed to use Microsoft's music formats in its phones. [C4.]    Judge to Consider Yukos Case  A judge will decide this week whether a bankruptcy case pitting the Russian oil company Yukos against the Kremlin can proceed in the United States. [C8.]    Ads in Pursuit of Big Legal Game  A Baltimore-area lawyer has started a million-dollar advertising campaign, hoping to land a billion-dollar case. Advertising. [C10.]

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Army Accused Of Killing Peasants
abstract: Labor leader Carlos Ortega, who led two-month anti-government oil strike two years ago, is arrested and charged with trason and inciting rebellion; Ortega had been living in Costa Rica until his asylum there was overturned and he was forced to return to Venezuela; photo (S)

headline: OTHER SHOE DROPS
abstract: Bernard B Kerik, New York's former police commissioner, resigns from Taser International board three months after having to withdraw his nomination to run Department of Homeland Security (S)

headline: Ailing Prince Rainier in intensive care
Drug companies promise more data
HASBRO TO SELL GAMES WITH NICKELODEON CHARACTERS
abstract: Hasbro To Sell Games Wit

headline: I.R.A. Says It Will Quit Peace Negotiations in Northern Ireland
abstract: Irish Republican Army says it is withdrawing from peace negotiations in Northern Ireland and rescinding its proposals to disarm and cease paramilitary activities, because of what it calls false accusations and bad faith by British and Irish governments; does not say it would return to brutal violence that claimed most of 3,000 lives lost in 30-year conflict, or that it would end cease-fire that it says it has upheld since 1997; Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain and Prime Min Bertie Ahern of Ireland have blamed IRA for $50 million robbery from Belfast bank in Dec (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
Witness Recalls Ovitz's Efforts to Make Deals
abstract: Deals that Michael S. Ovitz tried to put together during his tenure as president of the Walt Disney Company would ''have paid his salary tenfold'' if the company had pursued them, an expert witness hired by Mr. Ovitz testified Wednesday.    The witness, Larry Feldman, a trial lawyer in California, testified in a lawsuit brought by shareholders who claim Disney should have fired Mr. Ovitz for deception and ethical breaches in his role as an executive.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands Stage Mass Rally in Taiwan
Study Faults U.S. Response to Outlawed Arms
abstract: Presidential commission on United States intelligence concludes that government has failed to respond to dire threat posed by unconventional weapons with great enough urgency and national purpose; report gives grim account of spy agencies' capabilities, despite steady increase in intelligence budget since 9/11 attacks; this is latest of several scathing assessments of intelligence failures; succession of reports designed to fix blame for botched intelligence on 9/11 attacks and Iraqi weapons has generated some wariness and cynicism at agencies (M)

headline: At a Crucial Oil Juncture, a Russian Calls on China
abstract: Russia's Energy Min Viktor B Khristenko makes quiet trip to Beijing over weekend; trip, which is not reported in Chinese or Russian media, is confirmed by Western businessman involved in China's oil business and Russian source close to embassy; visit comes at crucial time in energy diplomacy between two countries, which share 2,640-mile border and history of antagonism; Khristenko's unusually low-key visit takes place just days after he announced that Russia is willing to sell China stake in oil producer Yuganskneftegaz; trip also comes after recent announcement that Russia will route oil pipeline to Pacific Coast of Siberia instead of to Chinese oil hub of Daqing, route favored by China; photo (M)

headline: Stewart's Comeback
abstract: Since Martha Stewart was convicted in March, the stock in the company she founded has nearly tripled and her value as a marketing tool appears to have grown.     Article, Page C1.

headline: Rally in Semiconductor Issues Spreads to Broader Indexes
abstract: Stocks gained yesterday, aided by a rally in semiconductor shares after Intel said sales this quarter would beat analysts' estimates.    The benchmark indexes erased earlier declines that followed disappointing earnings from United Parcel Service and an unexpected widening of the nation's trade deficit.

headline: Executive for Home Depot
abstract: Home Depot hires Roger W Adams, advertising executive at General Motors, as its senior vice president for marketing, effective Feb 7 (S)

headline: Airline Obtains Financing
abstract: Airline Obtains Finan

headline: CBS DISMISSES 4 OVER BROADCAST ON BUSH SERVICE
abstract: CBS dismisses four of its top journalists, including high-ranking news executive, after independent panel concludes that report that raised questions about Pres Bush's Vietnam-era National Guard service, aired during Bush's re-election campaign, never should have been broadcast; panel concludes that network's news division, in dash to beat its competitors, suffered breakdown in judgment as it rushed report onto air on Sept 8; finds report was approved by inattentive executivies, was delivered by overworked anchor Dan Rather, and did not undergo even most rudimentary fact-checking; segment was broadcast on 60 Minutes II; presented four documents suggesting that Bush received preferential treatment in Texas Air National Guard in 1970's; panel says documents were not properly authenticated; says it found no indication that internal inquiry ordered by CBS News president Andrew Heyward two days after broadcast was pursued; following report, CBS chairman Leslie Moonves fires Mary Mapes, producer in charge of segment, and demands resignations from Betsy West, senior vice president and top deputy to Heyward, Josh Howard, executive producer of Wednesday edition of 60 Minutes, and Mary Murphy, his deputy; Dan Rather, who played only limited role in assembling report, previously announced that he would step down as anchor of CBS Evening News in Mar but will continue on 60 Minutes and 60 Minutes II; members of independent panel are Louis D Boccardi and Dick Thornburgh; photos; excerpts from panel's findings (L)

headline: E*Trade Hires Omnicom as Agency
abstract: E*Trade Financial names BBDO Worldwide as agency of record, replacing Martin/Williams (S)

headline: No 'Smoking Gun' in the Inquiry Into Iraq's Prewar Oil Sales
abstract: Paul A Volcker says report of his investigation into scandal-tainted oil-for-food program in Iraq will not produce any 'smoking gun'; appears to be seeking to lower expectations of what might be in his much-anticipated preliminary report, due this month; program's former director Benon V Sevan has been accused of accepting illegal oil allocations worth millions of dollars, and United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan has come under personal suspicion because one of contracting companies employed his son Kojo Annan; Volcker's final report is due in June (M)

headline: Advisor Accepts Ban in NASD Fraud Case
abstract: Todd M Eberhard, former president of Eberhard Investment Associates who pleaded guilty in September to federal charges that he defrauded clients of up to $20 million, agrees to be barred from investment industry in settlement with NASD (S)

headline: Europa: From America, Europe seems a long way off
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Cable Company Reworks Debt
abstract: Net Servicos de Comunicacao, Brazil's largest cable company, finishes restructuring 1.4 billion reais ($511 million) in debt that it defaulted on in December 2002; Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, raises its stake in holding company that controls Net, GB Participacoes, to 49 percent; remaining 51 percent is held by Organizacoes Globo, Brazil's biggest media group (M)

headline: In a First, CNN Runs A Liquor Commercial
abstract: CNN has shown commercial for Grey Goose vodka, making it first national cable TV news network to carry liquor advertising; spot was created by DeVito/Verdi and is part of eight-week, 60-spot scheduled for Grey Goose, sold by Bacardi (S)

headline: Summon Help With a Single Button
abstract: Emergency cellphone from Wherify Wireless lets user contact relatives or emergency services by pressing one button and provides information about his or her whereabouts; photo (S)

headline: White House Fought New Curbs on Interrogations, Officials Say
abstract: White House urged Congressional leaders to scrap legislative measure that would have imposed new restrictions on use of extreme interrogation measures by American intelligence officers; defeat of proposal affects one of most obscure arenas of war on terrorism, involving Central Intelligence Agency's secret detention and interrogation of top terrorist leaders like Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, mastermind of 9/11 attacks, and about three dozen other senior members of Al Qaeda and its offshoots; Congressional officials describe intense closed-door negotiations last month after White House expressed opposition to new restrictions in intelligence reform bill that passed in Senate by vote of 96 to 2; say four senior members from House and Senate then deleted restrictions from measure; some Democratic Congressional officials say they believe Bush administration was trying to maintain some legal latitude for CIA to use interrogation practices more extreme than those permitted by military (M)

headline: For Those at the Wrong End of the Horns
abstract: CLG Pro Rodeo Equipment makes improvement in vest it sells to rodeo bull riders to protect them better from hoofs and horns; photo (M)

headline: For European Jews, it fits better on the right
REUTERS TO TRANSFER BRIDGE TRADING TO INSTINET
abstract: Reuters agrees to transfer Bridge Trading Co to its Instinet Group for $21.5 million in Instinet stock; says it is assessing sale of Instinet (S)

headline: Exxon Mobil Earnings Jumped 27% in Quarter
abstract: Exxon Mobil says fourth-quarter profit rose 27 percent, to record $8.42 billion, as fuel sales rose and demand spurred price gains; net income climbed to $1.30 per share from $1.01 a share, or $6.65 billion, year earlier; full-year profit was $25.3 billion; oil prices rose to record, swelling company's 2004 sales to $298 billion; fourth-quarter sales rose 26 percent, to $83.4 billion (M)

headline: SARA LEE LOWERS EARNINGS OUTLOOK FOR 2005
abstract: Sara Lee Corp lowers 2005 earnings forecast and announces plan to sell European clothing business and make cost-cutting measures (S)

headline: Correction
GLAXO RECEIVES SECOND CLAIM FROM I.R.S. IN TAX DISPUTE
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline says tax dispute with United States might cost company $7.8 billion; has received second claim from Internal Revenue Service, which is seeking $1.9 billion in taxes on profits earned from 1997 to 2000, before merger that formed company (S)

headline: How Close Was Hitler to the A-Bomb?
A Witness's Personal Life Is Fair Game in Ebbers Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Bernard J Ebbers, former chief executive of WorldCom Inc accused of securities fraud, wins right to introduce personal details about former chief financial officer Scott D Sullivan, prosecution's main witness; Federal Judge Barbara S Jones says defense should be allowed to introduce details about 'marital infidelities' of Sullivan because it would help jury determine his reliability as witness; prosecutors had opposed introduction of information; Sullivan has pleaded guilty to charges of securities fraud and agreed to testify against Ebbers in hope of reducing his sentence; photo (M)

headline: Executives of Nortel Will Repay Bonuses
abstract: Nortel Networks releases much-delayed audited financial statements for 2001 to 2003 and says internal inquiry shows that executives manipulated initial results to obtain bonuses; says dozen current executives who played no role in manipulation will repay $8.6 million in bonuses voluntarily over three yeas; will also give up last two installments of restricted stock payout dating back to 2003; Nortel's financial review finds company's earnings in 2003 were $434 million, down from $732 million reported originally; revenue for 2003 rose to $10.1 billion from $9.8 billion; Securities and Exchange Commission has begun formal inquiry into accounting practices at company; Ontario Securities Commission and Royal Canadian Mounted Police are also conducting probes; Nortel announces that five longtime directors, including chairman Lynton Wilson, will not seek re-election (M)

headline: Even Buffett Can't Avoid Dark Clouds Settling Over Insurance Industry
abstract: Growing investigation into insurance practices has ensnared General Re, one of Berkshire Hathaway's main businesses, controlled by Warren E Buffett, raising possibility that Buffett's gleaming reputation in corporate America may be tarnished; Securities and Exchange Commission and New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer's office have been investigating deal between General Re and American International Group that may have been artificially bolstered AIG's finances; investigators are looking into other so-called finite insurance deals by Buffett's companies; insurance experts, in defense of Buffett, say Buffett's management of Berkshire is very different from Maurice R Greenberg's time at AIG; while Greenberg had his hands on practically every aspect of AIG, Buffett, known more for his investing acumen than management prowess, prefers to delegate; Buffett has not been named in any of insurance probes; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tibetan Pilgrims Killed In Truck Crash
abstract: A traffic accident in western China on Monday killed 54 Tibetans returning from a religious pilgrimage and left 29 others seriously injured, state media reported. A truck carrying the pilgrims overturned in an expanse of Qinghai Province as the passengers were returning from Lhasa, the spiritual center of Tibetan Buddhism. Qinghai is one of China's most rugged areas.   Jim Yardley (NYT)

headline: Mugabe forecasts 'huge' election victory
G.M. and Ford Lose Ground in Sales Again
abstract: Sales at General Motors Corp fell 12.6 percent in February from same month year earlier; Ford Motor Co's sales fell 2.8 percent; both companies scaled back numbers of cars and trucks they planned to make as unsold models accumate on dealer lots, though GM's cuts were deeper and it is showing few signs of turnaround; GM says it will shuffle its senior top management ranks and give several top North American executives broader global responsibilities; auto sales in US fell 1.8 percent in February from same month year earlier, to seasonally adjusted rate of 16.3 million cars and trucks; Toyota's sales were up 11.1 percent, Nissan sales rose 10.2 percent and Hyundai's 19 percent; Honda sales were down 7.2 percent, while Mitsubishi's sales declined 40 percent in February; graph; chart (M)

headline: Dispute Puts a Medical Journal Under Fire
abstract: British medical journal BMJ may face lawsuit from Eli Lilly & Co for New Year's Day article suggesing that 'missing' documents from decade-old lawsuit indicated that Lilly, maker of Prozac, minimized data about drug's risks for causing suicidal or violent behavior; article has been cited in hundreds of television and newspaper reports; but some of documents cited in BMJ article have been circulating for years, and Lilly officials claim BMJ and its reporter refused to provide copies of documents at issue prior to article's publication; Lilly's lawyers notify BMJ that company considers article 'inaccurate and defamatory,' and that records were not missing; photo (M)

headline: Lightweight Projector Brings You a Home Theater That Can Travel
abstract: You can find video projectors that are smaller, cheaper or sharper than Mitsubishi's new HC100U, but you probably will not find one that is all three.    It may sound like faint praise to call the HC100U a solid compromise, but at 6.5 pounds and 12 by 4 by 10 inches, it is small and light enough to move to the children's room for a wall-size screening of ''The Little Mermaid'' or to cart to the office for a PowerPoint presentation. The $1,500 list price (expected to be $1,200 at stores) makes it a bargain, relatively speaking.

headline: EMI earnings hit by music sales slump
In Thrown-to-Lions Trial, Bloody Clothes Remain
abstract: Prosecutors in rural South African hamlet produced blood-soaked clothes of man they say was fed to lions by former employer; Mark Scott-Crossley allegedly ordered two other workers to beat Nelson Chisale and dump him in nearby breeding enclosure for 20 rare white lions (S)

headline: As aid gains steam, Asia aims for warning system
Sony warns of lower sales and profit for year
World Briefings
World Briefing | Asia: Turkmenistan: Gas To Ukraine Halted
abstract: Turkmenistan government, citing maintenance, stops sending natural gas via pipeline to Ukraine; Pres Saparmurat A Niyazov has been reported saying oil prices may increase from $44 to $60 per 1,000 cubic meters (S)

headline: Black-Focused Agencies Form a Trade Group
abstract: Ten agencies that specialize in advertising aimed at African-American consumers form trade organization, Assn of Black-Owned Advertising Agencies; E Morris Communications chairman and chief executive Eugene Morris is named interim chairman (S)

headline: Italy plans to cut back its troops inIraq
Bush seesa 'strategy for success' in Iraq
Pakistani's Black MarketMay Sell Nuclear Secrets
abstract: Nuclear investigators from United States and other nations now believe that black market network run by Pakistani scientist A Q Khan was selling not only technology for enriching nuclear fuel and blueprints for nuclear weapons, but also hard-to-master engineering secrets needed to fabricate nuclear warheads; their suspicion were initially raised by discovery of step-by-step instructions, some of which appear to have come from China and Pakistan, among documents discovered last year from Libya; more recently, investigators have found that Khan network had offered similar materials to Iran; secrets range from how to cast uranimum metal into the form needed at core of a bomb to how to build explosive lenses that compress core and start detonation; Khan photo (M)

headline: Revisions passed on the French work law
An Arsenal of Sanitizers for a Nation of Germophobes
abstract: Article, in light of movie The Aviator, which portrays Howard Hughes as germophobe, on plethora of germ-fighting products and devices that are available to American consumers; photos (M)

headline: 3 car bombs and a roadside attack kill 16 in Iraq
Besieged Chief of Atomic Agency Carries On
abstract: Mohamed ElBaradei, director general of International Atomic Energy Agency, will address annual conference of World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, to flesh out his proposal for five-year moratorium on building uranium-enrichment facilities, to stop spread of atomic weapons to Iran or other countries; under his plan, countries would be able to lease enriched fuel from international consortium; this would enable them to operate nuclear reactors to generate electricity without having to build facilities that could be converted to weapons production (M)

headline: Jet-Setter's Life Includes a Few Wrinkles
abstract: Martin Pakledinaz, freelance costume designer for Broadway, opera and ballet productions, in Frequent Flier column, on some of his not-so-pleasant travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Asked to Resign, 3 at CBS Hire Lawyers Instead
abstract: Betsy West, senior vice president for CBS News, Josh Howard, executive producer of Wednesday edition of 60 Minutes, and Mary Murphy, Howard's deputy, who were aksed to resign on Jan 10 because of flawed report on Pres Bush's National Guard service, have yet to step down; all three journalists have hired lawyers, each of whom has had at least preliminary conversations with those representing CBS; Howard and Murphy have been offered cash settlements that are equivalent to less than year's salary; each has thus far refused those offers (M)

headline: Science vs. Culture in Mexico's Corn Staple
abstract: Discovery of genetically modified corn in tiny plots in Capulalpam de Mendez, Mexico, birthplace of maize agriculture, sets off national furor over alleged assault by American agribusiness; Mexican Congress passed controversial biosecurity law in February, dividing Mexican scientists and alarming United States with at threat to 5.5 million tons of corn US sells Mexico annually, mostly for animal feed; at center of problem is dispute over whether Mexico's embrace of North American Free Trade Agr eement can coexist with age-old farming practices and whether modified corn is threat to Mexico's role as seed bank; map (M)

headline: Briefs: Coors-Molson deal clears vote
May Your Portfolio Have a Pleasant Afterlife
abstract: Ben Stein column describes investment portfolio he designed, with some outside expertise, to ensure that his wife and teenage son would be taken care of in case he should die; drawing (M)

headline: Four to Be Inducted Into Hall of Fame
abstract: American Advertising Federation names four executives to join Advertising Hall of Fame for 2005: Thomas Jr Burrell, chairman emeritus at Burrell Communications Group, Roger A Enrico, chairman of DreamWorks Animation, Harry M Jacobs, chairman emeritus at Martin Agency and Ted Turner (S)

headline: For Labor, a Wal-Mart Store Closing in Canada Is a Call to Arms
abstract: Wal-Mart's decision to close store in Jonquiere, Quebec, this spring because of low store revenue and escalating union demands is having much broader impact across Canada and even in US; closing--first of a Wal-Mart in Canada--is strategic retreat for retailer in its war with organized labor; at least three other Wal-Mart outlets in Quebec have received bomb threats since Jonquiere closing announcement, forcing evacuations and losses in sales; union leaders say Wal-Martn is using Jonquiere as example to whip workers into line at second Wal-Mart store outside Montreal that successfully organized in January and in more than 20 other outlets in at least three provinces where organizing efforts have begun; they also claim that 17-to-1 vote against unionization at Wal-Mart Tire and Lube Express in Loveland, Colo, in late February because workers feared organizing union could mean loss of their jobs; photo (M)

headline: In '05, Buffett Says He's Still Betting Against the Dollar
abstract: Market Place column on Berkshire Hathaway annual report; company head Warren E Buffett says in report that he should have sold stocks in late 1990's instead of just complaining that they were overvalued; says he acts on his view that dollar is still headed down; report shows that over half of $3.5 billion in pretax gains on investments company realized in 2004 came from betting against dollar, including $1.8 billion from foreign exchange contracts; 2004 earnings fell to $7.

headline: Death and Damage in Myanmar Are Now Believed to Be Relatively Light, U.N. Study Says
abstract: United Nations concludes that damage to Myanmar from tsunami was relatively light, with just over 50 people confirmed dead and several thousand in need of assistance (M)

headline: MEADOW VALLEY WILL SPIN OFF READY MIX, A CONCRETE MAKER
abstract: The Meadow Valley Corporation, a heavy construction contractor, said yesterday that it would sell shares in its Ready Mix division, a maker of concrete, to take the unit public. Meadow Valley, based in Phoenix, said it would sell a million shares in Ready Mix at $12 a share. After the sale, Meadow Valley will hold 60 percent of the shares of Ready Mix, which is based in Las Vegas. Ready Mix expects to use proceeds from the offering for working capital, to buy equipment and to repay debt to Meadow Valley.

headline: France doubles sale of its bonds
SAKS DISCLOSES FORMAL S.E.C. INVESTIGATION
abstract: Saks Inc says Securities and Exchange Commission has opened formal probe into whether company improperly collected as much as $21.5 million from vendors (S)

headline: Stocks: The Dow heads for 3rd week of losses
Another Income Tax Denier Will Have His Day in Court
abstract: Al Thompson, owner of Cencal Aviation Products, to go on trial in Sacramento for willful failure to file tax returns and failure to turn over more than $500,000 that should have been withheld from employees' paychecks; trial is expected to last three weeks, and major piece of evidence will be videotape of gathering with employees four years ago in which Thompson announced he stopped withholding taxes and Joseph R Banister, former Internal Revenue Service criminal investigator who became Thompson's accountant, being questioned about court rulings that have rejected similar antitax arguments (M)

headline: Adelphia Board's Choices Complicate a Bidding Process
abstract: Board of Adelphia Communications weighs number of options as deadline approaches for bids on its cable system; shares of Time Warner and Comcast have slid as investors and analysts conclude that their joint bid to meet asking price of $17.5 billion may be too high; other options being weighed by Adelphia are selling pieces to financial buyers or simply keeping its assets and emerging from bankruptcy proceedings (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Mladic Aide Imprisoned
abstract: Milan Gvero, senior aide to Bosnian Serb fugitive Gen Ratko Mladic, surrenders to United Nations war crimes tribunal; over dozen suspects are at large and Serbian government has been warned that more alleged criminals must come forward if Serbia wants to pursue better relations with European Union or NATO (S)

headline: NEW YORK LIFE SAYS EARNINGS ROSE 15 PERCENT IN 2004
abstract: New York Life Insurance Co says net income rose 15 percent last year, to $1.29 billion, as sales of life insurance and annuities surged; net income increased from $1.12 billion in 2003; revenue rose 16 percent, to $17.3 billion; net worth climbed 9.5 percent in 2004, to $11.8 billion (S)

headline: Boats and Cars? Oh, Not the Jet!
abstract: Federal prosecutors seek to seize racing boat, classic cars, jewelry and other items that it says Richard M Scrushy bought with proceeds of fraud they say he committed when he was chief executive of HealthSouth; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Dow Turns Over Molecule Patents
abstract: Dow Chemical turns over portfolio of patents for family of designer molecules called dendritic polymers to Dendritic NanoTechnologies; will receive stake of just over 30 percent in Dendritic; Starpharma, which is developing drugs based on technology, will inject undisclosed sum into Dendritic, reduce its stake and gain exclusive licenses to some patents (S)

headline: Federal Reserve Raises Key Rate .25%
SIEMENS TO BUY CTI MOLECULAR FOR $967 MILLION
abstract: Siemens agrees to purchase CTI Molecular Imaging for about $967 million (S)

headline: Iraqis Report a Variety of Complaints About Irregularities on Election Day
abstract: Claims of election irregularities surface around Iraq as national euphoria over high turnout and seemingly smooth operation of vote fades slightly; protests erupt in northern cities over charge that hundreds of thousands of people, including many Kurdish Christians, could not vote because balloting materials arrived inexplicably late; photo of Mosul official Khasro Goran; huge crowd of Shiites returning from Mecca say they were kept from getting home in time to vote; other complaints quoted (M)

headline: Syrian intelligence agents quit Beirut
Follow the Vanishing Check
abstract: Electronic transactions are rapidly replacing checks as way to pay for goods and services; Federal Reserve says number of checks written in US peaked sometime in mid-1990's; it has been falling precipitously for last four years; checks are still used more often than either credit or debit cards, but declines reported recently by big banks--as much as 10 percent from year ago--are so steep that checks over next two decades are likely to become as prevalent as electric typewriters; checks accounted for 45 percent of all payments that were not made with cash in 2003, down from 57 percent in 2000; some users of electronic bill paying comment; photos (M)

headline: Japan looks to modify its pacifism
Oil Exchange Sets Shift
abstract: International Petroleum Exchange will shut down its trading pits in London on April 7 and offer full-time electronic trading (S)

headline: For the Digerati, the Only Place to Be
abstract: About 130,000 people are expected at annual Consumer Electronics Show at Las Vegas Convention Center; various new electronic gadgets that will be on display discussed; photo (M)

headline: Once a Village, Now Nothing: Even the Bodies Are Gone
abstract: Indonesian coastal town of Calang, where thousands of people were swept away by tsunami, has not just been destroyed, it has vanished; most of town's 7.300 people are missing; only 323 bodies have been found; Calang and many other villages on western coast of Aceh Province have been wiped from map; suffering along land closest to earthquake's epicenter has been compounded by its remoteness; devastation is great and numbers in need is huge; much of terrain is accessible only by helicopter; photos; map (M)

headline: HUMANA RAISES PROFIT ESTIMATE FOR FIRST QUARTER
abstract: Humana expects its profit to rise to 61 cents to 63 cents a share in first quarter, more than earlier forecast; says revenue for full year will be about $14.5 billion; estimates its enrollment in its Medicare programs will rise to 470,000 to 485,000 by end of year (S)

headline: On Public TV, Not Quite an Ad but Pretty Close
abstract: Producers and distributors, to raise money for public television programming, are increasingly letting corporate underwriters turn their credits into something resembling regular commercials; sponsors are taking advantage of Public Broadcasting Service rule change on content of credits to create livelier sponsorship segments with traditional trappings, including jingles and slogans; Chipotle Mexican Grill credit that pushes closer traditional advertising than ever before cited; photos (M)

China Netcom Buys Stake in Hong Kong Phone Company for $1 Billion

Investing: Penny stock high rollers

abstract: Alltel agrees to buy Western Wireless, regional carrier in Northwest, in deal worth about $6 billion in cash, stock and debt; deal will create company with about $10 billion in sales and 9.8 million subscribes, or about 6 percent of cellphone market (M)

headline: Iraqis fire on protesters, killing one
Builders swoop in after wave
At Forum, Leaders Confront Annual Enigma of China
abstract: China's staggering potential coupled with steep language barrier make it Davos World Economic Forum's annual enigma; China's Vice Prime Min Huang Ju gives reassuring speech but says little on issues of overriding importance; West wonders if China will allow currency to rise against dollar; cultural disconnect remains problem for Chinese at summit; they seem to prefer watching Davos to taking part in it; photo (M)

headline: BMW Plans to Buy Back 10% of Stock
abstract: BMW says fourth-quarter profit rose 29 percent; net income increased to 549 million euros ($737 million) from 424 million euros year earlier; revenue rose 0.2 percent, to 11.01 billion euros; company will propose raising dividend to 62 cents a common share from 58 cents and dividend for preferred shares to 64 cents from 60 cents; plans to buy back 10 percent of stock; photo (M)0

headline: Shares Drop on Concerns That Profit Growth Will Slow
abstract: Stocks dropped yesterday as a rally in shares of Hewlett-Packard after the ouster of its chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, failed to override concern that earnings growth was slowing.     Technology stocks led the decline after Cisco Systems, the maker of computer-networking equipment, forecast its smallest sales increase in six quarters.

abstract: Charles F Dolan, chairman and controlling shareholder of Cablevision Systems, is forming company called Voom HD to buy remaining assets of Voom, troubled satellite company that Cablevision board decided to sell to EchoStar Communications in January over Dolan's objections (M)

abstract: Michael Fazende is named executive creative director, new post at Fahlgren Advertising; William Haney, who had served since 2002 as executive vice president and director for corporate communications at Foote Cone & Belding, retired last week (S)

abstract: Tamaulipas State Gov Eugenio Hernandez Flores, in response to wave of drug-related violence along Mexico's border with Texas, is purging corrupt officers from state's police agencies (S)

abstract: ILLA, Iraq, Feb 28 - A suicide car bomber killed 105 people and wounded 130 near a crowded marketplace south of Baghdad on Monday in the single bloodiest attack in Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Online Searchers for Job Seekers
abstract: Handful of companies like Indeed.com, SimplyHired.com and WorkZoo are introducing services that scan both well-known and obscure online employment boards for job seekers; big job sites seem willing in short term to let search sites scan their listings and send them customers; photo (M)

headline: 2-Day Rally Aside, It's a Bearish January
abstract: January has been bearish month for investors despite two-day rally; investors are withdrawing money from domestic stock funds and pouring money into international funds; Dow Jones industrial average rises 37.03 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,498.59, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 5.66 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,174.07; Nasdaq composite index gains 26.14 points, or 1.3 percent, to 2,046.09; graphs; charts (Market Place column) (M)

abstract: Pakistan's Parliament defeats bill that would strengthen law outlawing honor killings, despite concerns from rights agencies that existing law has too many loopholes and does not adequately protect women and girls from murder (S)

Mandela, Anti-AIDS Crusader, Says Son Died of Disease
abstract: Nelson Mandela, longtime crusader against AIDS, says his son Makgatho has died of the disease; says he is disclosing news to focus more attention on AIDS, which is still taboo topic among many South Africans; elder Mandela has campaigned for greater awareness of AIDS and HIV both personally and through Nelson Mandela Foundation; has acknowledged that as president he did not recognize severity of epidemic in his own nation; in 2002, when his successor Thabo Mbeki delayed rolling out anti-AIDS plan, it brought rare public reprimand from Mandela; photos (M)

abstract: Chinese industrial production reportedly rises in January by 8.9 percent, slowest pace in three years, after government clamps down on investment (S)

abstract: Most Japanese are unfazed by selection of Western executive, Sir Howard Stringer, as chairman and chief executive of Sony Corp; choice of Sir Howard to turn around Sony is latest in series of humbling events as Japan has watched China emerge as serious challenger to its economic supremacy in Asia (M)

abstract: Article on plight of tsunami survivors in Sri Lanka; Lal Karunamuni is blind and has lost his possessions, but his house still stands; fisherman Muhammad Zain lost his house, his boat and as many as 60 relatives, including his two children and pregnant wife; G H Premaratna's family survived intact, but their home is damaged and fishing boat is gone; two daughters working in garment factory will provide for family, but finding money to rebuild is another matter; map; photos (L)

abstract: Neiman Marcus hires Goldman Sachs to help it explore options with potential buyers; says it will close one of two stores it operates in Houston (M)

abstract: Smart Money Indicator is sending strong sell signal about stock market; gives added weight to what market is doing late in trading day, when wiliest professional investors are believed to make their moves, and less to trends in first hour, when less rational and less astute public has its biggest impact (M)

Deadlines Set in Vioxx Cases
abstract: US District Judge Eldon Fallon, appointed to oversee all federal personal injury lawsuits related to Vioxx painkiller made by Merck, sets March 18 for organizational hearing (S)

abstract: Federal Trade Commission rejects challenge to product placement by advocacy group Commercial Alert that criticizes practice as deceptive; group called on commission in Sept 2003 to require that placements be prominently identified with superimposed message like 'advertising' as they occur during programming; Association of National Advertisers lauds decision (S)

headline: People
abstract: Publicis & Hal Riney names James Consolantis senior vice president and worldwide group creative director on Hewlett-Packard account; Gene DeWitt opens DeWitt Media Options to offer media strategy services to marketers, agencies and media companies; Pile Cos names Pile & Co Consulting managing partner Judy Neer unit president, succeeding Rick Hooker, who remains chief executive; Sony BMG Music Entertainment names Cory Shields senior vice president for communications, succeeding Keith Estabrook (S)

abstract: Indonesia, OPEC's only member in Southeast Asia, might quit organization as falling crude oil production strains its ability to maintain exports; Indonesia's oil output has fallen 5 percent annually in last five years, to less than one million barrels per day, and for four months last year country to had to import supplies (S)

headline: Giving for a Cause, and That Cause Only
abstract: Donors to disaster relief effort in south Asia are often specifying that gifts go exclusively to help those victims (S)

abstract: Cisco Systems will resell data storage equipment from EMC to customers looking to centralize and consolidate storage in their corporate data centes; plans to begin selling EMC's network-attached storage products in second quarter of 2005; graph (S)

abstract: Eighteen employees who recently left flagship New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi are expected to announce agreement to joint Interpublic Group of Companies (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Labor Chief Who Led Crippling Strike Is Arrested
abstract: Carlos Ortega, left, the fiery former head of Venezuela's largest labor confederation, has been arrested in Caracas and charged with treason and inciting rebellion for leading a two-month antigovernment oil strike that devastated the economy two years ago, the government announced. Opposition leaders cast the arrest as a rights violation, but the government said Mr. Ortega had violated the law by leading a strike that was intended to end the presidency of Hugo Chvez. By the time the strike ended in February of 2003, it had virtually stopped crude oil shipments from the country and cost it an estimated $4 billion. Mr. Ortega fled the country and received asylum in Costa Rica. But Costa Rica later canceled his asylum, forcing him to return to Venezuela last summer and go into hiding.   Juan Forero (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Auto Parts Company Acquired
abstract: Mexican auto parts company Nemak will buy German auto parts company Rautenbach; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Interpublic Delays the Release of Some Financial Results
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos, in regulatory statement, says it will delay release of financial data for first quarter 2005; says it may also delay releasing data for second quarter and postpone annual meeting, typically held in May, until audited financial reports are available (M)

headline: Qwest Official Questions Verizon's MCI Bid
abstract: Qwest Communications chief executive Richard C Notebaert tells investors Verizon Communications would and should face serious regulatory hurdles in its bid to acquire MCI; makes remarks as part of effort to persuade Wall Street investors and analysts that MCI would be better off rejecting Verizon as suitor and accepting Qwest as merger partner (M)

abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly opens formal investigation into disclosure by Inamed Corp regarding a type of its silicone-gel breast implants (S)

Rare Infection Is Confirmed in 2nd Patient on M.S. Drug
abstract: Biogen Idec and Elan halt sales and clinical trials of multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri after confirming that second patient who used drug is suspected of having rare but deadly brain infection called progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy; say one patient has died from infection; Tysabri, approved three months ago, was viewed by many doctors as major advance (M)

headline: For Egg-Dyeing Legions, the Possibilities Abound
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column finds kits for Easter egg decorating and dying; drawing (M)

headline: How Electronics Are Penetrating North Korea's Isolation
abstract: Consumer electronics introduce new ways of thinking into North Korea, perhaps corroding steely controls on ideology and information that have kept Kim family in power for almost 60 years; defectors from North Korea say that construction of cellular relay stations last fall along Chinese side of border allows some North Koreans in border towns to use prepaid Chinese cellphones to call relatives and reporters in South Korea; after DVD players swept northern China two years ago, entrepreneurs collected castoff videocassette recorders and peddled them to North Korea; tapes of South Korean soap operas are popular; photo (M)

headline: Negroponte ends touras envoy after 9 months
Sudan Peace Deal Allows Displaced to Go Home at Last
abstract: Sudan celebrates peace agreement to end more than two decades of war between Arab-dominated central government in Khartoum and Christian and animist south; Pres Omar al Bashir makes good-will visit to south, releasing dove at huge rally, as millions of refugees plan to return to homes; photo; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Component Maker Forecasts A Loss
abstract: Zarlink Semiconductor, Canadian manufacturer of electronic components for communications industry, forecasts fourth-quarter loss and says it will cut 150 jobs (S)

headline: Militant questioned in Daniel Pearl murder
Playing Penny-Stock Roulette
abstract: Article, noting recent meeting at Mirage in Las Vegas of group of investors in Audible.com, on risks and rewards involved in playing penny stocks; record number of companies have been delisted since market collapse began in spring 2000; penny stocks come in variety of forms, including those tossed off Nasdaq's primary exchange that are traded on its bulletin board, those kicked off Nasdaq or New York Stock Exchange whose filings are not current and are traded on over-the-counter markets, and those that were never listed on one of major exchanges; University of Florida finance Prof Jay Ritter says recent popularity of penny stocks reflects sheer number of technology casualties since stock bubble burst that have come back from 'near-death experience'; photos; graphs (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Experimental Heart Valve Is Implanted Through a Vein  A team of Michigan cardiologists has implanted an artificial heart valve in a 76-year-old man by feeding the device up through a vein in his left leg, instead of opening his chest.    While the new technique may lead to shorter hospital stays, it might be costly in other respects. Edwards Lifesciences, which makes the valve and the tools to install it, says the products may cost $10,000 to $12,000 per procedure. [Page A23.]    I.B.M. to Buy Ascential Software  I.B.M. is paying $1.1 billion for Ascential Software, whose products help companies combine information from different sources. [C2.]    Iger Wants Disney to Move Faster  Robert A. Iger, left, seemed almost casual in an interview a day after getting the top job at Disney, which he has coveted for years. But it is apparent that he has been thinking for a long time about what he would do if he took over the corporate suite. Mr. Iger said there would be structural changes at Disney so decisions could be made quickly. [C6.]    Duke Power May Build Reactor  Duke Power met with nuclear regulators to discuss seeking permission to build a nuclear power plant, something no one in this country has done in decades. [C3.]    Major electric companies are interested in new nuclear plants, but are not looking to build anything too innovative. [F3.]    Philip Morris Pursues Asian Market  Philip Morris International will offer $5.2 billion to buy PT HM Sampoerna, Indonesia's third-largest cigarette maker. [C7.]    Chain Will Buy Sony Projectors  Landmark Theaters, the art-house chain controlled by Mark Cuban and Todd Wagner, will become the first chain to install new digital projectors developed by Sony. [C19.]    Report Finds Halliburton Overbilling  Excess billing by Halliburton for postwar fuel imports to Iraq totaled more than $108 million, according to a report by Pentagon auditors that was completed last fall. [A12.]    Saatchi & Saatchi Sues Executive  Saatchi & Saatchi filed suit against a senior executive who worked on its General Mills account, on grounds that include breach of fiduciary duty. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]    US Airways and Investor Reach Deal  US Airways said that Republic Airways Holding had agreed to invest $125 million in the airline once it emerges from bankruptcy protection, increasing its chances of survival. [C2.]    Video Frills on a Low-Fare Airline  As Delta cuts back on in-flight services to save money, its low-fare unit, Song, has introduced an in-flight entertainment system that rivals the audio-visual diversions found on the most luxurious international airlines. Song wants to appeal to travelers who are tired of being treated like cargo. [C18.]    Frequent fliers have been using more of their miles. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C18.]    Biotech Rise Helps Stock Market  Stocks rose, lifted by the biotechnology sector after positive news from Genentech. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 30.15 points, to 10,804.51. The S.&P. 500-stock index was up 6.75 points, to 1,206.83, and the Nasdaq composite rose 9.44 points, to 2,051.04. [C11.]    ABC Promotion Did Not Break Rules  Regulators said ABC did not violate indecency rules when it broadcast a controversial promotion for ''Monday Night Football.'' [E2.]

headline: Briefs: 'Innocent spouse'? It's a taxing matter
World Briefings
Global Funds: Timing it right as retirement looms
After Catalog Blunder, Eziba.com Suspends Business
abstract: Eziba.com, online retailer and catalog company known for selling handcrafted items from foreign artists, suspends operations after learning that its fall catalogs were mailed by error to members of its mailing list who showed lowest likelihood to respond; chief executive Bill Miller has resigned; company seeks new funding to hire new chief executive and restart operations, without catalogs (M)

headline: 3 journalistskidnapped in Baghdad
Britain set to cut deal with EDS
In Internet stickups, consumers risk being left on their own
Nordstrom Sales Climb 9.3%; Circuit City Weak Last Month
abstract: Nordstrom says December sales rose more than it had forecast, while Circuit City Stores posts steeper-than-expected decline; sales at Nordstrom stores open at least one year rose 9.3 percent year earlier; Circuit City's comparable sales at stores in US fell 5.8 percent (M)

headline: A Portable Rescue for Cellphones That Give Out at the Wrong Time
abstract: Charge 2 Go can deliver two hours of talk time for cellphone that needs to be recharged; offers chargers for other mobile gadgets; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Tensions High After Shia Leader's Death
abstract: Pakistani security forces are placed on alert after Shia leader Aga Ziauddin is gunned down and killed in attack in Gilgit; Ziauddin's death triggers sectarian riots in area, in which 15 people are killed (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of January 9 article about services that let investors create portfolios resembling mutual funds through tools known as folios or baskets (S)

headline: Today's space mission: Land on Titan
Sole Conviction Is Overturned in Ulster Bombing That Killed 29
abstract: A Dublin appeals court on Friday overturned the conviction of Colm Murphy, the only person jailed in connection with a 1998 car bombing in Northern Ireland that killed 29 people, saying the trial court failed to fully address tainted evidence.    Mr. Murphy, a 52-year-old builder, has been serving a 14-year sentence since 2002, when he was found guilty by the Special Criminal Court, which handles terrorism cases and has no jury. He was convicted on evidence that he lent the bombers cellphones that were used to organize the transportation of 500 pounds of explosives to Omagh, the small town where the bombing occurred. Though the crime was in Ulster, he was tried in Ireland because he lived here, in Dundalk.

headline: Wal-Mart Settles Illegal Immigrant Case
White House Drops Effort to Relax Media Ownership Rules
Fugitive Leader of Chilean Sect Is Captured in Argentina
abstract: Chilean and Argentine police arrest Paul Schafer, leader of Colonia Dignidad, paramilitary religious sect of German emigres established in Chile in early 1960's that allied itself with dictatorship of Gen Augusto Pinochet; Schafer was arrested outside Buenos Aires after manhunt that lasted nearly a decade; Chilean court convicted him last year in absentia of sodomy and pedophilia; photo (M)

headline: Asia Letter : 'Japan Inc.' finds itself in tight spot with China
German opposition to fight for China sanctions
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Factory Prices Fall
abstract: Cost of goods leaving British factories fell 0.4 percent in December; increase in factory prices slowed to 2.9 percent on annualized basis from 3.5 percent in November, adding to arguments for Bank of England to begin cutting interest rates this year as economy slows (S)

headline: Teachingthe (a)(b)(c)'s of investing and finance
A Deal Maker Named by Bush to Lead F.C.C.
abstract: Kevin J Martin, telecommunications lawyer known for his pragmatic and independent streak as Republican member of Federal Communications Commission, is named by Pres Bush to become agency's 26th chairman; Martin will replace Michael K Powell; Martin is attractive candidate for administration because he does not need to be confirmed by Senate; confirmation is required only to become a commissioner; photo (M)

headline: British try 3 soldiers on abuse charges
COMPANY BRIEFS

Terms were not disclosed.    LOCKHEED MARTIN, Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, said it had sold its 42 percent stake in TUSAS Aerospace Industries, a venture that made F-16 fighter jets for Turkey, to the government-owned Turkish Aircraft Industries. Terms were not disclosed.    TECO ENERGY, Tampa, Fla., said that it had agreed to sell Commonwealth Chesapeake Co., owner of the Commonwealth Chesapeake Power Station in Virginia, to an affiliate of Tenaska Power Fund, Omaha, for $89 million.    ICAP, London, an interbank brokerage firm, said it had agreed to buy GovPX, New York, which provides bond and swap market pricing, for $13 million.

abstract: Government-owned State Bank of India reports 20 percent increase in quarterly earnings, to 10.99 billion rupees ($250 million) (S)

headline: Kodak Bets Old Strategy Can Go Digital
abstract: Article explores possible turnaround at Eastman Kodak, which for decades had thrived on classic business model: sell lots of cameras at low prices and gain profits on inks, chemicals and papers used for making prints; success of Kodak's easy-to-use digital cameras is showing signs of making old model work again; Kodak cameras and software are selling well and its self-service kiosks and at-home printing docks and other devices are best sellers; photo (M)

headline: Bush's Next Target: Malpractice Lawyers
abstract: Article on Bush administration's next target: medical malpractice lawyers; Bush, in January speech in Illinois, again called for strict limits on medical malpractice suits, including 'hard cap of $250,000' on what patients could recover for non-economic damages like physical and emotional pain and suffering; health care analysts, while agreeing that medical liability system is deeply flawed, also agree that solution offered by administration and Republican Congress addresses only one aspect of problem; photos; graph (L)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Law Allows Hijacked Planes To Be Shot Down
abstract: Polish Defense Min Jerzy Szmajdzinski announces that legislation allowing his office or head of Polish Air Force to order hijacked airplanes shot down is in effect (S)

headline: Rossignol deal expands Quiksilver's reach
Volkswagen Profit Declined 29% in 2004
abstract: Volkswagen earnings declined in 2004, the third consecutive year they have done so, as sales in China, its second-largest market, fell and aging models and a slumping dollar contributed to a loss in the United States.     Net income declined 29 percent last year, to 716 million euros ($929 million), Volkswagen told the Frankfurt exchange on Monday. Sales last year rose 4.9 percent, to 89 billion euros.

headline: Novartis and Schering delay drug
Iraqi Civilians Fight Back Against Insurgents
abstract: Baghdad carpenter and his young relatives, in rare response by ordinary Iraqis to insurgents who terrorize Iraq, open fire on troop of masked gunmen approaching his shop; three insurgents are killed and rest flee after police arrive; two relatives and bystander are wounded; battle is latest sign that Iraqis may be willing to start standing up against insurgents; has sectarian overtones; Dhia is Shiite and insurgents are largely Sunnis and have aimed dozens of attacks at Shiite figures and rites; conflict has grown sharper in last year, with Shiites dominating Iraq's new police force and army; insurgents continue efforts with attacks in Mosul and Anbar Province (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BAE Plans Acquisitions
abstract: BAE Systems reports pretax loss of 232 million pounds ($443 million) in 2004, compared with net gain of 233 million pounds year earlier; chief executive Mike Turner comments; photo (S)

Maker of Wrinkle Treatment to Buy Breast Implant Leader
abstract: Medicis Pharmaceutical agrees to acquire Inamed, market leader in breast implants for women, in deal valued at $2.8 billion (M)

headline: Where Has All the Prilosec Gone?
abstract: Supplies of heartburn drug Prilosec OTC have fallen far short of demand for year and shortage will continue until at least April; Procter & Gamble and partner AstraZeneca, British drug company that owns rights to Prilosec OTC, say they underestimated demand for drug and are working to increase production and correct shortage; many Wall Street analysts, consumer advocates and academic researchers who study drug costs believe AstraZeneca could easily meet demand for drug if it chose; shortage of Prilosec has been very good for AstraZeneca's bottom line because it has increased sales of Nexium, far more expensive prescription heartburn medicine that AstraZeneca also sells; most doctors view two drugs as essentially identical, yet cost of Nexium is more than five times that of Prilosec OTC, about $4 a pill compared with 70 cents; graph; photo (M)

headline: Israel Agrees to Release 900 Prisoners; Palestinians Want More

abstract: Stuart Elliott column on growing number of ad campaigns that use ensemble casts rather one or two actors; photo (M)

GUITAR CENTER INC., Westlake Village, Calif., which sells guitars and amplifiers, said fourth-quarter profit rose 38 percent, more than the company expected, as musicians spent more in its stores.

headline: A Cruel Race to Loot the Splendor That Was Angkor
abstract: Hidden among stands of bamboo far from the throngs of tourists who clamber over the grand temples of Angkor, a series of bas-reliefs in rose and gray sandstone stand in solitary splendor.    The gods and demons and half-human, half-animal figures revered by the Angkor civilization were carved at Mount Kulen by anonymous artists and, like countless other artworks, disappeared into nature when the empire collapsed 500 years ago.

headline: Editors' Note; About World Business And the Stock Tables
abstract: The World Business section and the daily stock market tables have been combined into the main Business Day section starting this week. The Times is making its daily financial listings more concise by condensing some tables and eliminating secondary ones.     The tables in the Sunday Business section are unchanged. Full information about stocks and mutual funds is online at www.nytimes.com/business.     Comments about the changes may be e-mailed to tables@nytimes.com or telephoned to (212)556-3715.

Dennis Kozlowski, was later accused of stealing, a witness at his fraud trial testified yesterday.
