headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Cable's Regulatory Duties
abstract: Supreme Court to hear arguments in appeal by cable industry and Bush administration of lower court rulings overturning Federal Communications Commission's 2002 ruling that cable companies are not telecommunications services and need not lease their lines to competitors providing Internet service; Consumer Federation has joined Internet service provider Brand X in challenging FCC, holding cable companies, as dominant providers of high-speed Internet access, should be subject to government oversight (M)

abstract: Sound recording has taken big step away from moving parts and into emerging technology of solid-state memory storage; new machines store sounds on flash memory cards like those used in digital cameras; photos (M)

abstract: MetLife will buy Citigroup's life insurance business in deal valued at $11.5 billion; will pay $8.5 billion to $10.5 billion in cash for Citigroup's life and annuity division and nearly all of its international insurance operations; rest of purchase will be in MetLife stock (M)

abstract: Pres Bush will nominate Timothy D Adams to succeed John B Taylor as under secretary for international affairs at Treasury Department; fails to find permanent successor for deputy secretary post at department; will designate Arnold I Havens, currently Treasury Department's general counsel, as acting deputy secretary; photos (M)

Huge insurer admits it misled investors
Deutsche Post challenges regulator
An Effort to Help Free-Software Developers Avoid Suits
abstract: Nonprofit Software Freedom Law Center, backed by $4 million in initial financing from corporate consortium, will provide advice from specialists that is intended to minimize risk that developers and users of free software will be sued; founders say center will focus on helping leaders of open-source software projects organize and manage their work in ways that anticipate and avoid potential legal pitfalls; suit against IBM, seeking $1 billion, is largely responsible for legal concerns surrounding open-source software; SCO Group has accused IBM of contributing code to Linux that SCO legally controlled; IBM has denied accusations (M)

headline: Earnings Rise 27% at Lowe's on Strong Sales of Appliances
abstract: Lowe's Cos says fourth-quarter profit rose 27 percent; net income increased to $508 million from $401 million year earlier; sales rose 18 percent, to $8.55 billion (S)

headline: New Threats to a Five-Year Run
abstract: Many analysts urge caution on emerging markets bond funds, which rose 13 percent in 2004 and averaged annual gain of 16.7 percent for last five years; say stunning performance over last five years was partly attributable to series of crises that hurt sector in preceding period; says major threat emerging markets face today is mounting US current account deficit and threat of spike in US interest rates; photo (M)

headline: War and Politics Threaten Congo's Endangered Rhinos
abstract: Endangered northern white rhinos may be driven to extinction by wars in Congo and in Sudan; there are fewer than dozen still alive in world, in Congo's Garamba National Park, near border with Sudan; conservation groups say immediate culprits are poachers from offshoot of Janjaweed, Arab militia groups pillaging villages in Darfur region, who cross border to kill animals for their valuable tusks and horns; say other greatest threat to rhinos is political, a growing Congolese nationalism that undercuts protection efforts, including last-ditch program to move five of remaining animals to safety in Kenya; photo; map (M)

headline: HealthSouth Loses Mr. Right
abstract: When the HealthSouth Corporation welcomed Lee S. Hillman to its board in September 2003, it noted his experience as a chief executive, a chief financial officer, an audit partner with a global accounting firm and a corporate turnaround expert.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NORTHROP GRUMMAN CORP., Los Angeles, the military contractor, said it had agreed to buy privately held Integic Corp., Chantilly, Va., a software maker. Terms were not disclosed.    LTX CORP., Westwood, Mass., a maker of test equipment for the semiconductor industry, said it would cut 153 jobs, or 25 percent of its work force, after forecasting this week that it would have a loss for the fiscal third quarter.    CARNIVAL CORP., Miami, the cruise company, said that several members of the controlling Arison family will sell up to 17 million shares of the company's common stock over the next two years.    COOLBRANDS INTERNATIONAL INC., Markham, Ontario, a seller of ice cream, said it would stop making some low-calorie products produced by Weight Watchers International Inc., Woodbury, N.Y., an operator of weight- loss programs, to settle a breach-of-contract dispute.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea And Japan Renew Islands Dispute
abstract: South Korean and Japanese dispute over island group located halfway between nations heats up; there are protests in both countries over islands called Tokdo in Korea and Takeshima in Japan (S)

abstract: Israeli Atty Gen Menachem Mazuz orders Sharon government not to carry out policy decision permitting seizure of East Jerusalem property owned by Palestinians living in West Bank; cites Israel's obligations under international law; government last summer quietly approved measure allowing takeover of land in East Jerusalem under 'absentee owner' rule; critics, including Mazuz, see link to construction of security barrier, which prevents some Palestinians from getting to their property on Israeli side; decision was initiated by Min Natan Sharansky, who Mazuz says exceeded his authority (M)

headline: Sharon wants militant groups 'destroyed'
India Adopts Patent Law Covering Pharmaceuticals
abstract: Makers of generic drugs in India face uncertain new playing field after approval of bill that would bring India into line with international patent law--over time; bill, which requires only signature of Pres A P J Abdul Kalam, will set unspecified 'reasonable royalty' on drugs that are patented; what precisely that will cost India's consumers and companies remains to be seen; companies will need for first time to patent their drugs in India to receive royalty (M)

headline: Schrder urges firms to reinvest at home
No Remorse. No Regrets. No Worries For Martha.
abstract: Article on next steps that may be taken by Martha Stewart and company she founded, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, as she ends 4 1/2-month prison sentence on March 7; crucial question is whether company and Stewart really learned anything from last three years, when advertisers pulled out, television stations pulled programs from airwaves and merchandisers lost business; photos; graph (L)

headline: I.B.M. to Give Free Access to 500 Patents
abstract: IBM plans to announce it is making 500 of its software patents freely available to anyone working on open-source projects, like popular Linux operating system, on which programmers collaborate and share code; analysts say new model for IBM represents shift away from traditional corporate approach to protecting copyrights, trademark and trade-secret laws; estimate IBM collected $1 billion or more last year from licensing its inventions; IBM senior vice president John Kelly calls patent contribution beginning of new era in how IBM will manage intellectual property; company was granted 3,248 patents in 2004, far more than any other company (M)

headline: Persuading Retiring Baby Boomers to Volunteer
abstract: Center for Health Communication at Harvard School of Public Health begins effort that includes advertising, events, publication of book and public relations campaign, all aimed at volunteerism; Metropolitan Life Foundation donated about $1.7 million to pay for initial states of effort, aimed at baby boomers, those 75 million to 77 million Americans born from 1946 to 1964; John Glenn, former astronaut and senator, is among notable people enlisted to get future retirees to volunteer in their communities; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HARTZ MOUNTAIN CORP., Secaucus, N.J., a manufacturer of pet products, said it will purchase Harper Pet Products Inc., Bedford Park, Ill., a supplier of pet chews. Terms were not disclosed.    ROGERS CORP., Rogers, Conn., a manufacturer of parts used in computers and communications equipment, said that the chief financial officer and treasurer, James Rutledge, had quit for personal reasons.    PEPSIAMERICAS INC., Rolling Meadows, Ill., the Pepsi-Cola bottler, said that its chief financial officer, Mike Durkin, will assume the position of executive vice president of United States operations on March 21.

headline: SEC gives wide latitude on options
World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: A Tut Mystery Is Solved
abstract: Dr Zahi Hawass, Egypt's chief archaeologist, announces that extensive examination of more than 1,700 detailed images of Tutankhamen mummy did not identify cause of death and ruled out blow to head; pharaoh died more than 3,000 years ago at age 17 (S)

headline: Newcomers to Energy Investments Could Make This Year's Price Swings Wild
abstract: THE jarring swings in oil prices that gave investors and traders whiplash in 2004 are not preventing new investors from rushing into oil and other energy-related commodities this year.    These investors are attracted by the promise of better returns than those offered by bonds and equities, bankers and traders say. Ultimately, the rising number of speculators could lead to even more price volatility in 2005 as they push the highs higher and the lows lower.

headline: White House Letter:A Bush messenger to the Muslim world
Europa: From America, Europe seems a long way off

abstract: Government Accountability Office acquistion and sourcing management group member Paul Francis, testifying before Senate Armed Services Committee, says Future Combat Systems, costliest Army program ever conceived, faces hugh technological hurdles and potential for multibillion-dollar cost overruns; says initial phase of program, which aims to rebuild Army as networked force, will cost at least $108 billion and cover about one third of forces that Army wants to equip (M)

headline: Bush defends actions in Schiavo case
S.E.C. Rebuffs Investors on Board Votes
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission tells Verizon, Qwest and Halliburton that they can rebuff requests by institutional shareholders seeking opportunities to nominate small number of rivals for board seats; decision by staff of commission is seen as unambiguoous sign that earlier proposal to open proxies, or votes, to greater shareholder participation is dead; proposal has come under criticism from chief executives at many big companies, who have lobbied Bush administration and Congress to press commission to abandon it; SEC spokesman says chairman William H Donaldson is committed to changing proxy rules even though he no longer supports proposal put forward by commission in 2003; decision is sharply attacked by SEC commissioner Harvey J Goldschmid, a Democrat, who had been among strongest proponents of opening proxies; photo (M)

abstract: LeapFrog will introduce talking Fly pen that has tiny camera in its tip that scans what is written on special paper and translates it into individual letters; speech technology combines letters into lexicon of 70,000 works that pen can speak; photo (S)

CONTINENTAL, the German tire maker, plans to sell a tire factory in Bryan, Ohio, amid a reorganization of United States operations, according to a union that represents workers at the plant.

headline: Durable Goods Orders Up 0.6 Percent in December

Insurer Admits Bad Accounting in Several Deals
abstract: American International Group acknowledges that its accounting for number of transactions, including deal with unit of Warren E Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, was improper, and that impact of accounting errors would lower its book value by $1.7 billion; this is AIG's fullest disclosure since questions about its dealings first emerged last year; federal and state regulators are digging through dozens of transactions to determine how extensively it dressed up its financial condition; investigators are focusing on 2000 transaction between AIG and General Re unit of Berkshire Hathaway that artificially inflated AIG's reserves by $500 million; latest disclosure may not bode well for Maurice R Greenberg, who was forced to step down as chief executive after regulators uncovered evidence that he initiated transaction with General Re; his liability will reportedly rest on what he understood about transfer of risk in General Re deal and whether he believed transaction to be questionable; company also cites flawed accounting of its business with reinsurers that it controls in Bermuda and Barbados (M)

abstract: RealNetworks deputy general counsel David Stewart contends that Microsoft, ordered year ago by European Commission to sell second version of Windows in Europe that has its music and video-playing program, Media Player, stripped out, is not ready to comply with ruling; RealNetworks, which makes rival software, has most to gain from enforcement of order; commission has yet to decide whether Microsoft's proposal for introducing unbundled version of Windows meets its requirements (M)

headline: Abbas Tells Palestinian Forces to Block Attacks on Israel
abstract: Palestinian Authority's new president Mahmoud Abbas orders his security forces to try to prevent attacks against Israel; move could put him on collision course with armed Palestinian factions; he will not give details about how security forces might act against militant groups, and there is no sign that any action has started; Abbas has publicly opposed attacks on Israel as counterproductive, but genuine crackdown on Hamas, Islamic Jihad and other groups that have sworn to continue their attacks could put him in full-fledged confrontation with them; solid majority of Palestinians support suicide bombings and shootings to oppose Israeli occupation in West Bank and Gaza and to fight for statehood, although there are signs that support has declined as violence grinds on; photo (M)

WorldCom settlement makes directors fret

headline: If I Only Had a Hedge Fund
abstract: Torrid growth of hedge funds and their huge impact on securities markets prompt some observers to fear a bubble or at least the consequences of such growth, built as it is on leverage that banks provide managers to double or triple their investment bets; adding to concerns are mystery surrounding what kind of financial products are being traded by funds and how they value them, as well as proliferation of funds of funds, pools of hedge funds that are meant to lower risk but that also come with another layer of fees on top of what standard hedge funds charge; even some hedge fund experts who play down notion of investment bubble acknowledge possibility of compensation bubble, since fund managers do not receive fixed percentage of funds they manage, but rather 1 percent of assets under management and 20 percent of profits; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Hate acts on steep increasein France
How a 15-Year-Old Got the Flying Habit in the Old Days
abstract: I started flying young, if accidentally, in 1947 on propeller planes such as Dakotas and Super Constellations. The summer I was 15, I traveled with my mother by boat and train to Montreux, Switzerland, where she was born, for vacation. At summer's end she returned to the United States and I stayed on to attend a French language and literature class for foreign students at the local high school.    In December, when the semester ended, I took a train to Paris and the next day to Le Havre where I was supposed to take a boat. The French labor unions went on strike and since the transportation workers were involved, the boat didn't leave. On the third day, the steamship line transported all passengers back to Paris. There were reports of tanks in the streets and rumors of a Communist takeover.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Trials Set For 3 Sept. 11 Suspects
abstract: Spanish National Court announces plans to prosecute Driss Chebli, Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas and Ghasoub Al Abrash Ghalyoun for involvement in September 11 attacks on United States; prosecutors are calling for sentence of 25 years for each person killed in attacks; investigation of men, who were arrested between 2001 and 2003, was led by Judge Baltasar Garzon (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Charged In American's Death
abstract: Russian officials charge Chechen Muslim Ibragimov in last year's shooting death of Paul Klebnikov, American journalist and editor of Russian edition of Forbes; three other Chechens have been arrested for Klebnikov's murder, but only one remains in custody (S)

headline: Iraqis Exercised Right to Vote and Paid With Their Lives
Fed Lifts Rate 7th Time in Year and Warns of Greater Inflation
abstract: Federal Reserve raises federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks to 2.75 percent from 2.5 percent; restates its intention to keep raising rates at 'measured' pace in months ahead; says it sees rising inflationary pressures, setting off alarms in stock and bond markets that it might drive up interest rates faster than expected; implies it might have to take tougher monetary policy action to keep risks to inflation and growth roughly equal; Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq both drop by 0.9 percent and yield on 10-year Treasury bonds jump to 4.64 percent from 4.47; Commerce Department reports Producer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in Feb, compared with Jan gain of 0.8 percent; federal funds target rate graph; photo (M)

headline: Karzai visits India to bolster economic ties
U.S. pressing Arab states on Iran's nuclear threat
UN chief urges early spending on disasters
Some Economists Say the President of Harvard Talks Just Like Them
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on controversy surrounding Harvard University president Lawrence H Summers' leadership; immediate source of dispute is speech Summers gave Jan 14 at National Bureau of Economic Research conference on women in science and engineering; Summers in speech laid out three hypotheses for why women might be underrepresented in academic science and engineering, particularly at highest levels; photo (M)

headline: Stocks: Mergers and Mideast calm cheer Wall Street
Auschwitz victim's diaries rediscovered
Gandhi's 'salt march' to sea re-enacted
At Least 16 Iraqis Are Killed in Car Bomb Attacks as Violence Surges
abstract: At least 16 Iraqis were killed and dozens were wounded Friday in separate car bomb attacks outside a mosque in Baghdad and near a wedding party south of the capital, according to Iraqi government and hospital officials.    With just over a week before national elections on Jan. 30, the wave of violence that American and Iraqi officials had predicted appeared to be gaining momentum as insurgents continued their campaign of car bomb attacks, kidnappings and beheadings.

headline: Gucci Hires Rival From Dior as Chief of Saint Laurent
abstract: Gucci Group appoints Valerie Hermann from rival Christian Dior house as chief of its loss-making brand Yves Saint Laurent; position has been vacant since October, when Mark Lee was promoted from post to head flagship Gucci brand (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Kodak Introduces Wireless Camera
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, which is shifting to digital photography as film sales decline, introduced yesterday what it said was the first digital camera able to send high-resolution images without connecting to a computer. The EasyShare-One camera, which allows users to share pictures online or by e-mail, will be featured at the Consumer Electronics Show, opening today in Las Vegas, said Kodak, based in Rochester. The camera will go on sale in June for $599. It has a 4-megapixel sensor and a 3x optical zoom lens -- the most popular configuration among consumers, according to Kodak. It also has 256 megabytes of internal memory, compared with 16 to 32 megabytes in current EasyShare models. Users can transmit images through a proprietary wireless card that connects through a hub, wireless router or cellphone.

headline: The talk of Davos: Dollar and deficit
Horse Trading for a Venture in China
abstract: Goldman Sachs has won government approval to set up its own joint-venture investment bank in Beijing in exchange for making $67 million 'donation' to cover investor losses at failed Chinese brokerage firm Hainan Securities; Goldman also agrees to lend $100 million to Chinese banker named Fang Feng Lei; deal offers rare glimpse into maneuvers taht many foreign companies undertake to get leg up in rough-and-tumble race to establish business in China; joint venture was years in making, involving frequent talks with high Communist Party officials; photo (M)

headline: Britain Faulted Over McDonald's Libel Case
abstract: European Court of Human Rights says anti-McDonald's activists Helen Steel and David Morris, convicted of libel in Britain for criticizing company's animal rights practices, its environmental policies and nutritional value of its food, did not get fair trial and should be compensated by British government; defendants were ordered in 1997 to pay 60,000 pounds to McDonald's after it sued them for distributing pamphlets titled What's Wrong With McDonald's in front of its London outlets; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Unpunished Killings Rise
abstract: Amnesty International reports that unlawful killings by both government and Maoist rebel forces are on rise in Nepal; more than 10,000 people have been killed during nine-year-old conflict (S)

abstract: Spiegel, bankrupt mail-order marketing company, plans to give ownership of company and its Eddie Bauer unit to creditors; Otto GmbH will no longer own company (S)

headline: 9 Executives Face Charges of Sales Fraud
abstract: Nine current and former sales executives from assortment of food companies are charged with participating in scheme that created huge accounting fraud at US Foodservice, unit of Royal Ahold, which has been under investigation in US and Netherlands for last two years; all executives are accused of approving documents that claimed US Foodservice was owed millions of dollars more in promotional allowances than was actually case; letters are issued by former US Foodservice chief marketing officer Mark P Kaiser; Kaiser is awaiting trial on conspiracy and fraud charges, along with former chief financial officer Michael J Resnick; executives Timothy J Lee and William F Carter pleaded guilty to similar charges last summer; all of the executives have been named in civil case brought by Securities and Exchange Commission in case involving John Nettle, former vice president of General Mills, letter prepared by US Foodservice's auditor stated that General Mills owed company $13.44 million at end of 2001; Mark Bailin, who was president of Rymer International Seafood, and Peter Marion, president of Maritime Seafood Processors, are accused of buying US Foodservice stock in 2000, ahead of company's announcement that it was being acquired by Royal Ahold (M)

headline: Times Co. Plan for Boston Paper Faces Inquiry
abstract: Justice Department begins antitrust probe into planned investment by The New York Times Co in Boston Metro, free daily newspaper owned by unit of Metro International; Times Co spokeswoman Catherine Mathis says investment in Metro Boston would increase competition in Boston area (M)

headline: Showdown in Britain over antiterror laws
For Value Funds, a Tough Act to Follow
abstract: Value funds overperform growth funds in 2004, although they lag in fourth quarter; some fund managers are anxious about finding stocks that will allow them to carry through that performance into 2005; photo (M)

headline: Finding a Sea Less Crowded
abstract: AMERICAN companies spend too much time competing in narrowly defined industries and, as a result, face relentless downward pressure on profits, say W.Chan Kim and Rene Mauborgne, professors at Insead, the French business school, and authors of a new book, ''Blue Ocean Strategy: How to Create Uncontested Market Space and Make the Competition Irrelevant'' (Harvard Business School Press). Here are excerpts from a conversation:    Q. Has globalization helped create the brutal competition that you describe as a red, or money-losing, ocean?    Kim: Absolutely. There are three tiers in the international production system. One is the United States and other industrialized nations. The second is emerging countries like South Korea. The third is China and other countries with such low wages and cost structures.

abstract: Cisco Systems acquires Airespace for about $450 million in stock to bolster sales of wireless-network gear (S)

On EBay, E-Mail Phishers Find a Well-Stocked Pond
abstract: eBay online auction site reportedly is one of companies most frequently targeted by phishing, form of online fraud in which victims disclose account passwords and other data in response to e-mails that seem to come from legitimate business; company's domination of online auction business and its heavy dependence on e-mail make its users particularly vulnerable to this kind of scam; proliferation of problem means legitimate e-mail that powers eBay deals are increasingly being eliminated by jun

abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission gives companies wide latitude in calculating expense to be recorded for stock options issued to executives and other employees; move may enable companies to keep reported costs low as they adapt to accounting rule that requires options costs to be treated like any other expense; SEC also makes it clear that it expects companies to disclose details about what they did, to make it possible for investors to evaluate accounting (M)

abstract: Sara Lee Corp names new chief executive, Brenda C Barnes, and announces plans to divest four businesses that together account for 40 percent of company's revenue; C Steven McMillan, who also announces he is stepping down as chief executive, says Sara Lee will spin off its $4.5 billion apparel business, its $1.1 billion European packaged meat division, American coffee brands and direct-sales unit for cosmetics and household products; McMillan will remain as chairman through October (M)

headline: 60 Companies Plan to Sponsor Health Coverage for Uninsured
abstract: Sixty large employers, including General Motors, IBM, McDonald's and Sears, Roebuck, are joining together to sponsor array of low-cost health insurance options intended to cover part-time and temporary workers, contractors, consultants and early retirees, who typically are not eligible for employer health plans; will not subsidize coverage, but their participation creates pool of potential participants sufficiently large to justify lower insurance rates than individuals would have to pay on their own; UnitedHealth Group will offer four low-cost options in all 50 states; UnitedHealth and Humana will offer major medical policies in states where they have been approved by regulators; Cigna will offer program's major medical option in Arizona; chart (M)

headline: In a first, France plans an anti-terror Web site
The more choice the better: Yes, no or maybe?
Mastering the Complexity And Opportunity of the 1040
abstract: IF you find the tax laws confusing, you are not alone. The national taxpayer advocate, Nina E. Olson, in a report to Congress last month, cited the tangled Internal Revenue Code as the most serious problem facing both taxpayers and the I.R.S.     ''Without a doubt, the largest source of compliance burdens for taxpayers and the I.R.S. alike is the overwhelming complexity of the tax code,'' she said, ''and without a doubt, the only meaningful way to reduce these compliance burdens is to simplify the tax code enormously.''

abstract: Pope John Paul II leaves hospital in splash of showmanship meant to allay worst fears about his health; he travels to Vatican in his popemobile, waving to wellwishers; for first time in his 26-year-old papacy he does not preside over Ash Wednesday ceremonies; he has repeatedly said he will not step down; photo (M)

headline: Credit Card Issuers Adjust to Open Field
abstract: American Express and Discover Financial Services, part of Morgan Stanley, are taking diverging courses in credit card industry now that Supreme Court gave them permission to work with more than 14,000 financial institutions that issue credit cards through Visa and MasterCard; American Express is steering directly for prosperous clientele it has long courted, and Discover is moving even further into mainstream with new products and services aimed at Middle America (M)

abstract: Credit rating of Gap is raised to investment grade by Standard & Poor's Ratings Services (S)

abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer says that its 2004 profit will fall short of analysts' estimates because of post-Christmas clearance sales; graph (S)

headline: The Latest Initiative in Congress: Blogging
abstract: Members of Congress are experimenting with blogs as creative way to reach voters; at least four members have taken up task on continuing basis, while others have used temporary blogs to document trips; Congressional bloggers praise power, popularity and potential of blogging and cite blog as among most frequently visited features of their Congressional Web sites; photos (M)

headline: Canadian Sikhs Are Cleared in 1985 Air India Bombing
abstract: Judge in Vancouver, British Columbia, acquits two Indian-born Canadian Sikhs charged in explosion of Air India plane en route from Toronto to New Delhi that killed 329 people 20 years ago; calls it 'diabolical act of terrorism' but says government did not make conclusive case, stinging rebuke to Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canada's intelligence agency, which conducted 20-year, $80 million investigation; nearly all physical evidence was lost 7,000 feet below ocean; most credible potential witnesses were either murdered, died of natural causes or were apparently intimidated from testifying; Canadian investigators quickly concluded bombings were work of Sikh separatists, who openly worked for their cause within large Sikh population in Vancouver; two defendants are Ripudaman Singh Malik, millionaire with influence among Canadian Sikhs, and Ajaib Singh Bagri, millworker and Sikh priest; photos (M)

headline: Britain lands in middle of U.S.-EU China spat
Unilever plans major reorganization
Building Autos With the Same DNA
abstract: Auto companies are using more of same manufacturing components for wide range of vehicles from different brands as industry has increasingly consolidated; strategy has become riskier in recent years as companies like General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler acquire or form alliances with European and Asian manufacturers; acquisitions create challenges in maintaining identity of distinctive Swedish carmaker like Saab, which GM acquired in 2000, whose vehicles increasingly are being jointly developed with American and Japanese brands; photos (M)

headline: Founder of Peru's AeroContinente Is Accused of Building Airline on Drugs
abstract: Trial of Fernando Zevallos, founder of Peru's largest airline AeroContinente, is in seventh month and is expected to end soon; American and Peruvian authorities charge that airline, which is now defunct, was built with money from drug traffickers; case revolves around 1995 seizure of more than three tons of cocaine in northern Peru, which authorities say implicates Zevallos and others; details of case discussed; officials in Washington say they are preparing additional case against Zevallos that could lead to indictment extradition request; photo (M)

headline: Sudan and Southern Rebels Sign Deal Ending Civil War
abstract: Islamic government of Sudan signs peace agreement with Christian rebel group in south that calls for end to one of Africa's fiercest and longest-running civil wars; Sudanese refugees--many of whom have known nothing but war in their homeland--dance with glee as Sudan Vice Pres Ali Osman Taha and rebel leadeer John Garang initial agreement in Nairobi, Kenya; celebration is tempered by fact that war continues in other parts of Sudan; agreement does not cover western Darfur region, where clashes involve different rebels; photos (M)

headline: Blast outside Tel Aviv nightclub kills at least 4
Swiss airline to cut jobs and shrink fleet
Let's Get Digital
abstract: Nielsen SoundScan reports sales of digital singles topped 5 million for week ended December 26, 2004, and hit 6.7 million the following week; photo; graph (S)

headline: Divide between rich and poor remains largest obstacle in WTO's Doha Round: Straining to bridge the free-trade gap
Japan Says Intel Violated Antimonopoly Law
abstract: Fair Trade Commission in Japan rules that Intel Corp violated country's antimonopoly law in way it sold semiconductors and orders company to step some of its sales practices; Intel takes issue with finding and says it is considering how to respond; commission says Intel used unfair business practices to persuade five Japanese personal computer makers, including Sony and Toshiba, to stop or limit their purchases of microprocessors from Intel rivals Advanced Micro Devices and Transmeta Corp (M)

headline: In Ireland, signs of renewed vigor

GENERAL ELECTRIC TO SELL SHARES IN INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: General Electric Co plans to sell as much as $2.84 billion of shares in its life and mortgage insurance unit, Genworth Financial; transactions will cut GE's ownership of Genworth to about 52 percent (S)

abstract: Leaders of Germany's conservative opposition party claim narrow victory in closely watched regional election in northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, which has long been controlled by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's Social Democrats; conservatives fall one vote short of 35 seats needed to control state legislature; map (M)

headline: PEPSICO TO ADD LIME COLAS IN RESPONSE TO COKE MOVES
abstract: PepsiCo, following move by Coca-Cola, plans to introduce lime versions of Pespi and Diet Pepsi in late April or May (S)

headline: Judge Given Option of Altering Sentence of Martha Stewart
abstract: Federal Court of Appeals grants request from Martha Stewart to give trial Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum option, offered to other defendants sentenced before January 1, to change her sentence (M)

headline: Jockeying for Position to Buy the London Exchange
abstract: Deutsche Borse makes public details of its 1.3 billion pound ($2.4 billion) preliminary bid for London Stock Exchange and promises all-cash deal will cut costs for all London Stock Exchange users by 10 percent; London Exchange, which in December rejected bid as too low, promptly reiterates is position; Euronext, pan-European exchange, says it will file its own bid soon; deal may decide future of exchange's chief Clara Furse; photos (M)

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Defends Role in Fraud Case
abstract: Former FBI agent Jeffrey A Royer testifies that controversial stock adviser Anthony Elgindy was 'very valuable source'; Royer and Elgindy are accused of securities fraud, market manipulation and extortion in conspiracy trial that is in its eighth week; Royer, in cross-examination, admits that between March 2000 and May 2002, gave Elgindy information about confidential government investigations; says he did so for law enforcement purposes and never expected anything but information in return; government contends Royer supplied Elgindy with advanced news of criminal probes into several small companies, which Elgindy published on two Web sites he operated, in short-selling scheme that allowed both men to profit; photo (M)

headline: Laser Pointers Draw Attention (to Themselves)
abstract: How It Works column on new kind of laser pointers that emit green light, which appears brighter than red ones; green laser pointers cost more because they are actually two lasers in one; illustrations (M)

headline: How Long Can G.M. Tread Water?
abstract: General Motors Corp is broadly struggling and facing humbling possibility that it will be displaced by Toyota at top of auto industry within few years; GM, which controlled nearly half American market as recently as late 1970's, held about one-quarter in February; company said last week it will produce 300,000 fewer cars and trucks in North America in first half of year, 10 percent drop from year ago; chief executive Rick Wagoner saye he believes company can weather the strom; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Parliament Rejects Basque Plan
abstract: Spanish Parliament votes, 313 to 29, against Basque plan for autonomous relationship with Spanish central government; Basque Pres Juan Jose Ibarretxe holds he will submit proposal to referendum in region; Prime Min Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero urges Basque government to meet and discuss alternative plans (S)

headline: Quarterly Income Rises at Motorola
abstract: Motorola, the world's second-biggest mobile phone maker after Nokia, said yesterday that fourth-quarter net income jumped 34 percent as demand surged for higher-price handsets, like the $499 Razr model.    Net income rose to $654 million, or 27 cents a share, from $489 million, or 20 cents, in the quarter a year earlier, Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., said. Sales rose 27 percent, to $8.84 billion.

headline: The Crystal Ball's Verdict on the Market's Future: Hazy
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column assesses stock market barometers, which indicate that market is neither particularly vulnerable to big fall nor well positioned for rebound; graph (M)

headline: Stewart sheds her prison garb
U.N. Oil-for-Food Chief Faces Fresh Charges
abstract: The Senate subcommittee on investigations says it has documents showing that the former head of the United Nations oil-for-food aid program may have made as much as $1.2 million personally from illegal oil shipments by Iraq.    The officials said in a briefing on Capitol Hill late Monday that they based the conclusion on documents written by the Iraqi Oil Ministry under Saddam Hussein and on reports prepared for the new oil minister after Mr. Hussein was overthrown in 2003. A subcommittee hearing about the oil-for-food program is to take place on Tuesday.

headline: Telecom Executive Accused of Evading $210 Million in Taxes
Chief to Step Down At Carmichael Lynch
abstract: Leland T Lynch to retire as Carmichael Lynch chief executive and managing partner (S)

headline: Improving Pope May Leave Hospital Before Holy Week
abstract: Vatican says Pope John Paul II continues to recover well and could be discharged from hospital before Easter week, although doctors advise him to speak sparingly in aftermath of tracheotomy (S)

headline: French Reporter Being Held Hostage Is Shown on Videotape
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Grasso Plans to Sue McCall Over Approval of His Pay  Lawyers for Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said they would sue H. Carl McCall, who headed the exchange's compensation committee when it approved Mr. Grasso's 2003 contract.    The lawyers argue that Mr. McCall should be ''held accountable'' for his role in overseeing the approval of Mr. Grasso's final retirement package. [Page C9.]    OPEC May Lift Production Quota  The president of OPEC said the group was considering an increase in its production ceiling to help bring down oil prices. [C3.]    Liberty Media to Create Spin-Off  Liberty Media, headed by John C. Malone, plans to spin off two of its units into a separate public company. Liberty will spin off Ascent and its 50 percent stake in the parent company of the Discovery Channel and other networks. Mr. Malone ended speculation that he joined the board of Cablevision because Liberty wanted to acquire its networks. [C7.]    Pinochet's Web of Bank Accounts  A Senate committee report suggests that ties between the former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet and American banks were deeper than previously disclosed. [C4.]    Data Brokers Face Questioning  The chief executives of two data brokers sought to explain their previously obscure industry to a House subcommittee. [C3.]    Rosneft Sues Yukos for $11 Billion  The Russian energy company Rosneft has sued Yukos, seeking $11 billion for what it said were questionable oil pricing practices. [C3.]    Pepsi One Goes Television-Free  To reintroduce its Pepsi One drink, Pepsi-Cola is using offbeat alternatives to TV commercials. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]    Microsoft Develops Web Ad System  Microsoft is unveiling some features of a new advertising system on its MSN search engine, part of its effort to match the success of Google in the paid Internet search business. Steven A. Ballmer, left, the chief executive, said he believed that having an independent advertising system was strategically vital. [C16.]    Chip Stocks Weigh on the Market  Semiconductor stocks and A.I.G. led the market lower. The Dow Jones average fell 59.41 points, to 10,745.10, and the Nasdaq composite fell 16.06 points, to 2,034.98. [C10.]    Sports Magazines Try Spanish  Two big sports magazines, Sports Illustrated and ESPN The Magazine, are going after Hispanic sports fans with new publications. [C7.]

World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Blast In Dagestan Kills 3
abstract: Car bombing outside Kizlyar government building in Dagestan, Russia, kills three people and injures five others; Dagestan's Deputy Prime Min Amuchi Amutinov is thought to have been target of bombing (S)

abstract: Talks by Apax Partners and Texas Pacific Group and Telecom Italia, majority owner of TIM Hellas, again fail to produce purchase agreement, opening door for takeover fight; analysts estimate that 80 percent stake in TIM Hellas may be worth as much as 2 billion euros ($2.7 billion) (M)

Briefs: WTO panel to rule on dispute between Canada and U.S.

abstract: United Nations officials report that abush, killing and mutilation of nine United Nations peacekeepers from Bangladesh last week are not typical of local militias; investigation is in progress (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar gains against euro as buyers believe US economic recovery will remain on track; dollar is $1.3368 to euro compared with $1.3459 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Spruced Up, Qwest Looks at Its Options
abstract: Qwest Communications International's attempt to take over MCI Inc speaks to remarkable turnaround at company; accounting scandal that erupted in 2002 led to management shake-up and drove company to brink of bankruptcy; Qwest has to gauge whether it can grow on its own or whether it must fix itself up to be sold; company reports fourth-quarter results that exceed analysts' forecasts; lost $139 million, down from $407 million year earlier; sales dipped 1.7 percent, to $3.4 billion, smallest quarterly decline in two years; revenue slid 3.4 percent, to $13.8 billion, for all of 2004; chief executive Richard Notebaert comments; photo (M)

headline: Entr'acte:Berlin and its culture, 15 years after the wall
ECB fight pits small against big
FORD SEEKS TO INCREASE LINCOLN-MERCURY SALES
abstract: The Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company is seeking to increase sales in the United States 10 percent this year and end five years of annual declines for its brands, the unit's president, Darryl B. Hazel, said yesterday in an interview at the Chicago Auto Show. Lincoln-Mercury sales fell 8 percent last year to 332,550 vehicles, and have dropped 55 percent since 1999. The automaker's Volvo brand, which is based in Sweden, outsold Lincoln in the United States last year.

headline: Bomb in Christian Area of Beirut Wounds 5
abstract: Car bomb explodes in predominantly Christian Sid al Bushriya neighborhood in eastern Beirut on eve of Easter, wounding at least five people and destroying two factories in third attack on a Christian neighborhood in week; Lebanon's Christians are overwhelmingly opposed to Syria's military occupation, and many Lebanese drawn to site of bombing say they suspect Syrian involvement; photo (M)

headline: Three Romanian journalists missing in Iraq
Gold Prices? The Dollar Offers Clues
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on watching price of euro against dollar in order to predict price of gold; notes that when euro has jumped in value, price of gold, now at $426.90 an ounce, has generally also climbed; graphs (M)

headline: RadioShack Names Finance Chief
Kidnappers free bishop after one day
Israelis and Palestinians Look to a Quiet Gaza and a Cease-Fire
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian officials welcome period of quiet in Gaza and speak hopefully of cease-fire that would last at least one month; Palestinian militant groups have pledged to suspend attacks on Israelis while talks continue with Pres Mahmoud Abbas about long-term cease-fire and power-sharing role until legislative elections in July; Abbas is optimistic about progress and of reaching agreement with militants about role in government (M)

headline: Report Criticizes Annan but Finds No Evidence of Corruption
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Profit Surges
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada reports first-quarter profit of 1.04 billion Canadian dollars ($839 million), 31 percent increase from year earlier; revenue rose 11 percent, to 4.65 billion Canadian dollars (S)

headline: World Briefings
Ever more security risks for PC users (and drivers)
The Last-Minute Scramble to Help Iraqis Abroad Vote
abstract: As many as one million Iraqis living abroad are expected to turn out to vote, touching off scramble to inform and register them; registration to begin at 75 centers in 36 cities in 14 countries, including US; outside voting will begin two days before election on Jan 30, to allow flexibility for traveling to polling centers; Peter Erben of International Organization for Migration, directs effort; photo (M)

headline: Worker Tied to Ex-Chief at Boeing Is Identified
abstract: Female executive whose romantic relationship with Boeing chief executive Harry C Stonecipher led to his ouster is identified as Debra Peabody, employee in Washington who has been at Boeing for more than 20 years; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Grocery Chain Is Sold
abstract: Royal Ahold agrees to sell its G Barbosa supermarket chain in Brazil to unit of US investment company Acon Investments, but it does not disclose terms of deal (S)

headline: Manila arrests 4 terror suspects
Fatah accepts cabinet list including Abbas loyalists
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: American Home Mortgage Investment Corp., Melville, N.Y., which originates residential loans, said it had agreed to buy 23 Irwin Financial Corp. mortgage-loan branches. Irwin is a diversified financial company based in Columbus, Ind. Terms were not disclosed.    Mimix Broadband, Inc., Houston, and Celeritek Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., the maker of circuits for personal communications systems, said that they had entered into an agreement for Mimix to acquire substantially all of Celeritek's assets relating to its gallium arsenide technology.    Hollinger International Inc., Chicago, publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, said it had named Gregory Stoklosa to succeed Peter Lane as vice president and chief financial officer. Mr. Stoklosa was chief financial officer of R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co., a commercial printing company.

headline: Free Speech, or Secrets From Apple?
abstract: Series of legal actions filed by Apple Computer over last month highlights difficulties of defining who is journalist in age of Web log; company obtained court order allowing it to issue subpoenas to AppleInsider.com, PowerPage.org and Thinksecret.com as part of lawsuit filed on Dec 13; three Web sites published or linked to information on what they said was future Apple audio device that was code-named 'Asteroid'; subponenas are aimed at getting operators of those site to disclose sources of information that was reportedly leaked; attorney representing AppleInsider and PowerPage asserted that bloggers ought to be extended same protections as mainstream journalists, who have traditionally been given some latitude by courts in protecting identities of confidential sources (M)

headline: Germans Arrest 2 on Suspicion of Planning Suicide Blast
abstract: Police in Mainz, Germany, arrest two men suspected of being members of Al Qaeda, saying they were planning suicide bombings; say suspects had also tried to buy small amount of enriched uranium from contact in Luxembourg; full names of suspects are not released in keeping with German law; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Falls
abstract: Industrial production in Brazil fell 0.4 percent in November from October, suggesting that economic growth slowed in last quarter of 2004 after series of interest rate increases; graph (S)

headline: Nepalese feeling isolated under state of emergency
Out of the Shower and Off Key? Perfect Pitch May Be in a Box
abstract: Singing Coach software from Carry-A-Tune Technologies is 20-lesson computer tutorial designed to improve singer's pitch and rhythm; photo (M)

headline: Tsunami Group Will Expand Its Network
abstract: Officials in charge of the existing international tsunami warning system, which covers only the Pacific Ocean, have taken an initial step to broaden the network to the Indian Ocean and other possible trouble spots, agreeing to distribute their bulletins on earthquakes and possible waves ''to anyone who wants to receive the messages.''     Until now the bulletins had gone only to about 300 agencies and individual scientists tracking conditions mainly in the Pacific, which has historically experienced 90 percent of the world's underwater earthquakes and tsunamis.

headline: Blair's antiterror law approved
Challenges for Tung's successor
A Booming Personal Sound System Lurks Inside a Sleek, Compact Shell
abstract: Philips offers 'boom box' that is really portable digital music player with its own set of speakers built in; photo (S)

headline: Smoking Ban Clears the Air, but It Befogs Italians' Mood
abstract: Tough new law that bans smoking in public places goes into effect in Italy, causing smokers and restaurant owners to fume; law is one of strictest in Europe; getting people not to smoke in country where quarterof population does has been major headache for Health Ministry, which pushed law through more than year ago (M)

headline: An Italian Town Takes Aim at Loiterers With Wings
abstract: Bevagna, Italian town in Umbria's hunting country, takes novel approach to protecting medieval monuments, Roman ruins and 5,000 citizens from pigeon droppings, encouraging marksmen to blast feathered pests from skies; photos; map (Bevagna Journal) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Services: Monster Offers Volunteer Job Search
abstract: Monster Worldwide, the Internet job search company, yesterday introduced a volunteer section on its Web site. The new channel was devised to help connect users interested in volunteer work with nonprofit organizations, the company said. The company has joined with Idealist.org and BoardnetUSA, two volunteer opportunities sites, for the new offering. Monster said a recent poll showed that 66 percent of its users planned to seek volunteer opportunities in 2005. Volunteer jobs in the new section cannot be viewed from the general job search area.

PanAmSat brings in $900 million in IPO

Abbas Wraps Up Campaign to Lead Palestinian Authority
Taser Shares Rise on News of Safety Study
abstract: Shares of Taser International, manufacturer of stun guns whose safety has been questioned, rise more than 22 percent after company says study by journal Pacing and Clinical Electrophysiology affirms that gun's electric shocks do not cause cardiac arrest and my be safely applied multiple times if needed; Wall Street Journal reports Pentagon has found guns generally safe, although military study recommends further studies; California Assemblyman Mark Leno announces he will introduce bill requiring collection of data on use of Taser guns in state (M)

headline: Israel is said to seek security partnership
World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Date Set For Elections
abstract: Zimbabwe's government sets parliamentary elections for March 31; it is unclear if Movement for Democratic Change, opposition party, will participate; opponents hold that elections are unfair; Zanu-PF, Pres Robert G Mugabe's party, has governed since 1980 and is likely to win majority of 120 seats up for election (S)

headline: The News Is Big. It's the Papers That Are Getting Small
abstract: Jersey Journal, 138-year-old newspaper, to shift from broadsheet format to tabloid Apr 25; circulation at paper has been dwindling for decades, to 26,000 today from over 100,000 nearly 30 years ago; editor Steve Newhouse comments; owners of more traditional, upscale newspapers, including Knight Ridder Newspapers chairman Anthony Ridder, weigh similar moves to regain readers; photos (M)

PNC Reaches Revised Deal to Buy Riggs Bank
Delta's Tough Sell
abstract: Delta Air Lines, which remains in danger of filing for bankruptcy protection, has released ad campaign that emphasizes its array of lower fares introduced in January; campaign was created by Ogilvy & Mather; photo (M)

headline: SHAKE-UP AT HEWLETT
abstract: C.E.O. AS CELEBRITY -- Carleton S. Fiorina was a rock star of the computer world. But her personality and flashy management style attracted a number of critics. abstract: Cooper Companies wins Federal Trade Commission clearance to complete its $1.2 billion purchase of Ocular Sciences; acquisition makes Cooper world's third-largest maker of contact lenses (S)

headline: Net falls at Heineken and Carlsberg
Interactive Viral Campaigns Ask Consumers to Spread the Word
abstract: Article on developing field of viral advertising, in which companies try to create messages so compelling, funny or suggestive that consumers spontaneously share them with friends, often through e-mail or cellphone text messages; goal is exponential spread of ads that are endorsed by consumers' own friends; 'Innocent Escapes' video for Brawny paper towels, which Fallon New York created for Georgia Pacific, is example; photo (M)

headline: Hong Kong-Shanghai rivalry goes creative
Marsh to Pay $850 Million to Settle Charges
Suit Against Clear Channel Over Racing Goes to Jury
abstract: Suit by Jam Productions charging Clear Channel Communications illegally used its leverage to block Jam from becoming sponsor of Supercross dirt bike races in stadiums around nation offers unusual glimpse into media giant's business practices; suit details Clear Channel drive to crush Jam's efforts to break into lucrative business; Clear Channel denies using anticompetitive tactics, characterizing its actions as those of fierce competitor protecting its turf; photos (M)

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Cautiously Optimistic on Road Ahead
abstract: The day after the Israeli and Palestinian leaders announced a truce, Israel outlined additional steps on Wednesday to ease travel restrictions on Palestinians and raised the prospect of a follow-up meeting between the leaders soon.     Israeli and Palestinian commentators expressed varying degrees of optimism after the summit meeting on Tuesday in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, seeing a strong level of commitment by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority.

headline: What's Chic in Top Hotels Is Finding Its Way Home
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on latest in interior design at some of top hotels; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Inquiry Into Ex-Leaders of Hollinger
abstract: US Attorney Robert Kent Jr, in filing in Northern District Court of Illinois, confirms it is conducting criminal investigation of former top Hollinger International executives Conrad Black and F David Radler; inquiry will seek to determine whether fraud occurred in sale of community newspapers owned by Hollinger International from 1999 to 2002 to companies controlled by Black and Radler; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Patent Law in India Spurs Concern on AIDS Drugs  India, a major source of inexpensive AIDS drugs, passed a new patent law that organizations providing drugs to the world's poorest patients fear will choke off the supply of new treatments.    Because millions of Indians and other poor people -- including, by some estimates, half the AIDS patients in the Third World -- rely on India's generic drug industry, lobbyists for drug companies along with activists fighting for cheap drugs had descended on New Delhi to try to influence the outcome. [A1.]    Makers of generic drugs in India face an uncertain playing field after the approval of a new patent bill. [C6.]    Longtime PBS Program Is Canceled  ''Wall Street Week,'' which became one of the most-watched programs on public television over its 35-year run, has been canceled. Maryland Public Television the program's producer, and the Public Broadcasting Service, plan to announce that the program will be broadcast for the last time on June 24. The cancellation comes three years after the program's creator and longtime host, Louis Rukeyser, was removed as part of an effort to attract a bigger audience. [C8.]    Taking On a Giant in Japan  A court ruling in Japan set the stage for a 32-year-old entrepreneur and his Internet company, Livedoor, to gain a majority stake in Nippon Broadcasing System Inc. [C9.]    Airlines Beginning to Raise Fares  In the last four weeks, the nation's major airlines have instituted three rounds of fare increases. [C5.]    Bush Fills a Treasury Position  President Bush announced that he would nominate Timothy D. Adams, a policy adviser to Mr. Bush's presidential campaigns, to succeed John B. Taylor as under secretary for international affairs. [C7.]    Stocks Recover From Inflation Data  Stocks ended little changed as the biggest drop in oil prices this year led to a recovery from an inflation report. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 0.82 point, to 1172.53. The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.88 point to 1990.22. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 14.49 points, to 10,456.02. [C10.]    Newmarket Films Is Acquired  HBO and New Line Cinema said that they would jointly acquire Newmarket Films, an independent film distributor. [C9.]    Paxil Factory Woes Hurt Glaxo  GlaxoSmithKline's factory troubles are turning into a major financial problem. Three weeks after government regulators seized undelivered supplies of the company's popular antidepressant Paxil CR and ordered its manufacturing line to be shut down, the company remains uncertain about when it can correct its production problems and resume shipments of the drug. [C2.]    Strong Sales From a Weak Dollar  For some small companies in the United States, sales are increasing as the dollar declines. Small Business. [C8.]    The Travails of an Inflation Tracker  Hotel rooms offer an example of the judgments economists make when they track inflation. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. [C2.]

headline: Economic Calendar
Floyd Norris: More jobs, squeezed pay
Joint Venture in Cellphones Reports a Gain
abstract: Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications reports 28 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit as mobile phone shipments rose more than 50 percent; net income rose to 55 million euros ($72 million) from 43 million euros year earlier; sales jumped to 2 billion euros from 1.44 billion euros year ago (M)5

headline: Aon May Settle Friday in Incentive Payment Case
abstract: Aon, close to settlement with attorneys general of New York, Connecticut and Illinois, reportedly agrees to pay about $190 million over several years that would end investigations into hidden incentive payments it received from insurance companies; money would be designated as restitution to Aon's commercial insurance customers around world who paid it to provide unbiased advice on obtaining best coverage at lowest prices (M)

headline: Bush Chooses a Top Pentagon Aide to Head the World Bank
Europe takes aim at junk food ads
Court gets new appeal on Schiavo
Home Video Made to Watch on HDTV
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Sony's new three-chip, high-definition camcorder aimed at consumer market; like professional cameras, it has three light sensors, one for each primary color, for superior color capturing; it is pricy at $3,700, but its introduction opens world of high-quality, professional-looking, wide-screen video; release coincides with that of Apple's new low-priced movie editing program; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Gadgets can make you power-hungry
Powerful quake off Japan kills one and injures 250
Political risk in the Turkish north
World Briefings
The No. 3 Airline in Canada Suddenly Grounds All Flights
abstract: Jetsgo, Canada's third-largest scheduled airline, shuts down without warning, stranding thousands of passengers throughout North America; low-fare carrier, which has 29 aircraft and has been under safety review and struggling with increased fuel costs, applies for bankruptcy protection; Jetsgo estimates it has lost 55 million Canadian dollars ($45.6 million) in last eight months; president Michel Leblanc comments; photo (M)

headline: Palestinians promise action to end violence
Parliament sets Yushchenko inaugural
Price Increases by Companies Start to Stick
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in February, fastest pace since October; surging oil prices contributed substantially to increase; core Consumer Price Index, which excludes food and energy, rose 0.3 percent, sharpest increase since September; average prices are 3 percent above their level year earlier; medical costs are 4.3 percent higher than year ago; hotel rates gained 7.3 percent and dairy products are up 5.6 percent; worries about inflation among investors are tempered by sharp slide in oil prices that take them below $54 a barrel, as Energy Department reports that weekly crude inventories in US rose to their highest level since summer of 2002; graph (M)

headline: A Folksy Lawyer With a High-Powered Client
abstract: Reid H Weingarten, defense lawyer for Bernard J Ebbers, former chief executive of WorldCom who is on trial for fraud, attacks prosecution's star witness, WorldCom's former chief financial officer Scott D Sullivan, forcing Sullivan to admit he lied to his co-workers, his friends, shareholders, auditors and WorldCom board; Weingarten adds burst of theatrics to otherwise plodding testimony; photo (M)

headline: EU doubts efforts by Microsoft to comply
How to Save Medicare? Die Sooner
abstract: Daniel Altman Economic View column holds one way to contain Medicare's ballooning costs would be to focus end-of-life care on reducing pain rather than prolonging life; holds families should be told that goal of medical care is not always to make people live longer; calls for better coordination of care of patients whose health changes suddenly and severely; graph (M)

headline: If Directors Snooze, Now They May Lose
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column welcomes agreement by 10 former directors of WorldCom to pay $18 million of their own money to settle investor lawsuit accusing them of not exercising oversight that might have prevented fraud perpetrated by company's managers; praises Alan G Hevesi, comptroller of New York State and trustee of its Common Retirement Fund, lead plaintiff, for seeking compensation from right people: the directors personally, and not shareholders, who would bear onus of settlement if it were paid by company or insurers; photo (M)

headline: Correction
Citigroup Unit Buys Real Estate Publications
abstract: Citigroup Venture Capital Equity Partners acquires Network Communications, which owns group of real estate publications, reportedly for about $380 million; Network Communications chief executive Dan McCarthy, who will retain post, comments on deal (M)

Paris defies protests on workweek

headline: Live Large With a Wide-Screen Wall Entertainment PC System for All of Your Media
abstract: Tek Panel 460 is Windows XP computer that also happens to have 125-channel TV tuner, 512 megabytes of memory, 80-gigabyte hard drive, CD and DVD recorders and variety of memory card slots, all tucked behind 46-inch liquid-crystel display screen; price starts at about $11,000; photo (M)

headline: Bush cites Qaeda's threat
Bottle to throttle: Mixedrules for pilots
OPEC Member Burdened by High Oil Prices
abstract: Purnomo Yusgiantoro, minister of energy and mineral resources for Indonesia, says rough consensus has formed among OPEC oil ministers that oil prices are too high; says that consensus may not be widely shared; there are growing indications that OPEC's larger producers are actually getting more comfortable with higher oil prices; photo (M)

headline: Public Relations Agency Acquires Grayling USA
abstract: Havas unit Euro RSCG Magnet acquires US operations of Grayling International, part of Huntsworth, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Report Calls for Simpler Taxes
abstract: National tax advocate Nina E Olson, in annual report to Congress, says Congress has made tax code so complicated that even Internal Revenue Service is having trouble coping; urges simplification of tax code; calls for repeal of alternative minimum tax, which she says is increasing burden on middle class; cites alternative minimum tax, earned income tax credit and growing array of education tax breaks and retirement savings plans as among major causes of unnecessary complexity and confusion for taxpayers; warns increasing use of automated techniques to deal with taxpayers can result in unfair treatment, uneven enforcement of law and lost revenue; warns taxpayer compliance is on the wane; Congress created office of taxpayer advocate to identify problems facing taxpyers and to promote their interests within IRS and to Congress (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Maker Of Hearing Device Acquired
abstract: Cochlear Ltd, maker of inner-ear hearing devices, agrees to buy Entific Medical Systems of Sweden, hearing-implant maker owned by Nobel Biocare Holding and other Swedish investors, for $153 million (S)

headline: A Rich State in Bolivia Moves Toward More Autonomy
abstract: Leaders of affluent state of Santa Cruz, which functions as Bolivia's economic engine, claim important victory in their fight for regional autonomy, naming provisional assembly to prepare legal framework for greater independence; movement for autonomy, which grew out of public protests against government increase in fuel prices, is latest crisis to strike Pres Carlos Mesa's weak government; map; photo (M)

headline: Investment Banks to Settle WorldCom Bond Suit
abstract: Lehman Brothers, Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs and UBS, investment banks that helped sell WorldCom bonds to public before company collapsed, agree to pay a little more than $100 million to settle with investors who lost money in deals (M)

headline: The Tsunami's Horror Haunts a Thai Fishing Village

headline: Cancer Therapy Dropped in U.S. Is Revived in China
abstract: Shanghai Sunway Biotech licenses worldwide rights to cancer therapy from Onyx Pharmaceuticals; move is sign that China is plowing ahead in certain areas of medicine that are regarded more cautiously in US; therapy uses virus that has been genetically modified to attack cancer cells but avoid normal cells; treatment, called Onyx-015, elicited greater interest among cancer researchers few years ago when it showed ability to shrink tumors in midstage clinical trials; there were challenges delivering therapy to tumors because immune system attacks virus; some scientists also considered treatment form of gene therapy, technique that fell into disfavor after death of teenager in gene therapy trial at University of Pennsylvania; Onyx stopped work on virus treatment in 2003 to devote its money to more conventional cancer drug that is in late stage trials with Bayer; Sunway has taken treatment through clinical trials in China and thinks it is close to winning approval to sell it for head and neck cancer (M)

headline: Funds: A strategy for contrarians: Love those old losers
New Tug of War Over Excess Pension Cash
abstract: Some business advocates have begun urging Congress to let companies tap any surplus that appears in their pension funds, if and when good times return; return to 'reversions'--removal of surplus money from pension funds--gives chills to pension rights advocates, who can recall bitter fights waged over surplus pension money in 1980's; Congress imposed 50 percent excise tax on pension reversions in 1990, making surplus pension money lose its allure; consulting firms and business organizations say excise tax should be lifted, or at least reduced; they are responding to Bush administration's proposal to establish stricter pension funding standards; measure in Congress would require some companies to make much larger contributions to their pension funds than they now do; would also encourage big contributions by raising current ceiling on tax deductibility; companies will be reluctant to make big contributions as long as excise tax impedes them from taking any excess out again; chart (M)

headline: In Sri Lanka's Time of Agony, a Moment of Peace
abstract: Sri Lankan government representatives and Tamil Tiger rebels--mortal enemies in brutal civil war--are sitting together in bullet-riddled building in Puthkady Junction, planning distribution of relief aid to tsunami victims; elsewhere in country, ordinary government and Tamil Tiger soldiers are working together to repair tsunami-damaged roads; checkpoint commanders on both sides have loosened rules to ease flow of aid; government hospital has even accepted injured rebel official for treatment; such open signs of cooperation are extraordinary in region where rebels have maintained what is effectively separate country for two decades; increased grass-roots cooperation between two sides seen as one facet of deeply felt, deeply emotional response that has swept across nation of 19.5 million since merciless sea swept away 30,000 of its people; photo (M)

headline: Germany steps up its tax-evasion fight
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Strong Doubts in Europe On Microsoft Compliance  The European Commission has strong doubts that Microsoft is obeying an order issued a year ago in an antitrust ruling against the company, a spokesman said.    The commission could impose fines up to 5 percent of daily worldwide sales until it decides that Microsoft is complying with the order, which requires it to disclose information about Windows to rival software makers. [Page C2.]    Interpublic Again Delays Results  Interpublic, the advertising giant, said continuing problems with accounting would cause further delays in releasing its financial results. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]    Ann Taylor Names Chief Executive  Ann Taylor, the clothing chain, reported disappointing earnings and named a new chief executive. [C3.]    Triumph for a Young Prosecutor  The conviction of Bernard J. Ebbers for his role in the WorldCom fraud was the latest in a string of victories for David B. Anders. [C2.]    Westlaw to Restrict Data Access  Senator Charles E. Schumer said executives at the data broker Westlaw had agreed to new restrictions on the release of information like Social Security numbers. [C4.]    Strong Profits for Wall Street Firms  Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley followed their Wall Street peers in reporting strong first-quarter earnings, fueled by continued strength in trading. [C7.]    New Yorker Tops Nominations  The New Yorker once again received more nominations for National Magazine Awards than any other publication. [C6.]    Bertelsmann Earnings Up Sharply  Bertelsmann, the German media company, reported sharply higher profit for 2004, propelled by best-selling books and deep cost-cutting at its music division. [C6.]    Schrder Seeks Corporate Tax Cut  Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany said he wanted to reduce corporate taxes to 19 percent from their current 25 percent to improve business competitiveness. [A3.]    Big Orders for Jets From Brazil  The Brazilian jet maker Embraer is building a new kind of plane that may allow JetBlue to serve many smaller markets in the United States. Maurcio Botelho, left, the chief executive, said the planes were suited for regional and low-fare airlines looking to expand, as well as older airlines with a need to cut expenses. [C2.]    OPEC Speaks; Not Everyone Listens  Hours after OPEC ministers meeting in Iran decided to increase a production ceiling, oil prices in New York jumped to a new high. It seems there is little OPEC can do about rising prices. [C7.]    Stocks Stabilize Despite Oil Rise  Major indexes fluttered in a narrow range even as oil headed higher. The Dow average fell 6.72 points, to 10,626.35. The S.&P. 500 rose 2.14 points, to 1,190.21, and the Nasdaq composite gained 0.67 points, to 2,016.42. [C7.]    F.D.A. Nominee Is Questioned  Senate Democrats questioned Dr. Lester M. Crawford, President Bush's choice to lead the Food and Drug Administration, about approval for over-the-counter sales of a morning-after pill made by Barr Laboratories. [A16.]    Citigroup Told to Delay Takeovers  The Federal Reserve has told Citigroup to delay plans for major takeovers until it addresses regulatory problems and tightens internal controls. [C4.]    Surgeons' Bid for a Board Is Denied  A group of vascular surgeons was turned down again in its effort to create an independent medical board, but a new system of certifying the specialists was approved. [C4.]

headline: Switzerland clears sale of airline to Lufthansa
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cisco Reports Increase In Second-Quarter Profit  Cisco Systems reported solid growth in second-quarter profit, while sales came in shy of Wall Street's forecast as the company continued to face strong competition and a difficult corporate spending environment.    The chief executive, John T. Chambers, said he was cautiously optimistic that corporate spending was improving, though he said the strength of that market would not be entirely clear until the fourth quarter. [Page C8.]    Preparing for Tough Sell on Budget  The chairman of the House Budget Committee, anticipating stiff resistance to the administration's new spending plan, told the White House budget chief that President Bush might need to consider his first veto to hold Congress in line. [A18.]    Older Workers Lack Means to Retire  Many aging workers who had expected to ease comfortably out of the labor force in their 50's and early 60's are discovering that they do not have the financial resources to support themselves in retirement. As a result, a lot more of them are returning to work. [A1.]    Taser Results Cause Stock to Fall  Taser International, the manufacturer of stun guns, said its sales and profit rose in the fourth quarter, but its shares declined as the results fell short of analysts' forecasts amid questions about the safety of its electric weapons. Shares fell more than 11 percent as one analyst cut his sales forecast for the company. The stock quadrupled last year, but has fallen 52 percent so far this year. [C5.]    Losses Widen at Mitsubishi Motors  Net losses at Mitsubishi Motors more than doubled to 228.2 billion yen, or $2.16 billion, in the nine-month period ended on Dec. 31. [C6.]    UBS, Europe's largest bank, posted a 12 percent jump in quarterly net profit. [C6.]    How the Advertisers Fared  A look at the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of commercials that ran during the Super Bowl. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]    Microsoft to Buy Security Firm  Microsoft said that it planned to acquire Sybari Software, which makes programs aimed at protecting business computer networks from viruses, worms and other threats. [C8.]    Goldcorp Responds to Hostile Bid  The directors of Goldcorp responded to improvements in a hostile takeover bid from Glamis Gold by offering a special dividend linked to a competing transaction. [C9.]    Boeing Chief Expects Settlement  The Boeing Company's chief executive, Harry C. Stonecipher, said that he expected Boeing and the federal government could move as early as the end of this month toward reaching a settlement over several ethics investigations into the company's dealings with the Pentagon. He said the settlement would probably occur after the Feb. 18 sentencing of a former Boeing chief financial officer, Michael M. Sears, a central figure in a conflict-of-interest scandal involving Boeing and billions of dollars in Pentagon contracts. [C2.]    Stock Market Indicators Rise  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.87 points, to 10,724.63. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.58 point, to 1,202.30, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 4.65 points, to 2,086.68. [C9.]

abstract: Floyd Norris column on US budget deficits focuses on tax side of budget, which Bush administration calculates would cost $1.4 trillion from 2006 through 2015; says one area that deserves attention is estate tax; says law calls for phasing out that tax and then bringing it back; holds estate tax provision costs $256 billion; says more could be saved by stopping process of reducing tax every year; graph (M)

headline: First the Markdown, Then the Showdown
abstract: Retail stores and clothing makers are arguing about who is going to pay for profits lost because of markdowns during Christmas holiday season; suppliers are incensed--marquee names like Tommy Hilfiger, Liz Claiborne and Jones Apparel Group; merchants are demanding a lot of these rebates, called 'markdown money' in trade, and suppliers have little choice but to pay up; suppliers say they have been told merchants will be buying less of their fresh fall merchandise, if any at all, if suppliers refuse; merchants say they have no choice but to mark merchandise down because of weak demand; suppliers say stores panicked, marking down items too soon; they claim merchants shoud have stuck to sales plan, which as agreed to before stores saw designs; photos (M)

headline: Justice Dept. Looks at Gannett Bid for Michigan-Based Publisher
abstract: Antitrust investigators at Justice Department have begun examining proposed acquisition of HomeTown Communications Network by Gannett Co as industry appears headed for further consolidation; department has also received letter from Boston Herald contending that planned investment by New York Times Co in Boston Metro, free daily newspaper mainly for commuters, would violate antitrust law and hurt advertisers and readers; Wall Street Journal says department is looking into both deals (M)

headline: A $225 million restitution fund languishes
