A Thrilling Exhibit in an Empty Room
abstract: Virtual reality room will be part of $25 million renovation of Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens; renovation will double museum's size to nearly 95,000 square feet; plans include new outodoor theater and garden, 74-seat screening room, more gallery space and fully wired infrastructure able to support digital media classrooms and new new virtual space, the VR Room; photo (M)

headline: 3 deputies defect, citing rightist influence
U.N. Is Transforming Itself, but Into What Is Unclear
abstract: Kofi Annan, who was once held up as best United Nations secretary general since Dag Hammarskjold, has had his reputation battered by charges of mismangement and corruption in Iraqi oil-for-food scandal, sexual abuse of girls and women by peacekeepers in Congo and inaction in face of genocide in Africa; he has had debilitating public disagreements with United States, which originally championed him for job; Annan is shedding most of his inner circle who have risen through ranks with him, raising speculation about face of new UN (M)

headline: Bush Vows to Back Digital Health Records
abstract: Pres Bush extols benefits of electronic health records and prescriptions during visit to Cleveland Clinic, and administration renews pledge to finance projects intended to accelerate adoption of computerized health records; $50 million will be restored in Bush's 2005 budget for office of administration's national health information technology coordinator, Dr David J Brailer; Congress deleted money in November in omnibus appropriations bill in effort to contain federal deficit (M)

Report Calls for Punishing Peacekeepers in Sex Abuse
abstract: Report on sexual abuse by United Nations peacekeepers in Congo recommends that offending soldiers and their commanders be punished by their home countries, that payments made to them be recovered and put into fund for victims and that UN make compliance with these measures condition for talking part in its missions; Secretary General Kofi Annan commissioned report after evidence emerged that blue helmeted peacekeepers and civilian staff members had sex with women and girls in Congo in exchange for food and money. and in some instances raped them; report also recommends that assistance be provided for 'peacekeeper babies' left behind when troops rotate back to their own countries; report was prepared by Prince Zeid Raad al Hussein, Jordan's ambassador to UN who is former military officer and civilian peacekeeper (M)

headline: The Music Goes on Side A and the Flip Side Is a DVD
abstract: Forthcoming solo album from Rob Thomas, lead singer in Matchbox 20, will be among first by major artist to be released only on DualDisc, new format that includes traditional CD on one side of disc and DVD content on the other; DVD side includes same album mixed in surround sound so that it can be heard through home theater systems, as well as about 20 minutes of documentary video; DualDisc format is intended to entice consumers who might be tempted to download songs illegally; photos (M)

abstract: Japan's gross domestic product contracted at annual pace of 0.5 percent in fourth quarter; revised figures show economy shrank at annual pace of 0.3 percent in third quarter and declined at 0.2 percent in second quarter; strong growth in first quarter meant that economy still expanded by 2.6 percent for all of 2004 (M)

Mexico Says Drug Cartel Had Spy in President's Office
abstract: Prosecutors in Mexico say major drug cartel had spy inside office of Pres Vicente Fox, who fed one of its traffickers precise information about Fox's movements for more than three years; discovery that drug dealers bribed someone inside Mexican presidential mansion adds to sense of crisis that has gripped government in recent months, as tide of drug-related assassinations has swept nation; security around Fox is extremely tight; Nahum Acosta Lugo, who got patronage appointment as advance man for trips by Fox, has been arrested; Atty Gen Rafael Macedo de la Concha says Acosta is accused of putting Fox's well-being in risk; federal agents raid houses belonging to Hector Beltran Leyva, top lieutenant of Joaquin Guzman, most ruthless and wanted trafficker in Mexico (M)

headline: Canadian Premier Testifies in Inquiry Into Quebec Payoff Scandal
abstract: Prime Min Paul Martin of Canada appears in nationally televised hearing before commission investigating Quebec payoff scandal; says he played no significant role in program sponsoring sporting and cultural events in Quebec that has been linked to money-laundering scheme at time he was finance minister; offers no hint about who he thinks might have directed payment of tens of millions of dollars for little or no work to Quebec advertising firms that contributed campaign funds to governing Liberal Party (M)

abstract: Famous chefs, including Patrick O'Connell, Thomas Keller and Daniel Boulud, say they usually prefer simple breakfasts and lunches when they travel and sometimes eat at Burger King and other fast-food shops; say they usually get serious about eating after 8 PM, when they are adept at finding best local restaurants; confess they often cannot wait to return to comfort of their own kitchens; photos (M)

Drilling for Oil by the Yard
abstract: Small oil companies like Ballard Exploration of Houston are relying on old geological maps from 1930's and new oil exploration methods in their attempts to find oil in areas like Northmore neighborhood not far from downtown Houston; back in 1930's, before Northmore neighborhood went up, pumpjacks sucked oil out of swaths of grassy pasture known as Eureka Oil Field; today, on top of field that was once thought depleted, is district of crumbling one-story bungalows that rarely sell for more than $50,000; city officials do not foresee surge in urban oil exploration in and around Houston; some Northmore residents comment; map; photos (M)

Cheney to urge Poland to stay in Iraq

2 Dutch Deputies on the Run, From Jihad Death Threats
abstract: Two members of Dutch Parliament are being closely guarded after receiving death threats for criticizing behavior of militant Muslim immigrants in Netherlands; two, Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Geert Wilders, have revealed their whereabouts to protest conditions under which they live, one in jail cell, other on naval base; many Dutch question whether it is acceptable for legislators in Western democracy to be forced to go into hiding, to live like fugitives on the run in their own land; Dutchofficials are taking threats seriously after two previous political assassinations; photos (M)

headline: As rescue progresses, Kashmir toll rises
F.D.A. APPROVES A LOW-DOSE VERSION OF HORMONE THERAPY
abstract: Warner Chilcott wins Food and Drug Administration approval of low-dose version of its hormone known as Femhrt used to treat symptoms of menopause (S)

headline: When It's Tax Time, Call In the Professionals
abstract: Article offers advice to small business entrepreneurs on what they need to do to prepare business taxes; focuses on importance of finding qualified tax professionals and keeping records of business expenses separate from personal spending; drawing (special section: Small Business) (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chief of SBC Has Turned A Baby Bell Into a Colossus  In a string of deals, Edward E. Whitacre, the chief executive of SBC Communications, has amassed the country's most complete telecommunications company. Now he intends to add AT&T for $16 billion.    Mr. Whitacre riles critics who argue that he overpays and moves too quickly, but aggressiveness and decisiveness have marked his 40-year career. [Page C2.]    Hints of Oil Mergers to Come  After a lull since the wave of mergers in the late 1990's, the time for large-scale takeovers in the oil industry may be here again. One potential candidate is Unocal, which has substantial reserves, a strong portfolio of assets and a reputation for underperformance that has discouraged investors recently. [C2.]    Low Expectations for Auto Industry  Detroit continues to lose American customers to Asian competitors. Ford lost the most last month, with sales falling 4.9 percent. [C8.]    Secretary Wants Medicaid Changes  Michael O. Leavitt, the secretary of health and human services, called for sweeping changes in Medicaid that would cut payments for prescription drugs. [A12.]    Testimony on HealthSouth Numbers  A former financial officer for HealthSouth testified that he made up numbers to increase profits under the direct orders of Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive. [C5.]    Bankers for Bernard J. Ebbers once threatened to sell his stock in WorldCom unless it backed his loans, a banker testified. [C5.]    L. Dennis Kozlowski did not violate Tyco policy when he paid a $20 million fee to a board member, a former director said. [C5.]    Sharpton Urges a KFC Boycott  The Rev. Al Sharpton is joining forces with People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals to urge a boycott of KFC because of its suppliers' treatment of chickens. [C8.]    Lego Plays Rough in the Courts  Competitors to Lego, the maker of plastic building blocks, say the company is unfairly trying to use intellectual property law to dominate its market. Lego's last significant patent expired decades ago, so the Danish company zealously guards its trademarks and other intellectual property rights. [C4.]    Declining Oil Prices Help Stocks  Stocks rose, helped by strong earnings and lower oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 62 points, at 10,551.94. The Nasdaq composite index rose 6.29 points, to 2,068.70. [C10.]    China Loan Helped With Yukos Deal  China lent Russia $6 billion late last year to enable a government-owned company to buy a unit of Yukos, Kremlin officials said. [C4.]    Promise of a Shuttle Seat Is Gone  Delta Air Lines is now flying just one shuttle an hour from La Guardia Airport to Boston and Washington and vice versa, no matter how many people show up. [A1.]    The S.U.V. as a Hairy Beast  A new public service campaign is intended to inform young men about the rollover risks of sport utility vehicles. Advertising. [C10.]

headline: Powerful Quake Kills at Least 420 in Iran

abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column welcomes SEC plans to ensure that debt ratings published by Standard & Poor's, Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings are result of thorough analysis and are not tainted as result of conflicts inherent in business model of these services, which are paid by corporations they analyze, not by investors who look to ratings for help in assessing a company's creditworthiness; says investors would be better served if there were more credit-rating services approved by SEC (M)

headline: Euronext Offers Merger Plan but No Price
World Briefings
Mixed Reviews for 2 of Pfizer's Top Drugs
abstract: Two studies presented at cardiology conference in Orlando, Fla, offer mixed news for Pfizer's cholesterol-lowering medicine Lipitor and hypertension drug Norvasc; first study shows high dose of Lipitor lowers heart attacks and strokes more than lower dose, but high dose does not reduce overall deaths, because patients on that dose were more likely to die from cancer and other factors; second study shows that patients taking Norvasc are less likely to die than those on another regimen of hypertension medications, and that Norvasc treatment appears to raise good cholesterol; study fails in its initial goal of proving that Norvasc lowers rate of heart attacks or fatal coronary heart disease compared with other hypertension treatment; Dr John C LaRose, who lead study on Lipitor, comments (M)

headline: World Briefings
Bomb Kills a Briton at a Theater in Qatar
abstract: Car bomb outside theater in Doha, Qatar, injures dozens of people and kills British citizen directing performance; audience at theater is usually composed mainly of English-speaking expatriates of United States, Canada and Great Britain, though Arabs also attend (S)

headline: Many Iraqis Losing Hope That Politics Will Yield Real Change
abstract: Residents interviewed in two Iraqi cities voice dismay and even anger that elections have not yet translated into new government; there is striking sense of disillusionment among Shiites, who make up 60 percent of Iraq's population but were brutally suppressed under rule of Saddam Hussein; Shiites turned out in extraordinary numbers to vote; Shiite alliance's leaders are locked in difficult negotiations with Kurdish leaders; Kurds refuse to join government coalition unless Kurdish property rights are restored in Kirkuk and they are allowed to retain their militia; photos (M)

headline: Crisis Grips Kyrgyzstan; Ousted Chief Is in Russia

headline: Health Care's Unlikely Surgeon
abstract: New Gingrich, former House speaker, has become broker of ideas and influence in field of health care policy, particularly conservative notion of applying principles of 'ownership society' to medicine through health savings accounts and consumer-directed health care; idea is to give individuals tax breaks to assume responsibility for paying more of their own medical costs and to rely less on government and insurers; believes market forces will bring more options, lower prices and higher quality to health care; another focus of his, one on which he often works with liberals, is to increase investment in health information technology in order to reduce medical errors and improve efficiency; photos (L)

abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. Also on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively, 5-year and 10-year notes will be auctioned.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.32 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 2.63 percent, and the four-week issue's was 2.01 percent. In when-issued trading, the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 3.71 percent, and the 10-year note was offered at a price to yield 4.27 percent.

BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pfizer Says Internal Studies Showed No Celebrex Risks  Pfizer has told federal regulators that the company's analysis of 41 of its patient trials of the arthritis and pain drug Celebrex found no evidence that the drug increases the risk of heart problems.     The analysis is one of many documents that the Food and Drug Administration released ahead of hearings at which the agency will assess the safety records of Celebrex and similar drugs. The Pfizer analysis covered tests involving 44,000 patients but did not include results from studies conducted by independent researchers or those at other drug makers. [Page C2.]    Court Victory for Tobacco Industry  A federal appeals court delivered a victory to the nation's leading tobacco companies, ruling that the government cannot force them to turn over $280 billion in profits if a trial court finds the companies engaged in a conspiracy of fraud and deceit to promote smoking. [A1.]    Profit Jumps 47% at Matsushita  Matsushita Electric Industrial, the world's largest consumer electronics maker, said profit jumped 47 percent last quarter on demand for flat-panel TV's and DVD recorders. Matsushita, the maker of Panasonic products, said strong sales of the products, along with digital cameras, more than offset dwindling sales of VCR's and stereos. Matsushita's strong profit growth made it a standout among its Japanese peers. [C3.]    At the Top, Assistants Are Pricey  After this week's disclosure that the personal assistant for Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, was paid $240,000 a year, the role of the executive assistant has drawn scrutiny. In the upper ranks of Wall Street, that level of pay for loyal assistants is not unheard of. [A1.]    Honda Wants More Regulation  In a move that some environmental advocates said was unprecedented, Honda urged the federal government to impose tougher fuel-economy regulations. [C2.]    Time Warner Meets Expectations  Time Warner released a solid earnings report, but its stock fell slightly amid concerns that its bid for Adelphia Communications would commit it further to an industry whose growth could be slowing. [C4.]    Jobs Report Gives Stocks a Spark  A report on weak job growth sent stocks sharply higher as investors bet that the Federal Reserve would hold off on further interest rate increases. The gains capped the best week for stocks so far this year. For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.8 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 2.7 percent and the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.5 percent. [C4.]    Guilty Plea in AOL Spam Case  A former software engineer at America Online pleaded guilty to stealing and selling 92 million user names and e-mail addresses, setting off an avalanche of up to seven billion unsolicited e-mail messages. [C3.]    Schwab Cuts Trading Fees for Some  Charles Schwab said it would cut online trading commissions by more than a third, its latest attempt to win back market share from rivals like Ameritrade. [C2.]    Citigroup Puts Traders on Leave  Citigroup said it placed on leave the traders involved in a large trade of European government bonds in August that prompted regulatory investigations. [C3.]    Icahn Wants Stake in Temple-Inland  The financier Carl Icahn has filed for regulatory approval to buy up to $1 billion in shares of Temple-Inland, which makes packaging and building materials. [C4.]

headline: ENCYSIVE REPORTS RESULTS FOR A PULMONARY DRUG
abstract: Encysive Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company based in Houston, said yesterday that a study showed its Thelin drug improved exercise tolerance in people with a condition that damages the lungs and heart. People taking Thelin for pulmonary arterial hypertension added about 26.5 yards to the distance they could walk in six minutes during the 18-week test, while those on a placebo worsened, the company said. Encysive said it intended to file in April for Food and Drug Administration clearance to sell Thelin, which would be a competitor to Tracleer from Actelion Ltd., which was included in the study. Thelin showed a lower rate of side effects than Tracleer, Encysive said. Stock in Encysive rose $1.29, to $11.80 a share.

headline: 'I Don't Have a Magic Wand'
One EU future, 25 views on the path
Expense Account Alert
abstract: EXPENSE ACCOUNT ALERT -- Almost half of the business travelers in Europe and the United States who were questioned in a survey released yesterday by American Express say their companies have tightened travel-spending policies over the last two to three years. More than a third say their travel and entertainment expense accounts are getting greater scrutiny. With good reason, apparently: more than a third believe it is either ''somewhat'' or ''quite'' common for business travelers to submit expense accounts with ''one or more completely false or bogus charges.'' But most road warriors also disapprove of such fraud. Those in the United States expressed the strongest support (77 percent) for careful audits of expense reports and receipts, while 72 percent in Britain agreed, as did 70 percent in Germany and 64 percent in France. For all their stepped-up vigilance, companies do seem to be loosening up on restrictions against traveling in style. In a survey conducted by the National Business Travel Association and the Travel Industry Association of America, the proportion of corporate travelers who reported their employers restricted the class they could travel on fell to 50 percent last year from 56 percent in 2002. The decline reflected a better economy and ''a departure from severe travel restrictions'' put into effect after the 2001 terrorist attacks, the survey said.    UPGRADE UPHEAVAL -- As turmoil churns through airline elite-status programs, with many top-level members complaining that upgrades on major airlines have become more elusive this year, Continental Airlines is changing its upgrade policy to favor those who pay the highest coach fares and check in earliest online. Effective March 16, Continental said, priority for upgrades will be given to OnePass elite members traveling on full economy fares, based on elite status and time of check-in. Next in line will be those traveling on fares less than full economy, with priority based on elite level, then fare paid, and then time of check-in. The policy for companion travelers accompanying Platinum Elite members also is changing. Companion upgrades will be sorted by the status level of the elite member and by the time of check-in. For instance, Continental said in an e-mail message to its elite members, passengers accompanying a Platinum Elite member will be upgraded only after all other Platinum Elite members have received upgrades.    SHOPPERS' PARADISE -- Airport Revenue News, a trade publication, has announced the results of its annual survey of airport shops, restaurants and other retailers. Among large airports, Cincinnati-Northern Kentucky International Airport was rated first in overall concessions; Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport ranked first in best concession design; Orlando International Airport was first in customer service; and Newark Liberty International Airport ranked first in a category for unique retail services.     JOE SHARKEY

Effort to Extend Workweek Advances in France
abstract: France's lower house of Parliament voted Wednesday to relax rules governing the country's 35-hour workweek, angering powerful unions and leftist politicians who have put hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in the streets to fight the changes.    The more flexible rules will allow private sector employees to work longer hours for more pay. That may seem an innocuous, if not a proper privilege from an American point of view, but many French see it as an insidious erosion of the country's jealously guarded leisure ethic.

headline: More Armchair Quarterbacks
abstract: Electronic Arts is paying ESPN at least $750 million for exclusive right to use sport channel's mark in sports video games; sports video games accounted for $1.2 billion in sales last year; graph of top video genres; table of top games; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gambling Venture Ends
abstract: Britain's Gala Group ends $1 billion joint venture with Harrah's Entertainment Inc to build eight casinos in Britain after government scales back plans to deregulate industry; Gala and Harrah's will instead develop strategic alliance to consider opportunities arising from British gambling bill (S)

headline: U.S. Running Pension Plans of US Airways
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, federal agency that insures pensions of 44 million workers, takes over retirement plans of 51,000 current and former employees of US Airways; assumes $3 billion in pension liabilities of US Airways; carrier says it will eliminate 1,800 maintenance jobs by closing or scaling back some operations and hiring outside companies to handle work; job cuts will not mean 1,800 workers will lose their jobs; number will not be determined until company has accounted for retirements and attrition (M)

headline: Thaksin needs no coalition to govern
Guidelines Are Urged in Food Ads for Children
abstract: Sen Tom Harkin, citing General Mills' Shrek cereal and promotional children's book that features Kraft's Oreo cookies, criticizes nation's food industry for contributing to childhood obesity by promoting sugary and nutritionally deficient products; calls on food companies to do more to limit what they advertise to children; says he intends to introduce bill that would give Federal Trade Commission authority to regulate advertising to children (M)

headline: J.P. Morgan Chase Settles WorldCom Suit for $2 Billion
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Application Withdrawn
abstract: AstraZeneca withdraws its application for European Union approval of lung cancer treatment Iressa after study finds that drug failed to extend patients' lives; graph (S)

headline: Even the oil-rich are lured by VAT
Merck's Actions on Vioxx Face New Scrutiny
abstract: The spotlight is likely to be on Pfizer tomorrow when federal drug regulators begin hearings on cox-2 drugs, the class of arthritis and pain medicines that include the company's Celebrex and Bextra brands. After all, Merck, which made the other drug in that class, Vioxx, pulled it off the market last fall, citing its safety risks.      But Wall Street analysts and battalions of lawyers will be intently watching testimony by and about Merck because the company faces hundreds of lawsuits over Vioxx, some of them scheduled to go to trial as early as May in Alabama and Texas. Consolidated groups of cases are headed for trial in California and New Jersey this summer.

headline: It's Just Like Oz, With You Behind the Curtain
abstract: Article on services and products available for free or at low-cost on Internet that help small business owners make their operations look big; drawing (special section: Small Business) (M)

headline: Le Monde in talks with Lagardre
Briefs: Apple to split its shares
Even Chechnya's Dream Street Is a Dead End
abstract: Lovely block-long street in Gudermes is showcase for Russia's drive to show that life in Chechnya, place devastated by decade of war and mired in abject poverty, is improving; has been rebuilt by Ramzan Kadyrov, unelected first deputy prime minister, who may be most powerful, richest and most feared man in Chechnya; is named for his father, assassinated president Akhmad Kadyrov, but pays homage to son as well; his reconstruction efforts, like Kremlin's generally, remain erratic and infected with rampant corruption; he comments; photos (M)

headline: Suicide Bomb at Tel Aviv Club Shatters Palestinian-Israeli Truce
Security coordination resumes in Gaza
Prosecutors Rewrite Script in New Trial of 2 at Tyco
abstract: Prosecution makes opening arguments in second fraud trial of former Tyco executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz; drop most striking accusations of lavish spending that they concentrated on during first trial and focus instead on laying out core theme of their case: that two men illegally awarded themselves millions of dollars in bonuses and concealed them from company's board and shareholders; among people in gallery is Ruth Jordan, who received threatening letter while deliberating as juror in first trial, prompting judge to declare mistrial; photo (M)

headline: On Advertising:Mixing sex and power in Bulgaria
World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Vatican Says Pope Is Recovering
abstract: Vatican Chief Spokesman Dr Joaquin Navarro-Valls reports that Pope, who days ago underwent emergency tracheotomy to ease severe breathing problems, is improving without complications (S)

headline: Allawi urges Iraqis to unite after vote
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.D.A. Forms Safety Board To Assess Drug Dangers  The Food and Drug Administration is creating a safety board to advise it on drug complications and warn patients about unsafe drugs.    The move comes as Congressional committees are investigating the F.D.A.'s ability to uncover drug dangers. [Page A1.]    Robot Soldiers Are on the Way  The Pentagon predicts robots will be a major fighting force in less than a decade. [A1.]    Insurance Executives Plead Guilty  A senior executive at Marsh & McLennan and two employees of A.I.G. pleaded guilty to criminal charges of bid-rigging. [C2.]    Buffett and Soros Place Bets  Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by Warren E. Buffett, increased its stake in Comcast by about $150 million, doubling its holding. In a separate move, the Quantum Fund, the $8.7 billion hedge fund overseen by the financier George Soros, said in regulatory filings that it had bought $50 million of Time Warner stock. [C8.]    U.S. Investigating Lexus Brakes  Regulators are looking into the safety of the brakes on the Lexus RX330 S.U.V. [C5.]    McDonald's Libel Ruling Faulted  Two anti-McDonald's activists convicted of libel in Britain did not get a fair trial, a European human rights court said. [C5.]    CBS Employees Refuse to Leave  Three CBS journalists who helped oversee a flawed report on the National Guard service of President Bush are refusing to resign. [C3.]    Plans for an Overhaul at Lowe  Tony Wright, left, the new leader of Lowe Worldwide, is seeking to revive its fortunes with a major reorganization plan. The agency is struggling to recover from account losses, management turmoil and failed mergers. A revival of Lowe is crucial to the turnaround efforts of its parent, the Interpublic Group. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C8.]    Report on Retail Sales Helps Stocks  Stocks rose after a report on growth in retail sales. The Dow rose 46.19 points, to 10,837.32, a 2005 high, and the Nasdaq composite gained 6.30 points, to 2,089.21. [C9.]    More Security for Internet Explorer  Microsoft plans to introduce a version of its Web browser with stronger security. [C15.]    Jury Rejects Zoloft Defense  A teenager who blamed the Pfizer drug Zoloft for his violent behavior was convicted of killing his grandparents when he was 12. [A17.]    Foreigners Steer Clear of Treasuries  Foreigners' purchases of Treasury securities plunged 75 percent in December from the previous month. [C9.]

headline: Czechs' hero? The people's choice is a joke
Russian push for pipeline to Europe raises doubt
Key figure quits new Kyrgyzstan government
A Rise in Two-Computer Homes and a Leap for Home Networks
abstract: More Americans are introducing second computers into their homes and networking them so they can work together; graph (S)

headline: Vote highlights Portugal's political wobbliness
World Briefings
TechBrief: Ericsson sets plant closing
SETBACKS FORCE ASTRAZENECA TO CUT SALES JOBS
abstract: European drug maker AstraZeneca will cut about 500 contract sales positions, or almost 10 percent of its sales force in US, after setbacks with blood thinner Exanta and Iressa, treament for lung cancer (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Catholics Rise Everywhere But Europe
abstract: Vatican reports that number of Roman Catholics in world rose to 1.086 billion in 2003; Africa registered largest growth and only Europe declined in total number of Catholics (S)

headline: More Celebrities Finding Roles as Antidepressant Advocates
abstract: Lorraine Bracco, actress who has suffered from depression and been treated with Pfizer's drug Zoloft, discusses illness in forthcoming television commercial, which will not mention Zoloft, but rather refer viewers to Web site that does; is latest of number of celebrities to go public about depression under contract with drug company; photo of Bracco in her role as psychiatrist in Sopranos television show (M)

headline: Paris-Rome power deal shapes up
U.N. Asks Bill Clinton to Be Envoy to Tsunami Region
Mexican Troops Seize Prison After Drug Lord Violence
abstract: Over 750 troops and federal police officers with tanks and helicopters seize control of La Palma, Mexico's top maximum-security prison, where drug kingpins have managed to carry out killings and conduct business; takeover comes day after Osiel Cardenas, leader of gulf cartel, organized prisoners to protest tightening of security at Almoloya prison; photo (M)

headline: WIRELESS: Dial-a-prayer, upgraded
Deal-Making, in a Lower Gear
abstract: Hugh L McColl Jr retired chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, now runs several financial ventures from bank's headquarters and pursues other endeavors as well, including fine art business; photo (M)

headline: Ford Posts Profit as Finance Unit Offsets Auto Losses
abstract: Ford Motor Co posts modest profit in fourth quarter, as gains at its financing unit offset losses in its automotive division; net income was $104 million compared with loss of $793 million year earlier; revenue dropped to $44.7 billion, from $45.9 billion year ago; earnings were $495 million in 2003; revenue rose 4 percent, to $170.8 billion; photo (M)

headline: DOW CHEMICAL IN FUEL CELL DEAL WITH MILLENNIUM CELL
abstract: Dow Chemical Co and Millennium Cell Inc plan to develop portable hydrogen fuel cells for consumer electronics and the military; Dow will receive 3 percent preferred equity stake in Millennium Cell and retain right to buy as much as $5 million in additional equity (S)

headline: Interpublic Agencies Win Intel Accounts
abstract: In a coup for the struggling Interpublic Group of Companies, the Intel Corporation yesterday named agencies that are part of the largest Interpublic division, the McCann Worldgroup, to handle its $300 million global brand marketing account.    The decision came after a five-month review that pitted Interpublic agencies against agencies owned by the Omnicom Group and the WPP Group. Agencies owned by Havas, which had worked for Intel since 1991, creating campaigns like ''Intel inside,'' withdrew from the review in January when it appeared that Intel would shift the account elsewhere.

headline: Cut Is Forced on Mechanics at United Air
abstract: Mechanics at United Airlines, who last week rejected cost-cutting contract, will take temporary 10 percent pay reduction after bankruptcy Judge Eugene R Wedoff approves company's request to impose concessions; pilots' and flight attendants' unions vote to approve new contracts that will help save airline $311 million annually over five years; Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association represents mechanics (M)

headline: S.E.C. Brings Fraud Suit Against Ex-Qwest Officials
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission sues former Qwest Communications chief executive Joseph P Nacchio and six other former executives, accusing them of orchestrating $3 billion accounting fraud intended to mislead investors during telecommunications bubble and its bursting; civil complaint covers period from April 1, 1999, to March 31, 2002; SEC is seeking to force Nacchio and his associates to give back what it calls ill-gotten gains in higher salaries, bonuses and stock sales from inflating Qwest's financial results; complaint states Nacchio reaped $216 million and profits to others came to $84 million; contends Nacchio and his subordinates inflated revenues they reported to investors as part of scheme to persuade shareholders of US West to allow their company to be acquired by Qwest in deal in 2000; those sued include Afshin Mohebbi, former president, and two former chief financial officers, Robert S Woodruff and Robin R Szeliga; James J Kozlowski and Frank T Noyes, senior accounting executives, and Gregory M Casey are also targets; photo (M)

headline: SPIEGEL TO CLOSE FURNITURE STORES IN REORGANIZATION
abstract: Spiegel, under bankruptcy protection, files reorganization plan that calls for closing of 34 of its Eddie Bauer furniture stores and layoff of 8 percent of its work force (S)

headline: ImClone to Pay $75 Million to Settle 2002 Suit
abstract: ImClone Systems agrees to pay $75 million to settle class-action shareholder lawsuit from 2002 that accused company of making false or misleading statements about prospects of its Erbitux colon-cancer drug; agreement will result in fourth-quarter charge of $55.4 million for portion of payment not covered by insurance (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Set for This Week
BP Says Earnings Jumped in Quarter and for Year
abstract: BP reports better-than-expected profit for fourth quarter and full year, and says it might return $23 billion to shareholders in dividends and buybacks in next two years; net income rose 26 percent in quarter, to $3.6 billion; full-year net income also rose 26 percent, to $16.2 billion; BP says production volumes will increase in 2005 to 4.1 million to 4.2 million barrels per day, up from just under 4 million barrels per day in 2004 (M)

headline: Talks on Baghdad Power-Sharing Drag On
abstract: Iraq's leading political parties negotiate furiously, but apparently fruitlessly, on day before scheduled meeting of national assembly; wave of violence sweeps area south of Baghdad known as Triangle of Death for regularity with which Iraqi civilians and security personnel are gunned down; at least 9 people are killed; attacks are expected to increase as Shiite pilgrims head through area to Karbala for religious festival; Pres Traian Basescu of Romania says three Romanian journalists were abducted; photo (M)

headline: Measuring Literacy in a World Gone Digital
abstract: Educational Testing Service, nonprofit group behind SAT, Graduate Record Examination and other college tests, has developed new test it says can assess students' ability to make good critical evaluations of vast amount of material available to them; so-called Information and Communications Technology literacy assessment will be introduced at about two dozen colleges and universities this month; diagram; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Added a Record $666 Billion to Its Debts Abroad Last Year
abstract: Commerce Department reports US current-account deficit widened by 13.3 percent in fourth-quarter 2004, to $187.9 billion and climbed 24 percent for year, to record of nearly $666 billion; figures highlight US's rising demand for foreign capital, much of it from Asian central banks; some analysts warn that widening imbalances could result in sharp drop in value of dollar, which could fuel inflation and push up interest rates; others say imbalances are less ominous than they appear because foreign investors continue to pump money into US; graph (M)

headline: Disney Directors Re-elected With 92% of Shares
abstract: Walt Disney Co directors win re-election with at least 92.2 percent of shares voted; board is working to find successor to chief executive Michael Eisner (M)

headline: Gates, Ellison and Dell lead rise in insider sales
Corrections
F.D.A. PANEL SEEKS MORE STUDY OF IMAGING PRODUCT
abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory group votes 15 to 4 to recommend rejection of Combidex, imaging solution developed by Advanced Magnetics, until more patient studies are done; Combidex, when combined with magnetic resonance imaging, is intended to detect spread of cancer to lymph nodes (S)

headline: Czechs honor artist who died at Auschwitz : A new life for youth's wartime diaries
Federal Reserve Is Expected to Continue Raising Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve appears poised to continue raising interest rates for most if not all of this year despite latest Commerce Department report showing that economic growth has slowed in recent months; inflation, though still subdued by most measures, is running higher than a year ago, and Fed officials continue to believe that economic growth will probably remain fairly strong this year without stimulation from them; analysts note that cheap money is almost as plentiful now as it was before Fed started process of raising short-term rates six months ago; note that cost of home mortgages and long-term corporate financing has actually declined (M)

headline: In the Backlands of Brazil, a Stony Path to Sainthood
abstract: Birth of Rev Cicero Romao Batista 161 years ago is celebrated in Brazil, where many consider him to be saint; Roman Catholic Church, which had suspended him from his duties in nervousness over his legacy, is now reappraising him; factor in turnaround may be army of pilgrims traveling to Juazeiro do Norte, Brazil, where he was priest; disciples are hoping he can quickly be beatified and canonized; photo; map (M)

headline: WorldCom's Audacious Failure and Its Toll on an Industry
abstract: Former WorldCom Inc chief executive Bernard J Ebbers' accounting fraud trial is scheduled to begin with preliminary motions and beginning of jury selection; telecommunications industry, whose 1990's boom Ebbers help fuel with his deal making, is in shambles, riddled with heavy debt, sagging stock prices and network overcapacity; phone carriers, emerging from financial ruins, are relying less on long-distance and data services that Ebbers championed, and more on bundles of products like wireless and video that can attract customers with deeper pockets; WorldCom's downfall led Congress to answer critics' calls for action by reviving stalled legislation that became Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, sweeping pice of corporate reform legislation; companies are spending millions of dollars to comply with law, which has increased accountability but, critics say, also stifles innovation; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Protest Over Polygamy Bill
abstract: Polygamy bill before Ugandan Parliament, which would require men to get permission of their first wife before taking another, is met with protest by Muslims, who say polygamy is religious not legislative matter (S)

headline: Molson Moves to Ensure Coors Merger Is Approved
abstract: Molson, concerned that its proposed merger with Adolph Coors Co might be rejected by its shareholders, increases special dividend by 67 percent; dividend is increased by 2.18 Canadian shares to 5.44 Canadian dollars per share; dividend will be paid only if merger is approved by two-thirds majority at shareholders' meeting thas been rescheduled to Jan 28 from next week (M)

headline: A Spartan Warrior With a Sense of Humor
abstract: Sony Computer Entertainment's promotion of new PlayStation 2 video games God of War highlights consumers' ability to use game's graphics engine to make their own animated films; photo (S)

headline: Equality of Opportunity: The Water We Swim In
abstract: Ben Stein Everybody's Business column on stunning achievements that American business has made since 1958 in opening itself up to all in society, including blacks and Jews; drawing (M)

headline: Israel frees 500 Palestinians in gesture to Abbas
Abbas Pledges to Walk Arafat's Path, but Goes Extra Mile
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas is campaigning for Palestinian presidency by pledging to follow in footsteps of Yasir Arafat, but he has shown willingness to set his own course and travel in directions not open to Arafat or favored by him; has patched up Palestinian relations with visits to Lebanon, Syria and Kuwait, all places where Arafat was persona non grata for years; has appeared in most militant Palestinian towns and refugee camps and told gunmen that attacks against Israel are counterproductive and should not be part of Palestinian intifada; Arafat used to condemn suicide bombings only after they had occurred, prompting Israel to dismiss his statements as insincere; photo (M)

headline: HVB bank cuts jobs in bid to control costs
Dust-up over Paris digs snares a minister
Nepal king announces cabinet of supporters
The Dynamics of Pricing Tickets for Broadway Shows
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene article on discounting of Broadway theater tickets; says top ticket price for Broadway shows has risen 31 percent since 1998, but actual price paid has gone up by only 24 percent; holds savvy fans know that there are deals available for even most popular shows, with most popular discounts being offered through coupons, two-for-one deals, special prices for students, and through TKTS booth, run by Theater Development Fund, in Times Square; holds value of a seat in theater, like seat on airplane, is highly perishable; and once show starts or plane takes off, seat is worth next to nothing; study by Stanford economist Phillip Leslie on price discrimination in Broadway theater discussed; photo (M)

headline: Moldovan Communists shift West
Airlines Moving More Troops This Month
abstract: Pentagon says commercial airlines are flying more than double number of troops overseas in January as year ago, reason government expects to spend 15 percent more on such transports this quarter; expects commercial air carriers to move 83,000 troops overseas, comapred with 40,000 in January 2004; expects to move 71.600 troops in February, and 75,300 in March (M)

headline: Sharon Says Israel Is Coordinating Gaza Withdrawal
Suicide Car Bombing in Iraq Kills 19
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Miner Increases Capital Spending
abstract: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, Brazilian mining company known as CVRD, plans to invest $3.3 billion in 2005, nearly doubling last year's capital spending, to increase output of metals like iron and aluminum and move products faster to port; plans to open offices in Australia and Venezuela (S)

headline: Chen Shui-bian to join protest over China law
World Briefings
Socialist Party chief to form government
Malaysians sour on moral policing
Pakistani Cited in Transfer of High-Tech Gear
abstract: Commerce Dept bars Pakistani businessman Humayun Khan and his Pakland PME Corp from doing business with American companies for 180 days for violating export regulations by trying to route American-made oscilloscopes and switches to Pakistan through South Africa in circumvention of federal nuclear nonproliferation regulations; exports came to light last year when Asher Karni, Israeli citizen living in South Africa, was arrested in Denver on suspicion of illegally buying equipment for delivery to Khan (M)

headline: Retailers try just about anything to attract teenagers
Egypt charges opposition chief with forgery
Putin Makes Good-Will Visit to Ukraine President
Blogging firm to acquire a youth-oriented rival
25 Killed as Insurgents Strike in Wide Area of Iraq
Technology Briefing | Earnings: Drop In Earnings At Bellsouth
abstract: BellSouth Corp reports sharp drop in fourth-quarter profit (S)

headline: G-7 meeting may fall short of high hopes
Israel Won't Charge Sharon in a Campaign Finance Case
abstract: Atty Gen Menachem Mazuz of Israel says he will not file charges against Prime Min Ariel Sharon after long investigation into campaign financing, though Sharon's son Omri is indicted in case; decision clears prime minister of two of three long-running inquiries into possible corruption; Mazuz has not announced his findings in third case; indictment against elder Sharon would have almost certainly driven him from office; charges against his son include fraud, perjury and breach of trust linked to 1999 financing of his father's successful campaign to become leader of Likud Party; Ariel Sharon is third Israeli prime minister in row to face long probe into possible financial wrongdoing; no charges were ever filed against others, Ehud Barak and Benjamin Netanyahu; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. Issues a Guide to Gathering Genetic Data
abstract: Food and Drug Administration, in significant step toward development of so-called personalized medicine, issues guidelines aimed at encouraging pharmaceutical companies to gather and submit information about how genetic variations affect way people respond to their drugs; companies reportedly have shied away from doing so for fear that government might use information to limit market for their drugs and block approval if drug is shown in lab tests to activate gene that might be involved in cancer; FDA says information will be used to help it learn about new science of tying genetic variations to drug response, field called pharmacogenomics or pharmacogenetics (M)

headline: Israel Frees 500 Palestinian Prisoners in Gesture to Abbas
Sisters, Separated by the Holocaust, Reunite After 61 Years
abstract: New computerized archive of Yad Vashem, Israel's center for Holocaust studies, reunites Klara Bleier and Hana Katz, sisters who were separated in Budapest ghetto in October 1944; sisters settled 45 miles apart in Israel in 1948, each thinking she was sole survivor of family; their mother died at Auschwitz, and they know nothing of fate of father or siblings; maps; photo (M)

headline: Jump in Price of Oil Sends Markets Sharply Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 174.02 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,611.20; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 17.43 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,184.16; Nasdaq composite index falls 28.30 points, or 1.4 percent, to 2,030.32; price and yield for 10-year bond noted; chart on key US interest rates; graphs (M)

headline: 3 Top Accounting Managers Reassigned at Fannie Mae
abstract: Fannie Mae has replaced top accounting managers Sam Rajappa, Janet Pennewell and Jonathan Boyles involved in its financial problems last fall; three managers will remain at company as special advisers, probably with full salary and benefits, but their exact daily responsibilities have not been determined (M)

headline: Adventure Is the Critical Ingredient in Life
abstract: Aureole restaurant chef-owner Charlie Palmer, in Frequent Flier column, on some of his business travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Sure, Come Back to the Nest. Here Are the Rules.
abstract: Article on adult children who live in family home; Census Bureau reports 50 percent of all 18-to-24-year-olds and 27 percent of 18-to-34-year-olds were living at home in 2003; main factors for growing numbers of boomerangers returning home are economic, including struggles to pay off college loans and trouble finding jobs that can cover housing costs; list; photo (M)

headline: Relief Groups Hail Level of Donations by Individuals
abstract: Huge response from individual donors who want to help victims of Southeast Asia tsunami has stunned officials at world's largest private relief agencies; they call response 'unprecedented'; say that while no one has tallied all private giving, numbers reported by individual organizations indicate that amount will far surpass contributions for previous disasters (M)

headline: Senator to Ask C.I.A. to Explain Nazi-File Stance
abstract: Republican Sen Mike DeWine will demand public explanation from CIA Dir Porter Goss about agency's decision to withhold from government working group hundreds of thousands of pages of documents related to Nazi war criminals; group has broad legislative mandate to make public all such classified materials; dispute was dislosed by The New York Times; intelligence officials have said they do not believe they are required to disclose full details of all relationships with former Nazis (S)

headline: Lilly Shares Fall on Report About Prozac Documents
abstract: Shares in Eli Lilly & Co fall 1.3 percent to $56.75 after article in British Medical Journal suggests that its antidepressant Prozac could cause violent and suicidal behavior (M)

headline: Motivation on Two Wheels
abstract: David A Jones, president and chief executive of Rayovac, comments on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CLOSES VINYL RESINS FACTORY
abstract: Occidental Petroleum closes its vinyl resins factory in Pottstown, Pa; closing reduces pretax profit in fourth quarter by about $53 million (S)

headline: Plan would shield Chirac as senator for life
KIMBERLY-CLARK TO CLOSE TEXAS PLANT AND CUT 350 JOBS
abstract: Kimberly-Clark Corp, shifting production to Mexico, says it will cut about 350 jobs and close medical products plant in Fort Worth, Tex, by 2007 (S)

headline: WIRELESS: Serial monogamy of devices
World Briefing | Europe: France: Ready To Vote On Constitution
abstract: French Parliament clears way for referendum on European Union's new consitution; Pres Jacques Chirac will meet with leaders to determine date for vote; eight other countries will vote on constitution, while remaining nations will ratify document by parliamentary vote (S)

headline: High Demand Puts Midtown at Turning Point, as Office Vacancy Rate Drops to 10%
abstract: Demand for office space has been so strong in Midtown Manhattan that vacancy rate has dropped to 10 percent, level most real estate executives consider dividing point between surplus of acvailable space and shortage; specialists say scarcity of big blocks of space in Midtown will tend to force financial services firms and related companies to consider Midtown South and downtown; rents are likely to rise as landlords shrink concessions like periods of free rent and contributions toward interior construction; no major new office buildings are scheduled to come on market in 2005; Seven World Trade Center, 52-story tower downtown with 1.7 million square feet of office space, is not expected to be ready for occupancy until early in 2006; photo (M)

headline: HealthSouth Loses Mr. Right
abstract: Bally Total Fitness accuses former executive Lee Hillman and executive John Dwyer of multiple accounting errors, which will force it to restate more than three years of earnings (S)

headline: Courts Side With United and US Airways on Labor Contracts
abstract: In separate bankruptcy proceedings yesterday, US Airways received approval to cancel contracts with its mechanics and baggage handlers and United Airlines won pay cuts it had sought for a similar group.    The rulings were victories for both airlines, which are struggling for survival, but defeats for their unions.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ministers Say I.R.A. Robbed Belfast Bank
abstract: Irish Foreign Min Dermot Ahern and Paul Murphy, Britain's secretary of state for Northern Ireland, hold that recent Belfast bank robbery, which they say was conducted by Irish Republican Army, has seriously compromised efforts to restore local government; robbery netted $34 million (S)

headline: Europe's New Trade Chief Has a Soft Landing in U.S.
abstract: Peter Mandelson, once a close adviser to British Prime Min Tony Blair, is on his first visit to US as new European Union trade commissioner; Mandelson, during two-day visit to Washington, DC, seems to have succeeded in persuading US politicians and business leaders that he is serious about using trade as springboard to larger geo-political goals; photo (M)

headline: Clashes in Togo After Late Dictator's Son Succeeds Him
Opposition to Palestinian cabinet choices rises, and vote is delayed
COMPENSATION CUT FOR SOME ON CONTINENTAL'S BOARD
abstract: Continental Airlines says its board agreed to reduce fees for most directors by 30 percent and to forgo stock-option grants this year to help cut labor costs; reductions begin Feb 28 and affect annual retainer, which was $35,000 last year, as well as meeting fees, which were as much as $2,000 per meeting for directors who are not company employees (S)

headline: France will vote May 29on the EU constitution
Ethics training ordered by Citigroup executive
He refuses to predict government's course; it won't be 'Wyoming' : Cheney urges calm on Islam's role in Iraq
7 Habits of Highly Effective Cadres
abstract: Article on popular Western management experts who have reached celebrity status in China; Chester Elton, 46, author of management handbook, The 24-Carrot Manager, John Welch Jr, Stephen Covey and Michael Porter as well as lesser known experts, many of them hired by Communist Party officials, are conducting management-training seminars, hawking their books, making television appearances and soaking up adoration; photos (M)

headline: Electricity Producer Settles With California Utilities
abstract: Mirant Corp, Atlanta-based power producer, agrees to pay as much as $750 million to settle claims by California's Atty Gen Bill Lockyer that it manipulated prices during state's energy crisis in 2000 and 2001; settlement allows Mirant, which is in bankruptcy protection, to file for reorganization plan with Federal Bankruptcy Court (M)

headline: Former Executive at Tyco Testifies
abstract: Former Tyco International senior vice president Mark Foley testifies that board never approved millions of dollars in bonuses that former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski and former finance chief Mark Swartz are accused of stealing (S)

headline: I.B.M. Reports Strong Results for 4th Quarter
abstract: IBM reports strong fourth-quarter results, surpassing Wall Street's expectations and earnings reaching $3 billion for first time in company's history; reports earnings of $1.80 per share, and earnings from continuing operations of $1.81, a 16 percent increase from year-earlier quarter; revenues rose 7 percent, to $27.7 billion; chief financial officer Mark Loughridge comments (M)

headline: Big Board Is Considering Trading More Than Stocks
abstract: New York Stock Exchange chief executive John Thain, in interview at World Economic Forum, says it is in position to withstand threats to its franchise in stocks and is ready to consider possibility of expanding out of corporate equities; says there is positive reaction to idea of opening earlier in day; says exchange has made no plans but might consider trading corporate bonds; photo (M)

headline: Entry Level: Getting real about retirement
U.N. Says Iran Blocked Investigation of Nuclear Program
Fox vs. CNBC? Now That Would Be a Grudge Match
abstract: Profitability of CNBC, General Electric's cable business channel, prompts News Corp to consider adding its own cable business channel; CBNC's audience has been shrinking, but its audience is coveted by advertisers; Roger Ailes, who heads Fox News division of News Corp, led CNBC during its formative years, but quit when he was not given responsibility for MSNBC; lingering acrimony from that departure could add personal dimension to Fox-CBNC battle; photos; graphs of CNBC viewership and revenues (L)

headline: Backup power for your phone
Oil Wealth Wasting Away in Indonesia
abstract: Indonesia's oil industry is being squandered through underinvestment, bureaucracy, corruption and wariness of multinational companies; annual production has dropped by more than one third in last decade; draining of existing fields has forced Indonesia, one of oldest members of Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, to import oil in last quarter of 2004; graph; photos (M)

headline: Cingular Awards Media Services Account
abstract: Cingular Wireless awards two-thirds of its media services account to Mediaedge:cia, which handled those duties for AT&T Wireless, which it acquired last fall, and rest to OMD, which handled Cingular's media duties before merger (M)

headline: Study Ties Bankruptcy to Medical Bills
abstract: Harvard University study finds hundreds of thousands of Americans file for personal bankruptcy each year because of medical bills--even though they have health insurance; many lost their jobs, and their insurance, because they got sick, while others faced thousands of dollars in co-payments and deductibles and for services not covered by their insurance; study is scheduled to appear on Web site Health Affairs, academic journal; graph (M)

headline: Ex-Serbian General Agrees to Surrender to War Crimes Tribunal
abstract: Retired Serbian Gen Vladimir Lazarevic agrees to surrender to UN war crimes tribunal in Hague, where he is wanted for crimes committed by his troops against ethnic Albanian civilians during 1999 war in Kosovo (M)

headline: Southwest Adds ATA Flights From Chicago
abstract: Southwest Airlines' code-sharing arrangement with ATA Airlines will allow Southwest's passengers to fly from Chicago to several new destinations, including La Guardia and Newark Airports, Boston and Washington; agreement is scheduled to begin Feb 4; passengers will be able to buy tickets from Southwest to new destinations beginning Jan 16, when airline will announce fares; Southwest will start service at Pittsburgh International Airport in May; US Airways will close its hub there; Air Transportation Stabilization Board agrees that US Airways can continue to draw from its cash to run its operations through June 30; photo (M)

headline: Chirac urges French to back EU charter
Craigslist's global expansion could threaten big players
The Times Names Tierney as Op-Ed Columnist
Armed and Elusive, Afghan Drug Dealers Roam Free
abstract: Seen from the air, the Margo desert, which sprawls across the far southwestern corner of Afghanistan toward the borders with Iran and Pakistan, is traced with white car tracks.    With its forbidding reputation as the ''desert of death,'' it deters most travelers but is the favored route of drug traffickers taking opium, heroin and hashish produced in Afghanistan to Iran for smuggling to Turkey and Europe. They cross in armed convoys of 10 to 20 pickup trucks, at such high speed that police officials say they cannot catch them.

headline: Ex-HealthSouth Officer Testifies About Meeting Boss on Lake
abstract: William T Owens, former longtime HealthSouth executive, provides more details about $2.7 billion accounting fraud and describes pivotal meeting in middle of Lake Martin in Alabama as he continues his testimony against company's founder Richard M Scrushy (M)

headline: 2 European Banks Move on Plans to Buy Into Italy
abstract: ABN Amro of Netherlands plans to announce it will bid for Banca Antonveneta, 1,000-branch lender based in Padua, Italy; offer is expected to be worth about 6 billion euros ($7.8 billion); Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain offers stock worth about 6.6 billion euros ($8.5 billion) for Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, 90-year-old commercial bank based in Rome; takeover attempts are being closely watched in Europe; Italian banking sector is generally considered inefficient and ripe for consolidation, but to date, foreign banks have been discouraged from trying to buy assets by Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio and by local shareholders, who have indicated they would like industry to remain under Italian ownership (M)

G.M. Picks Germany, Not Sweden, as Home of New Saabs

headline: Another Marketing Barrier Falls
abstract: CNN, rewriting its liquor advertising policy for first time since its 1980 inception, is set to begin running spot for Grey Goose vodka, which would make it first national cable television news network to accept commercials for distilled spirits; CNN and Headline News are joining other cable networks in imposing rules for liquor commercials that are stricter than those for many other advertising categories; photo (M)

headline: Nokia Stock Jumps as Earnings Beat Expectations
abstract: Nokia reports better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and stock rises 8.7 percent; net profit was 1.02 billion euros, or $1.33 billion, 12 percent drop from year ago, but up from 660 million euros in third quarter; company made 3.21 billion euros for all of 2004, down from 3.59 billion euros in 2003; fourth-quarter sales rose 3 percent from year ago, to 9.06 billion euros (M)

headline: An architect of diplomacy on the greens
Spaniards Approve European Constitution in Referendum
abstract: Spanish voters back European Union Constitution in first referendum on charter among 25-nation bloc; Spanish officials say success of their campaign will inject momentum into ratification process, but political experts say decisions on Constitution are likely to be determined by internal politics of each nation; photo (M)

Daily News Gets Editor From Chicago
abstract: New York Daily News names Michael Cooke, editor of Chicago Sun-Times, editor in chief, filling vacancy that was created in October 2003 with retirement of Edward Kosner; announcement comes at tumultuous time for newspaper's 370 editorial employees, who have been offered voluntary buyouts in cost-cutting effort; employees had until Jan 2 to apply for buyouts, and paper has given itself deadline of midnight Jan 8 to decide which applications it will accept (M)

headline: Agriculture Issues Divide U.S. and Europe
abstract: US and European Union are disagreeing over agriculture positions adopted last year, casting doubt on progress made earlier; in one spat, US has threatened sanctions on range of European food exports in retaliation for Europe's decision in September to raise import tariffs on rice; European Union has started paying wheat producers export refunds to encourage them to sell their produce outside union after bumper harvest last year; American officials have criticized new export refunds; Mariann Fischer Boel, agriculture commissioner for European Union, defends policy; photo (M)

abstract: Sony Corp's new chairman and chief executive Sir Howard Stringer will try to untie technological and bureaucratic knots at company; some skeptics wonder if Stringer's reputation for diplomacy and building consensus can compensate for his lack of expertise in technology and electronics; they wonder how well his leadership will be accepted by other top executives, given that he speaks no Japanese and intends to spend much of his time at his homes in New York and Oxfordshire, Eng, rather than Tokyo, where company has its world headquarters; Stringer dismisses concerns; graph; photo (M)

headline: A MAVERICK, OF SORTS
abstract: Pres Bush names Nancy A Nord to serve on Consumer Product Safety Commission even though she was one of several former environmental officials who criticized him in 2004 for plan to open more federal land to off-road vehicles (S)

headline: Fed Notes Disclose Worries That Inflation May Pick Up
abstract: Minutes from Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meeting in December show Fed officials were becoming markedly more worried about inflation, with some pushing to raise interest rates faster than originally planned; cause quick sell-off in stock market as investors worry that interest rates could rise faster and growth become slower than expected (M)

abstract: Rivendell Media and Prime Access report advertising spending in print publications aimed at gay and lesbian readers rose 28.4 percent in 2004 to $207 million, up from $161.2 million in 2003; say number of ads created specifically for gay and lesbian readers more than doubled (S)

headline: Poland bars Monsanto's biotech corn
On a Haunted Island, Talk of Rebuilding
abstract: Phi Phi Island, Thailand, ultimate getaway spot for travelers from around world, was engulfed by tsunami that struck on Dec 26; most hotels, shops and restaurants were clustered between two bays at island's flattest point, which proved pitifully vulnerable to 20-foot wave; as many as 70 percent of people who lived there are dead; rest wonder whether they can return without tourist trade that was their livelihood; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefings
Disney and the Miramax Chiefs Call It Quits
abstract: Walt Disney Co and Bob and Harvey Weinstein, founders of Miramax Films, draw anticlimatic end to their stormy 12-year partnership; Disney is left with Miramax's name and its library of 550 films, and Weinstein brothers get about $130 million to start new company; Weinsteins will remain at helm of Miramax until their contract expires Sept 30, but they are free to begin acquiring film projects; search is expected to begin immediately for executive to run Disney's Miramax division beginning in July, but whoever is chosen will have to make do with budget expected to be scaled down by half or more from Weinsteins' $700 million a year; Weinsteins will take with them Dimension Films, genre label started by Bob Weinstein which is behind Scream and Scary Movie series as well as Sin City, film by Robert Rodriguez that opens March 31; Disney will retain half-interest as co-financier fo about half of forthcoming projects of Weinsteins, including Scary Movie 4, which is to begin production shortly; Disney retains Miramax and Dimension library, which includes many Academy Award winners, including best-picture recipients Chicago, Shakespeare in Love and The English Patient; photo (M)

headline: MBIA Will Restate Results for 7 Years Over Improper Accounting
abstract: MBIA is restating its financial results for last seven years because of improper accounting related to two insurance deals it struck in 1998; restatement, which amounts to $54 million net reduction in profit over period, is related to financial reinsurance agreements MBIA made with Converium Re, reinsurer previously known as Zurich Reinsurance Centre; MBIA says restatement will not have material impact on its financial position (M)

headline: Sweden's Take on Private Pensions
abstract: Article on impact on workers and retirees in Sweden from five-year-old restructuring of state pension programs; Sweden, unlike Pres George Bush's Social Security overhaul proposal, imposes mandatory 2.5 percent savings on top of its basic benefit; 16 percent of wages go into overhauled pay-as-you-go system that defines contributions but no longer guarantees same benefits as in past; photos (M)

headline: Senator Says Data Service Has Lax Rules for Security
abstract: Sen Charles E Schumer says data seaerch service Westlaw has lax rules for security, news conference; complains that any employee of company subscribing to Westlaw's databases can access sensitive records on millions of people, including Social Security numbers, previous addresses, dates of birth and other data that is valuable to identity thieves; Westlaw disputes claims; Schumer promises to introduce legislation aimed at curbing identity theft; photo (M)

headline: Liberty Media Is Planning Spinoff of Two Subsidiaries
abstract: Chairman John Malone says Liberty Media will spin off Ascent Media and its 50 percent stake in Discovery Communications into separate public company; investors say they do not believe spinoff is connected to Malone's efforts to swap News Corp shares for News Corp assets; do not see any relation to Malone's efforts to help his friend, Cablevision Systems chairman Charles Dolan, who is trying to raise money to finance Voom, high-definition television business (M)

Hitting the Tax-Break Jackpot
abstract: One-time tax break will allow American companies to pay fraction of normal tax rate on billions of dollars of profits gained overseas; main purpose of tax break was to encourage American companies to build new operations and hire more workers at home, but many companies might end of cutting their work forces; Hewelett-Packard, which has accumulated $14 in foreign profits and lobbied intensively for tax break, announced on Jan 10 that it would continue to reduce its work force this year; says it has not made any final decisions about what to do with money; Kellogg says it will use new tax break to bring back about $1 billion in foreign profits; will use money to 'look at close-in acquisitions' of other companies; Procter & Gamble says it has about $10.7 billion in foreign profits that could be brought back at fraction of normal corporate tax rates; will be eligible under law to use that money to help finance its planned $57 billion takeover of Gillette; chart; photo (M)

headline: Simple Praise for Cost-Efficient Luxury
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on what appears to be loosening of corporate purse strings and stringent policies on business air travel and hotel expenses; domestic luxury hotel occupancy reportedly increased about 13 percent between 2003 and 2004; prices have risen only slightly since 2000 and supply of luxury hotel rooms has risen; airlines are waging fierce competition for premium business-class market share, with, in some cases, prices of overseas business-class travel cut in half from year ago; drawing (M)

Shopping for a Laptop? Choose Agility or Endurance
abstract: Q. I am planning to purchase a laptop, but I don't know which processor type to get. Should I go with the Pentium 4 chip or Centrino technology?    A. Base your purchasing decision on the types of tasks you want to do with your laptop, because these processors were designed for different styles of computing.    The Pentium 4 processor is the latest in Intel's long line of Pentium family products that started when the first Pentiums replaced the old 486 line of computer processors back in the early 1990's. The latest Pentium 4 chips, both for desktop and laptop computers, are built for heavy duty, whether for multitasking through several programs at once or doing processor-intensive tasks like video editing.

Charles Calls End to the Affair: He'll Happily Wed His Camilla
abstract: Prince Charles says he will marry Camilla Parker Bowles in civil ceremony at Windsor Castle on Apr 8; they have been friends and lovers for most of last 30 years; they have survived marriages and divorces from other people, icy disapproval of relatives, resentment of public, and publication of intimate details of their risque pillow talk; bride will not become Princess of Wales--position so notably filled by Charles' first wife Diana; instead, she will be known as Her Royal Highness the Duchess of cornwall; she will become princess consort, not queen, if Charles succeeds his mother on thrown; chart with highlights from their long relationship; photos (M)

abstract: Nielsen Media Research reports CNN has failed in recent effort to close ratings gap with Fox News Channel, which leads CNN in every prime-time news slot; table of top prime-time cable news shows; photo (S)

abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies announces that Michael I Roth, chairman since July, has also been named chief executive, effective immediately; Roth succeeds David A Bell, who had been chief executive since shake-up in February 2003; Interpublic, grappling for more than two years with operational and financial difficulties, has been undergoing extensive corporate makeover expected to last until mid-2006; photos (M)

headline: Yahoo's Profit Soars in Quarter on Ad Spending and Investments
abstract: After announcing a partnership with Verizon Communications to develop a portal for high-speed Internet services on Monday, Yahoo Inc. posted strong fourth-quarter profits yesterday, driven largely by strong advertising sales and a sizable windfall from sales of an investment.    The company said it planned to extend its broadband presence in 2005 and to continue its international expansion through acquisitions of Web portal and search sites. The company drew 119 million unique visitors in December, more than any other site, according to comScore Networks, an Internet research firm.

abstract: Documents released as part of Aon's settlement with New York, Connecticut and Illinois attorneys general show that insurance broker for years channeled home and personal auto coverage for wealthy Americans to Chubb Corp and Fireman's Fund, insurance companies that paid Aon bonuses for increased business and helped pay salaries of some of its brokers; arrangement often led to higher prices for Aon's customers; Aon chief executive Patrick G Ryan apologizes for ethics breaches; disputes some charges and conclusions in documents (M)

abstract: Earthquake with magnitude of 6.4 strikes Kerman Province in central Iran, killing at least 420 people and injuring more than 900; villages of Danuniyeh and Hoodkan are destroyed; photo; map (M)

abstract: Palestinian suicide bomber blows himself up amid crowd of young Israelis in front of Tel Aviv nightclub, killing at least four and wounding dozens; bombing is first major attack since Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas called for end to violence on Feb 8; bombing endangers efforts to end over four years of violence and renew peace negotiations; Abbas condemns attack; photo (M)
