Whose Patent Is It, Anyway?
abstract: Hitachi Global Storage Technologies files suit in Federal District Court in Northern California claiming that GS Magic Stor, with factory in Guiyang, China, stole crucial elements of patented design for miniaturized version of hard drive for Apple Computer's mini iPod; Apple, not named in Hitachi's suit, does not comment; some analysts say Apple may be forced, for image reasons, to drop Magic Stor as supplier; issue for Western companies doing business in China centers on intellectual property theft that has been fixture on trade agenda between US and China for years; photos (M)

headline: Ban on swastika shelved
Stewart to Star in Trump Spinoff
North Korea signals it will rejoin 6-party talks
The Fax Machine: Technology That Refuses to Die
abstract: Fax machines remain fixture of modern offices despite predictions that they would succumb to digital, hand-held and wireless devices; some 1.5 million fax machines were sold in US in 2004 for use in both businesses and homes, and demand would appear even greater when multiuse machines are included; fax has important features that e-mail does not, like providing written record and being invulnerable to hackers; photo (M)

headline: Security Center Makes Sure You're Alerted
abstract: Q. In the last few weeks I have persistently received System Tray balloons with an icon that looks like a shield and a message saying, ''Your computer might be at risk,'' along with other messages about viruses and spyware. What is this? I already use antivirus and antispyware programs. Do I still need to be concerned about these alerts?    A. Although it might seem like annoying nagware, that importunate icon shaped like a shield belongs to the Windows Security Center, which is a part of the Windows XP Service Pack 2 system upgrade released by Microsoft last year. Windows Service Pack 2 contains features that are supposed to keep your PC safer from intruders, Internet worms and other online perils; more information for home computer users is at www.microsoft.com/athome/security/default.mspx.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: CHICAGO IS BUILDING an $850 million expansion to the McCormick Place convention center as it tries to keep its spot atop the convention market. [C7.]    LONG ISLAND MACARTHUR AIRPORT has become an important economic force lately, thanks to expansion by Southwest Airlines. [C6.]

headline: Ex-Chief of Federated Stores Is Indicted on Charge of Perjury
abstract: James M Zimmerman, retired chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores, is indicted on perjury charge involving statements he made in 2004 to investigators from New York State attorney general's office who were looking into anticompetitive behavior by company and other businesses; pleads not guilty; probe resulted from dispute over bridal registry business; Bed Bath & Beyond had been trying to expand its bridal section by selling Waterford crystal, Wedgwood china and other upscale products for home; Federated and one of its chief rivals, May Department Stores, came under scrutiny after Bed Bath & Beyond's experimental program to sell products in handful of stores came to sudden end (M)

headline: When a Stranger Calls, From Afar or Nearby
abstract: Bluetooth technology was developed as way to create short-range cordless connections between devices like headset and phone or computer and printer, and has grown to encompass exchange of data between mobile devices, but has now become tool for meeting strangers--Bluejacking--within certain range; recipient cannot trace origin of instant e-mail message because it is not tagged with phone number; Bluejacking started in Europe, but is gaining adherents in US; photo; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Citigroup Venture Capital, New York, the buyout unit of Citigroup Inc., and Quadrangle Capital Partners L.P., will buy the telecommunications company Ntelos Inc., Waynesboro, Va. Terms were not disclosed.    ConocoPhillips, Houston, the oil company, applied to the United States Coast Guard to build a new offshore liquefied natural-gas terminal in the Gulf of Mexico to capitalize on growing demand for imports.    Clorox Co., Oakland, Calif., the household-bleach maker, named Gerald E. Johnston its chairman of the board, consolidating the company's leadership 19 months after he was promoted to chief executive. Mr. Johnston, 57, succeeded Robert W. Matschullat, who was designated the board's presiding director, Clorox said in a statement.

headline: Pioneer of cyberspace looks to outer space
Social Security Bashing: A Historical Perspective
abstract: Daniel Gross column says Pres Bush's warnings about bankruptcy of Social Security are nothing new, since dire predictions about Social Security and its possible impact on economy were voiced from very beginning; says only one to have materialized has been warning that government might be tempted to spend reserve funds; some $634 billion ostensibly collected to ensure long-term viability of Social Security has been spent on current programs over last four fiscal years; drawing (M)

headline: Pope Undergoes Surgery to Ease Breathing
2005 bond market faces some potholes
World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Brief Return For A Hated King
abstract: Government temporarily erects once-discarded statue of hated Belgiun King Leopold II, who inhumanly treated Congolese and exploited nation's resources during his rule; statue is displayed in Kinshasa for one day (S)

headline: Davos: Currency fears tinge Asia optimism
Rice faces a key test in visit to Turkey
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: America's Cup Crew Hits Whale
abstract: Shosholoza, South Africa's yacht entered in 2007 America's Cup race, hits Southern right whale near Cape Town; skipper and navigator are injured when keel hits whale; condition of whale is unknown (S)

headline: WPP Combines Agencies With Health Care Focus
San Francisco's Goldilocks Market
abstract: Article assesses San Francisco's hot commercial real estate investment market; privately owned Shorenstein Co has sold its interests in four properties over last 18 months as it evolves from local business to one that invests in commercial real estate throughout country; Shorenstein's role as city's top landlord has been assumed by Equity Office Partners; Equity, however, has put five of its buildings in San Francisco on market; photo (M)

headline: Job Growth Rises, to Delight of Investors
abstract: Labor Department, offering new evidence that US economy remains on path of robust and sustained growth, reports employment grew by 262,000 jobs in February, twice as many as in January and biggest increase since last October; reports unemployment rate increased by 0.2 percent, to 5.4 percent in February, reflecting unexpected loss of 97,000 jobs and increase of 153,000 people seeking work; reports hourly wages for production and nonsupervisory workers remains stagnant at $15.90 an hour; graphs; charts; photo (M)

headline: Some Pay for a TV Service That They Didn't Choose
abstract: Bob Teitelbaum is a sports fanatic who gets his daily fix of football, baseball and basketball games from DirecTV, the satellite television provider. In all, he spends about $150 a month for his premium programming package.    But his household, like every other in his West Palm Beach, Fla., golf community, is also required to pay about $31 a month for cable TV from Adelphia Communications.

headline: Hans Bethe, 98; helped create atom bomb
World Briefing
NANOMETRICS AND AUGUST TO MERGE IN STOCK DEAL
abstract: Nanometrics agrees to merger with August Technology Corp through stock swap; new company will be called August Nanometrics (S)

headline: Israeli parliament backs Gaza withdrawal plan

Investment Bubble Builds New China
abstract: Some Chinese and Western economists are concerned that investment in China, which grew at 9.5 percent pace last year, could produce unneeded factories and underused highways and power plants, weakening country's already shaky financial system; government officials have been trying to cut what they see as unneeded investment projects and reduce growth to more sustainable pace; independent experts who examined government statistics say investment in such projects represented 45 percent of China's gross domestic product, broadest measure of economy; map; chart; photos (M)

headline: Low bid hurts T-Online
Shopping Spree That Wasn't as Markdowns Hurt Retailers
abstract: Christmas 2004 was season of last-minute markdown as merchants, led by Wal-Mart Stores, scrambled to cut prices before and after Dec 25, in many cases choosing sales gains over higher profits; Wal-Mart announces it ended year ahead of its most recent sales forecast, in part because it began lowering some prices immediately after lackluster Thanksgiving weekend; sales in December were closer to 3 percent than 2 percent forecast last week; Kmart announces sales at store open at least year declined 2.6 percent in December from previous year, but is pleased with results because it is better than 12.8 percent decline for third qaurter; photo (M)

headline: Mustang Ad to Replace Ad Withdrawn by Ford
abstract: Ford Motor Co will place controversial commercial for new Lincoln pickup that it withdrew from Super Bowl with spot for Ford Mustang (S)

headline: Pressures mounting in Lebanon
New On-Air Imus: Sour in Secaucus
abstract: Don Imus, host of radio program Imus in the Morning, which MSNBC also televises, makes on-air complaints about on-air personnel after his show moves from small studio in Astoria, Queens, to state-of-the-art suite at company headquarters in Secaucus, NJ; photo (M)

headline: Price Increase Aids Busch
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies says fourth-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, helped by price increase; net income rose to $332.5 million from $294.2 million year earlier; sales rose 4.7 percent, to $3.37 billion (S)

headline: Powell Is Stepping Down as Chairman of F.C.C. in March
French vote on EU pact to be held in the spring
Rosneft Seeks $11 Billion in Yukos Suit
abstract: Russian energy company Rosneft files suit seeking $11 billion from Yukos for what it says are questionable oil pricing practices at Yuganskneftgas, Yukos unit that Rosneft now owns, as well as back taxes; analysts say Yukos could lose its remaining oil fields if Rosneft prevails in court (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 Posts Narrower Loss
abstract: Level 3 Communications Inc says fourth-quarter net loss narrowed as sales rose, but warns that communications revenue will shrink in 2005; net loss was $77 million, compared with net loss of $121 million year earlier; revenue rose 7 percent, to $1.06 billion, from $988 million; graph (S)0

headline: Israel, in a shift, wants Syria to leave Lebanon
Abbas Wins Palestinian Vote by Strong Margin
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, who opposes continuing violence against Israel, declares victory in election for president of Palestinian Authority after two surveys of voters leaving polls show him winning by as much as 40 percentage points; if strong margin is borne out in final results, it should help give him ability to remake and reinvigorate Palestinian Authority and try to put end to violence; international observers judge voting to be generally free and fair, with little interference from Israel, which eased travel curbs on Palestinians and largely halted military activity in territories; election officials keep polls open two hours longer than planned when turnout is lower than expected; radical Islamic groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad had called on followers to boycott vote, but Hamas spokesmen say they would work with elected president; one voter survey estimates turnout at 65 percent; Abbas faced little real competition; seeks sizable popular mandate to provide him legitimacy and authority to make difficult internal reforms, to reorganize Palestinian security services and to negotiate with Israel; photos (M)

headline: Fears for a Program That Lends Just a Little
abstract: Article on potential adverse impact on small businesses if Bush administation succeeds in its plan to cut off funds to Small Business Administrations' microloan program, which provides seed money and technical assistance to start-ups and low-income entrepreneurs; microloan program, hailed in recent election by both parties, lent almost $33 million to 2,400 entrepreneurs in fiscal 2004; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft enters antivirus space
Prince Harry apologizes for Nazi costume
Carbon Monoxide From Heater Kills Georgia Premier
abstract: Georgian officials say Prime Min Zurab Zhvania died in bizarre but accidental poisoning; say he was asphyxiated by carbon monoxide apparently released by space heater in apartment in Tbilisi of political acquaintance Raul Usupov, who also died; Zhvania, 41, was youthful reformer and ally of Pres Mikhail Saakashvili; his death unsettles country's politicians and raises questions about Saakashvili's efforts to push through economic and political reforms in turbulent and impoverished country without one of his most influential and popular aides; Saakashvili, announcing death of 'my closest friend,' says he will assume duties of prime minister as well as president, but does not say for how long; photos (M)

headline: Court Refuses Loan Unit Case
abstract: Citigroup savings and loan unit fails to persuade US Supreme Court to increase $381 million award against federal government for breaking promises made during thrift crisis of 1980's; action ends lawsuit filed 15 years ago by Glendale Federal Bank, now part of Citigroup; company sought to reinstate trial judge's award of $909 million; $381 million award will still be largest payment in 120 related suits filed against US government (S)

headline: A.I.G.'s Lucrative and Unusual Ties to Affiliate
abstract: C V Starr & Co Inc, private holding company owned by American International Group's top executives and managers, is attracting scrutiny over its dealings with AIG; Starr sells specialized insurance policies with AIG's name on them; AIG defends relationship, saying Starr brings business that it would not otherwise have; recently filed brief in lawsuit brought by Louisiana teachers' pension fund gives, for first time, fuller picture of relationship; legal brief shows Starr had operating profit of $47.8 million in 2002 on revenue of $305 million; defense motion shows Starr had net profit of $109 million from 1999 to 2002, on $2 billion insurance generated for AIG; Starr's revenue soared to $368 million in 2003 from $132 million in 1999; lawsuit says AIG, through Starr, engaged in 'rampant unchecked self-dealing'; says Starr exists primarily to increase compensation of AIG's top executives and directors, some of whom are also Starr directors; AIG chairman-chief executive Maurice R Greenberg also heads Starr and is leading shareholder; photo (M)

headline: I.R.S. Offers Lower Penalty if Shelter Abusers Confess
abstract: Internal Revenue Service says it will give more than 100 senior executives at 42 companies until May 23 to come forward and admit their use of tax shelters to avoid paying hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes owed on stock options, and become eligible for reduced penalties; IRS found that executives and companies had not paid taxes owed on $700 million in income from stock options from 1999 through 2002; photo of IRS Comr Mark W Everson at news conference on illegal stock-option tax shelters (M)

headline: INSIDE: CIRCUITS
abstract: Circuits will appear each Thursday within Business Day section beginning March 31; photo (S)

headline: As Piracy Battle Nears Supreme Court, the Messages Grow Manic
abstract: Some participants are stepping up their efforts in long-roiling public relations battle between copyright owners threatened by digital piracy and technology advocates opposed to strict controls on copying of digital media, and on kinds of software that make piracy easy, as Supreme Court hearing on pivotal case nears; case pits copyright holders (represented by MGM Studios) against makers of file-sharing software (Grokster and StreamCast Networks); both sides face difficulty in winning hearts and minds of teenagers, consumers and lawmakers; photos (M)

headline: China acts on textiles
AMERITRADE LOWERS FEE FOR OPTIONS TRADING
abstract: Ameritrade lowers fee it charges customers to trade options contracts by half, to 75 cents per contract, extending pricing battle in discount brokerage industry (S)

abstract: Online Diary column; World Sunlight Map shows current sunlight and cloud cover and other site-specific views of Earth; Web site offers transcripts of sermons and speeches given by Dr Martin Luther King, Jr, and some audio clips; Music Plagiarism Project is online resource consisting of documents dating from 1845 and offering clips of music; drawing (M)

abstract: $27 million public service campaign from governments of 50 states and District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands, paid for with settlement money from lawsuit against Ford Motor Co, starts this week and is aimed at informing young men in particular about rollover risks of sport utility vehicles; ad agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty developed campaign; photo (M)

abstract: Colony of monarch butterflies that arrived in Contepec, Mexico, in November was tiny and retreated up mountains as far as possible from lower slopes where loggers have thinned or destroyed forest butterflies depend on; number arriving this winter was smallest since Mexico and World Wildlife Fund began keeping records in 1970's, down three-quarters from winter before; biologists and nature lovers blame logging in Mexico and herbicides in US for diminished numbers; photos; map (M)

headline: Young West Bank Settlers Pondering Their Future
abstract: Residents of Mitze Dani, one of over 100 unauthorized West Bank settlements critized in new Israeli government-sponsored reports, comment; are upset with Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw Gaza settlers; most such outposts are near authorized settlements, feature bare necessities of life and are intended as temporary quarters while residents lay claim to land; map; photos (M)

headline: Ballot Strength Leads Kurds to Press a Role as Deal Makers
abstract: Early election returns indicating Kurds could well be power brokers in forming new Iraqi government embolden Kurdish leaders to press ambitious agenda; relatively secular Kurds may prove necessary coalition partner, putting them in position to limit attempts by religious Shiites to install Islamic government; are seeking presidency, as well as guarantees of autonomous region in north, which could heighten tensions with neighbors like Turkey; main Kurdish coalition has 25 percent of votes tallied so far, behind leading Shite slate but well ahead of other parties (M)

headline: Chief of Riggs Bank Resigns, Citing Its Pending Merger With PNC
abstract: Riggs National chairman and chief executive Robert Allbritton abruptly resigns; says he is leaving because of bank's pending $652 million merger with PNC Financial Services Group (M)

headline: Wall Street Hears Pitch for Social Security Plan
abstract: US Treasury Sec John W Snow begins three-day sales effort to drum up Wall Street support for Pres Bush's plans to overhaul Social Security; many Wall Street economists are dubious about costs despite what some see as potential boon to stock market from allowing younger employees to invest part of their Social Security tax payments in personal accounts; Bush administration officials acknowledge that their plan could require government to borrow as much as $2 trillion over next two decades, to pay costs during transition period when government still has to pay full benefit to existing retirees; Snow will confer with top executives from biggest bond-trading firms on Wall Street and is expected to argue that such borrowing would more than pay for itself at end of 75 years; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Groups Agree to Extend Cease-Fire
World Briefing | Middle East: Israelis Barred From Gaza Strip
abstract: Israeli military announces that citizens are barred from moving to Jewish settlements in Gaza Strip (S)

headline: New Course by Royal Navy: A Campaign to Recruit Gays
abstract: Royal Navy begins actively encouraging gays to enlist and pledges to make life easier when they do, five years after Britain lifted its ban on gays in military; navy says it has asked Stonewall, group that lobbies for gay rights, to help it develop better strategies for recruiting and retaining gay men and lesbians, possibly by advertising in gay mgazines and newspapers; new effort continues pattern of changing official attitudes in navy dating to 1999, when European court ruled that Britain's ban on gays in military violated European human-rights laws; gays in British miltary are subject to same rules of sexual conduct as heterosexuals: no touching, no kissing, no flaunting of sexuality; despite change in policy, relatively few gay men and lesbians already in military have come out (M)

headline: Belarus protesters sentenced

abstract: Robert Hershey Jr Investing column on investing in money market funds; graph (M)

headline: A Cricket Match Bridges a Longtime Gap in Punjab
abstract: As India and Pakistan face off in Mohali, India, for first test match of six-week cricket series, Indians and Pakistanis greet each other with mixture of emotions; Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf is expected to attend a match, probably in Indian city of Kochi, adding explicitly political flavor to game; last year's match took Indian team to Pakistan and prompted effusion of hospitality; this year's match occurs amid peace talks that have led to cooperation between two countries on Kashmir issue; photos; map (M)

headline: In race for WTO chief, a Frenchman faces off against 3 from developing nations
Ex-Director of Tyco Testifies Bonuses Were Unauthorized
abstract: W Peter Slusser, former director of Tyco International, testifies that company's former chief executive, L Dennis Kozlowski, and his finance chief, Mark H Swartz, were not authorized to award themselves bonuses they are charged with stealing; says bonuses for two were awarded by compensation committee according to 'an exact, carefully orchestrated procedure'; Slusser, on cross-examination, says that at least once, Kozlowski turned down salary increase and additional compensation in form of stock option grants (M)

headline: A Dutch Soccer Riddle: Jewish Regalia Without Jews
abstract: Amsterdam's home soccer team, Ajax, has been identified in public mind with Jews since 1950's, and nobody knows why; opposing fans call Ajax supporters Jews, and Ajax supporters have adopted that identity in spirit of defiance, wearing Star of David tattoos and draping themselves in Israeli flag; over time, Ajax games have become charged with anti-Semitic displays from rivals, and many Jewish fans now avoid games altogether; photos (M)

headline: Burger King Takes a Product From TV to the Table
abstract: Western Angus Steak Burger developed for Burger King by winning team on episode of The Apprentice that ran Jan 20 on NBC will go on sale Jan 21 at 7,800 restaurants around country; advertising campaign for sandwich and show is created by Crispin Porter & Bogusky; photo (M)

headline: Candidate Asks Gaza Militants to Stop 'Useless' Attacks on Israelis
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, favorite in impending Palestinian presidential election, visits northern Gaza Strip; calls on militants to stop firing rockets at Israel just hours after latest salvos prompted brief Israeli raid into area; he criticizes both Palestinian rocket fire and Israeli raid; tells militants such attacks are counterproductive (M)

headline: Judge faults U.S. on Cuba detainees
Credit Suisse Net Up 22%, Topping Quarterly Forecast
abstract: Credit Suisse First Group reports 22 percent increase in profit in fourth quarter of 2004, to $959 million Swiss francs ($809 million), beating analysts' expectations; photo (M)

headline: Know When to Hold 'em, Know When to Fold 'em
abstract: Sometimes, an entrepreneur has to know when to throw in the towel.    Nine days before Christmas, Jonathan Rosen of Scarsdale, N.Y., shut down Mobelex Designs, the home-office furniture retailer and wholesaler that he founded eight years earlier. In its early years, his company prospered, but then a combination of global forces knocked him to his knees: the Internet meltdown; the economic slump; a stronger euro, which hurt him as he bought primarily from Spanish and Italian makers; and cheap imports from China.

headline: Photo of Palestinian Boy Kindles Debate in France
abstract: Former France 2 correspondent Daniel Leconte and L'Express editor Denis Jeambar express doubts about authenticity of widely-shown Sept 2000 photo of terrified Palestinian boy, Muhammad al-Dura, 12, being shielded in vain by his father from Israeli attack in Gaza, article in French newspaper Le Figaro; wrote article after viewing all 27 minutes of footage shot by Palestinian cameraman, Talal Abu Rahman, who was only one to capture image; France 2 correspondent Charles Enderlin, who was not present during shooting, has characterized image as killing of child by gunfire from Israeli position, stand now under attack by some critics; article cites absence of scene showing boy had died; station notes there is no way to say for certain whether boy was killed by Israeli or Palestinian fire; photos (M)

abstract: Joe Sharkey column shares readers' responses to Jan 11 article about fare changes many domestic airlines have made recently, notably reducing price of first-class seats on many routes; drawing (M)

headline: Ousted Kyrgyz Hints He Might Officially Resign
abstract: Kyrgyzstan's ousted president, Askar Akayev, put out mixed messages on Tuesday about his willingness to resign, insisting first in a radio interview in Russia that he would not step down but later hinting that he might if given ''adequate guarantees.''    ''At this point I am the only popularly elected and legitimate president of the Kyrgyz Republic,'' Mr. Akayev said in an interview broadcast by Moscow Echo radio. He noted that his mandate would end on Oct. 30 this year. ''At the moment, I can see no reasons, no grounds for submitting my resignation,'' he said.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank's Profit Surges
abstract: Brazil's Banco Bradesco says profit rose 41 percent in fourth quarter from year-earlier period; earned 1.06 billion reais (about $400 million) and its credit portfolio expanded to 15.6 percent, to 62.8 billion reais; bank finished year with 184.9 billion reais in assets, 4.5 percent increase from 2003; graph (S)

headline: See You, Carly. Goodbye, Harry. Hello, Investors.
abstract: Article explores issue of how stock market responds when chief executives are forced to resign; market professionals assert it is possible to reap gains after corporate shakeup, but differ on how gains can be achieved; some say company with new leadership can still be burdened by poor reputation, unprofitable business mix and shortage of clear ways to reverse malaise; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Twin Explosions Rock Baghdad Mosques, Killing at Least 15
abstract: AGHDAD, Feb. 18 - A suicide bombing killed 14 people at a Shi'ite mosque in Baghdad on Friday as thousands of Shi'ites -- Iraq's majority Muslim sect -- commemorated Ashura, the main event in their religious calendar.

headline: Italian is freed in Iraq and is hit by U.S. fire
Symantec Battles Skepticism of Investors
abstract: Executives from Symantec and Veritas Software have been scrambling to persuade investors that their proposed $13.5 billion merger deal makes sense; share price of Symantec has continued to slide since word emerged on Dec 14 that company was in talks to acquire Veritas, making sales pitch for transaction even more of a challenge; shares of Symantec have fallen 29 percent since Dec 13 (M)

abstract: Peter Boneparth, chief executive of Jones Apparel Group, writes The Boss column on his education and career; photo (M)

abstract: Kenya puts bid in for permanent seat on United Nations Security Council, if council is expanded; South Africa, Nigeria, and Egypt are also interested in permanent seats (S)

abstract: Mitsubishi will offer PocketProjector, which is small and portable and can connect to many digital still and video cameras; photo (S)

World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp Adding A Plant
abstract: Japan's Sharp Corp will invest 150 billion yen ($1.46 billion) to build advanced plant to manufacture liquid-crystal display panels for large flat-panel televisions; plant will start production in 2006 and initially will manufacture 15,000 screens per month; expansion comes as Sharp is trying to cut costs amid steadily falling prices and increasing tough competition from South Korean makers of flat-panel televisions (S)

headline: Schrder Calls On Companies To Create Jobs In Germany
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder calls on German companies to stop moving jobs and factories outside country in search of cheaper labor and lower taxes and to invest in Germany to provide badly needed employment there; contends that package of economic changes made under his leadership in past few years has led to renewal of German competitiveness; those changes aim mostly at reducing jobless benefits and cutting back on social welfare, as well as at giving employers more flexibility in hiring and firing; this has led to deep disenchantment among some of core constituents of Schroder's party; photo (M)

headline: Changing the Game, PlayStation Goes Mobile
abstract: Playstation Portable will let users cut cord to television set and play favorite games anywhere; device's imminent arrival is hot topic at annual Game Developers Conference, San Francisco; Sony is promising 24 games will be ready when device goes on sale on March 24, all reworked to take advantage of new controls and sharp screen; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Yanukovich's Resignation Accepted
abstract: Ukrainian Pres Leonid D Kuchma accepts resignation of Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich; opponent Viktor A Yushchenko leads Kuchma-supported Yanukovich by 2.2 million votes, but tally is disputed by Yanukovich; first election on Novemeber 21, which re-elected Yanukovich, was overturned because of fraud (S)

headline: U.S. Seems Sure of the Hand of Syria, Hinting at Penalties
abstract: The Bush administration, condemning the assassination of the former prime minister, Rafik Hariri, in Lebanon, suggested Monday that Syria was to blame and moved to get a new condemnation of Syria's domination of Lebanon at the United Nations Security Council.     American and European officials also said the administration was studying the possibility of tougher sanctions on Syria, effectively tightening penalties imposed in May, when Washington said the Syrian government had failed to act against militant groups in Israel and against a supply line from Syria to the insurgents in Iraq.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Board Reopens Talks With Qwest
abstract: MCI's board reopens merger talks with Qwest Communications International; MCI has been forbidden from talking directly to Qwest because of its current merger agreement with Verizon Communications (S)

abstract: Newly merged British drug maker Sanofi-Aventis reports 18 percent increase in net profit, to 5.2 billion euros ($6.9 billion) (S)

abstract: Dell plans to build new plant in southeastern China, doubling production capacity in nation to increase sales in North Asia region; chairman-founder Michael S Dell says China is integral to Dell's worldwide development; photo (S)

abstract: Time Trax Technologies introduces docking station that connects to PC through USB port and, when iPod is in cradle, software can schedule recordings of any XM or Sirius radio program and download them as MP3 files; photo (S)

headline: EU president vows new fiscal framework

Ailing Pope Is Breathing Unaided, Eating and Writing, Vatican Says
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Senate Removes Obstacles To Bankruptcy Overhaul  The Senate assured final passage of a major overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws when it cleared the remaining political obstacles to a measure that the nation's credit and retail industries have sought for years.    The bill would disqualify many families from taking advantage of the more generous provisions of the current bankruptcy code that permit them to extinguish debts for a ''fresh start.'' It would also impose major new costs on those seeking bankruptcy protection and give lenders and businesses new legal tools for recovering debts. [Page A1.]    Financial Firm to Restate Results  MBIA Inc., a financial services conglomerate, disclosed that it was restating its financial results for the last seven years. [C2.]    Claims Focus on Insurance Broker  The Minnesota attorney general said he had documents that indicated that Willis Group Holdings, an insurance broker, might have cheated its commercial insurance clients. Willis took issue with his statements. [C2.]    BHP Billiton Tops Offer for WMC  BHP Billiton offered 9.2 billion Australian dollars ($7.3 billion) for a fellow Australian mining company, WMC Resources, topping a hostile bid. [C4.]    Studies on Pfizer Drugs Are Mixed  Two large studies offered mixed news for Pfizer's two best-selling drugs, the cholesterol-lowering medicine Lipitor and the hypertension drug Norvasc. The two drugs together accounted for about 30 percent of Pfizer's sales, and an even higher share of its profit. Pfizer sponsored both of the studies. [C16.]    Qualcomm Names New Chief  The technology firm Qualcomm Inc. said that Paul E. Jacobs would succeed his father, Irwin M. Jacobs, as chief executive. [C6.]    McDonald's Promotes Exercise  A new marketing campaign from McDonald's urges people to exercise. Advertising. [C6.]    Decision Against Intel in Japan  Japan's Fair Trade Commission ruled that Intel violated antimonopoly law and ordered it to stop some sales practices. [C7.]    3 New Products From Microsoft  Microsoft introduced three software products meant to blur the lines between phones and computer networks at corporations. [C7.]    Oracle Plans an Offer for Retek  Oracle said it was planning to make a cash offer for the software maker Retek. [C6.]    Boeing Executive Is Identified  The Boeing executive whose relationship with Harry C. Stonecipher led to his ouster has been identified as Debra Peabody, who has been at the company for more than 20 years. [C2.]    Free Snacks, but No More Pillows  Delta Air Lines will stop selling food on flights and give passengers a choice of snacks. It is also eliminating pillows to save money. [C4.]

Europe's aid to Kiev takes a new turn
EchoStar Names Publicis As Agency for Dish Network
abstract: EchoStar Communications names Publicis West in Seattle as creative ad agency of record for Dish Network (S)

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Aftermarket Technology Corp., 6.3 million shares. Citigroup Global Markets, Robert W. Baird and UBS.    Ares Capital Corp., 9 million shares. Merrill Lynch.

headline: Online Travel Firms Try Real People
abstract: E-Commerce Report: In the pursuit of face-to-face sa

headline: Two U.S. Soldiers, Marine Killed in Iraq
World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Broker Investigated
abstract: Broker at Phoenix Kapitaldienst is being investigated by German prosecutors for possible faking of about 700 million euros ($936 million) in assets (S)

headline: Dueling Parliaments, Old and New, Deepen Crisis in Kyrgyzstan
abstract: Conflict between Kyrgyzstan's newly elected Parliament and old one continues to cloud prospects for government that seized power last week; crisis began when Pres Askar Akayev suddenly fled in face of protests over election abuses; members of previously sitting Parliament and new one each claim legitimacy; head of world's largest election-monitoring body, Orgn for Security and Cooperation in Europe, arrives to offer help in mediating resolution to crisis; photo (M)

headline: Trials of Some of Hussein's Aides to Start Within Weeks; His Is Expected in 2006
abstract: Iraqi officials say that the long-awaited legal reckoning for Saddam Hussein and his associates will begin this spring with televised trials for at least two of the top 12 government members in American military custody, and that prosecutors will demand the death penalty for those judged guilty of the worst crimes.    One of the first men to be tried will be a cousin of Mr. Hussein's, Ali Hassan al-Majid, known as Chemical Ali for his role in poison-gas attacks that killed thousands of Iraqi Kurds in the late 1980's, officials say.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: General Motors, Detroit, said it would spend $175 million to prepare a plant in Fort Wayne, Ind., for new versions of its large pickup trucks.    Verizon Wireless, Bedminster, N.J., said it had agreed to buy Cellular 2000, a regional carrier, from St. Cloud Wireless Holdings, St. Cloud, Minn. Terms were not disclosed.    ChevronTexaco, San Ramon, Calif., said it planned to shut an additives plant in Brazil and supply customers there with imports.    Northwest Airlines, Eagan, Minn., said it had ordered eight Airbus SAS A330 planes to replace Boeing DC-10's in its fleet in 2006 and 2007.

headline: The Meek Shall Inherit the Bill
abstract: Edmund L Andrews column says Pres Bush's agenda for year will force national debate on vexing financial problems that loom in decades ahead, such as Social Security and revamping income tax; says that on closer inspection, much of agenda amounts to borrowing today and leaving bills for future generations to pay (M)

headline: Foster's Buys 18.8 Percent of Rival Australian Winemaker
abstract: Foster's Group Ltd acquires 18.8 percent stake in Southcorp Ltd, prompting speculation that it plans takeover bid of at least 3.1 billion Australian dollars ($2.4 billion) to gain control of top-selling brands like Penfolds and Rosemount; Foster's pays 583 million Australian dollars for Oatley family's stake to become biggest shareholder in Southcorp (M)

headline: Military policy on gays costs U.S. $200 million
Search for banned weapons in Iraq ends quietly
Euronext details LSE bid, but doesn't give a figure
Tax Credits Give Sony Profit, Masking Troubled Quarter
abstract: Sony Corp posts big increase in net profit, helped by favorable tax effects, but figure masks declines in sales and operating profit as aging PlayStation game console faltered and troubles continued in electronics business; net profit rose 55 percent, to 143.8 billion yen ($1.390 billion) in third fiscal quarter ended Dec 31, compared with 92.6 billion yen year earlier; revenue fell 7.5 percent, to 2.15 trillion yen, from 2.32 trillion yen year ago, while operating profit dropped 13 percent, to 138.2 billion yen, from 158.8 billion last year; photo (M)

headline: Will Europe's rates rise? Central bank official hints at shift
Netcom and PCCW link
Study Looks at Local Political News
abstract: Study by led by University of Southern California and carried out by University of Wisconsin and Seton Hall University researchers finds local big-city television stations devoted little time to campaigns for House, state legislatures and local offices in months leading up to 2004 presidential vote; finds only 8 percent of broadcasts included report on local race, while more than half contained report on presidential race; finds hours of advertising by House candidates eclipsed actual coverage of those races by 5 to 1; study adds to debate over how many television stations company may own (M)

headline: Hollywood banks on foreign DVD bonanza
Something in the Air: Inflation
abstract: Daniel Akst column warns of renewed inflation (M)

headline: NEW YORK TIMES CO. COMPLETES PURCHASE OF FREE DAILY
abstract: New York Times Co says its subsidiary, Globe Newspaper Co, has acquired 49 percent stake in Metro Boston, free daily newspaper aimed at commuters, from Metro USA division of Metro International for $16.5 million (S)

headline: Mercedes chief's goal: Restore the star's shine
Swiss Nurse Is Sentenced for 22 Murders
Serb generalto face UN trial
The Thrill Of the Chase
abstract: Philippe Kahn, who has agreed to sell LightSurf Technologies, pioneer in cellphone photography, to VeriSign in stock transaction valued at $270 million, comments on his personal life and work ethic; photo (M)

headline: Hamas Will Take Part in Vote for a Palestinian Legislature
abstract: Hamas confirms that it will take part in Palestinian legislative elections on July 17, ending 10-year boycott of Palestinian Authority; decision represents victory for Palestinian Pres Mahmoud Abbas and is likely to reduce possibility of violence around election, which is scheduled to be held at same time that Israel plans to begin dismantling settlements in Gaza and redeploying its troops; Hamas is likely to be offered and to accept ministerial posts after election and has signalled that it will accept two-state solution in final peace settlement (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AVIALL, Dallas, an independent distributor of new airplane parts, said that General Electric, Fairfield, Conn., had given it exclusive rights to distribute spare parts for GE's CF6-50 and CF6-80A aircraft engines.    LOCKHEED MARTIN, Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, said it had received a $532 million order from the United States Army for the latest version of the Patriot missile, with some of them going to Japan and the Netherlands in the first international sale of the weapons.    PEROT SYSTEMS, Plano, Tex., the computer services company founded by the billionaire Ross Perot, won a seven-year contract worth $200 million from Wolters Kluwer, a Dutch publisher.

headline: Fox Rejects Miller Beer Ads for Super Bowl
abstract: Fox Broadcasing refused to air during Super Bowl pregame Miller Brewing Co ad that poked fun at Anheuser-Busch's plan for new light beer; notes Anheuser-Busch is largest single supporter of day's programming (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Showdown at Cablevision Over Fate of Satellite Unit  A showdown in the family that controls Cablevision ended with the son outmaneuvering the father and getting directors to approve a sale of the company's troubled satellite unit.

headline: Bracing for a Bankruptcy Rush
abstract: Bankruptcy filings are expected to rise in near term as Senate approves, 74-to-25, new bankruptcy rules that will make it harder for someone to erase debts; final passage of legislation by House, set for April, is drawing near; measure, which has support of Pres Bush, could take effect as soon as fall; rules would make it harder for individuals to walk away from their obligations if they can pay off at least some of their credit card bills or other debts; financial problems of Milton Haynes discussed; photo (M)

headline: Founders of Web Site Accuse Backers of Cheating Them
abstract: Suit is filed alleging that partners at Benchmark Capital and August Capital, two prominent Silicon Valley venture capital firms, deceived four of five founders of dot-com start-up company, Epinions, and cheated them out of tens of millions of dollars; basis for suit is February 2003 proposal to merge Epinions and Deal-Time (M)

headline: CONFIDENCE RETURNS
abstract: Conference Board reports that its consumer confidence index jumped by almost 10 points, to 102.3, in December (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KONTRON, Eching, Germany, plans to buy Dolch Computer Systems, Fremont, Calif., for 11 million euros ($14.3 million).    OWENS-ILLINOIS, Toledo, Ohio, which makes glass containers, said its chief financial officer, Thomas Young, would retire March 31.    CONOCOPHILLIPS, Houston, announced plans to buy back as much as $1 billion worth of its stock.

headline: 'A Little Armadillo' Propels Cond Nast Abroad
abstract: Conde Nast Publications international division chairman Jonathan Newhouse comments on success of British version of Glamour magazine, printed in so-called pocket size, which is best-selling monthly magazine in Britain, interview; magazine's triumph with readers is even more critical because publishers outside United States depend more on revenues from newsstand sales; photos (M)

headline: Fraying of a Latin Textile Industry
abstract: Article in series, Made Elsewhere: Losing favor, focus on erosion of Latin textile industry in light of end of trade quotas; says shifting global trade rules threaten to reverse El Salvador's industrial revolution; holds employment in garment industry, until recently source of growth, declined in 2004 for first time in decade; says government puts number of jobs lost at nearly 6,000, while managers of assembly plants say number is almost twice as high; holds thousands more jobs will be lost this year, threatening to drive up El Salvador's largest export to US: its people; says trouble in garment industry has heightened in Central America as end of global textile quotas at beginning of 2005 spreads textile and clothes manufacturing to other parts of developing world, particularly China; photo (M)

headline: In mint condition: Altoids tins reborn
China Helped Oil Company in Russia Buy Yukos Unit
abstract: Russia's Finance Min Aleksei Kudrin says China lent Russia $6 billion to enable Rosneft, which is owned by Russian government, to buy Yukos's unit Yuganskneftegas in late 2004; terms of Rosneft's oil pledges are not clear (M)

headline: Greenspan Sees U.S. Trade Gap Stabilizing and Possibly Falling
KELSO & COMPANY TO ACQUIRE INSURANCE AUTO AUCTIONS
abstract: Insurance Auto Auctions, which sells salvaged cars on behalf of insurance companies, agrees to be bought by investment firm Kelso & Co for about $385 million (S)

headline: Insurgents step up attacks against Iraqi forces
Not Always Clear Sailing
abstract: Robert I Toll, chairman and chief executive of Toll Brothers, home builder based in Pennsylvania, writes The Boss column on his career; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cypress Will Cut Up To 250 Jobs
abstract: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, which makes chips for video game consoles and mobile phones, said yesterday that it would eliminate as many as 250 jobs as part of a restructuring plan intended to return the company to profitability. Cypress said it had a fourth-quarter net loss of about 21 cents a share on revenue of $209 million. The company said that it would close a computer design center in Austin, Tex., and cut jobs at a Bloomington, Minn., fabrication plant. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., will also combine two units to form a new consumer and computation division and reduce layers of management.

headline: Cult of Stewart Bounces Back in the Magazine
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia's Martha Stewart Living magazine welcomes her return from prison on its cover and launches her new monthly column; worshipful focus on her is departure from last two years, when magazine minimized her name on cover and replaced some features that bore her name with more generic columns; company, which has been debating since her Mar 2004 conviction in Imclone stock case whether to expand beyond her personality or rebuild around her, is clearly counting on her to be driving force in rebuilding; photo (M)

headline: Queen to stay away from Charles' wedding
KPN plans job cuts as it posts profit drop
In Italian and Spanish, a howl of EU protest
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Smarte Carte, White Bear Lake, Minn., which provides baggage buggies for airports, sought bankruptcy protection to shed almost $200 million in debt as part of an agreement with its creditors.    Corinthian Colleges, Santa Ana, Calif., which operates schools for health care professionals, appointed Kenneth S. Ord chief financial officer to replace Dennis Beal, who retired in November.    General Dynamics, Falls Church, Va., the military contractor, said that it had received a $35.2 million contract to help refurbish 120 Abrams tanks.

headline: Wholesale Inventories Increased in November
abstract: Commerce Department reports wholesale inventories rose 1.1 percent in November, as companies kept more goods on hand to meet increasing demand; rise brings value of stocks to $326.8 billion and matches October increase; sales rose 0.7 percent in November after increasing 1.6 percent; inventories of durable goods at wholesalers rose 1.3 percent after rising 1.6 percent in October; sales increased 0.9 percent after 1.8 percent rise (M)

headline: Biotech crops clearBrazil hurdle
Ghosn shifts to all-wheel drive
The European Union Has Rules Except When It Doesn't
abstract: Floyd Norris Market Place column on uncertain status of power in Europe, where European Commission can issue directives that are often at mercy of national governments to interpret and enforce; European finance ministers have reached agreement that gives national governments more time to reduce deficits and more discretion to ignore certain spending in calculating them; challenge to authority of European institutions, particularly European Union, may be brewing as ABN Amro of Netherlands considers buying Banca Antonveneta of Italy and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain considers acquiring Italy's Banca Nazionale del Lavoro; photo (M)

headline: These Days, 'Retirement Living' Can Mean Many Things
abstract: Elderly have range of living arrangements from independent-living communities to assisted-living communities to nursing homes; continuing-care communities cover spectrum from independent-living to nursing home services in one site; people who want to stay where they have always lived can obtain services associated with assisted living in their homes through what are called virtual retirement communities; consumers weighing options should first consider services they need and how much they can spend; photo (M)

headline: What? They Never Heard Of WorldCom?
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on cautious position on stocks taken by Richard Bernstein, chief US strategist at Merrill Lynch, who believes quality of corporation earnings is poor and getting poorer; Bernstein view is based on widening gap between between earnings that Standard & Poor's 500 companies have reported under generally accepted accounting principles and operating earnings, figures companies typically employ in press releases after excluding write-offs and other unusual items (M)

headline: 40-Year Veteran at Toyota Moves Into the Top Position
abstract: Toyota Motor, the world's most profitable car maker, shuffled its top management Wednesday as it faces a challenge Detroit would envy: how to keep a good thing going.     Katsuaki Watanabe, a 40-year Toyota veteran, was appointed president, succeeding Fujio Cho, who led the company to a string of record profits and began an ambitious global expansion strategy.

headline: Ukraine President Sworn In, Promising to Promote Unity
abstract: Viktor A Yushchenko takes oath of office as president of Ukraine, vowing to unite deeply divided country; declares Ukraine's freedom and independence in thinly veiled remarks aimed at departing president Leonid Kuchma and at Russian Pres Vladimir Putin, who supported his opponent; inauguration ends extraodinary period in nation's history that included two rounds of voting, street protests and legal challenge that ultimately overturned declared victory of his opponent Viktor Yanokovich; photo (M)

headline: Disney Posts Higher Profits, Lifted by Hits on Television
abstract: Walt Disney Co announces better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, buoyed by turnarounds in its television and theme park businesses that helped to offset decline in its movie division; net income for first quarter of 2005 was up 5 percent, to $723 million, from $688 million in period year earlier; revenue was relatively flat, increasing 1 percent, to $8.66 million; chief financial officer Thomas O Staggs comments (M)

headline: Putin Demotes Adviser Critical of the Kremlin
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin abruptly reduces responsibilities of Andrei N Illarionov, senior economic adviser who last week issued sweeping criticism of Kremlin's leadership and expressed deep misgivings about direction in which Russia is headed; Putin reassigns some of Illarionov's duties to aide thought to be more loyal Kremlin insider, Igor I Shuvalov; Illarionov's searing assessment of state of affairs in Russia reflect widely held views among Western critics of Kremlin and those few in Russia who still risk speaking publicly; he spoke warmly of United States bankruptcy judge who tried to block auction of Yukos unit, woman ridiculed by Putin days earlier; Illarionov also crticized Putin's decision o do away with elections for governors throughout Russia, and to appoint governors through presidency; photo (M)

headline: Those I.P.O.'s Are Sizzling Hot. Uh-Oh.
abstract: Initial public offerings do very well in 2004, totaling 242 and richly rewarding investors; however, shares of any number of these IPO's rose despite little or no history of profits, and 40 percent of them had annual sales of less than $50 million; this leads some observers to worry that market for IPO's is becoming frothy; photo; graph (M)

headline: Stocks: Slower productivity growth dismays Wall St.
Executive Changes At Three Agencies
abstract: Senior executives are coming and going at major agencies. MPG in New York, the media services division of Havas, is hiring a new chief executive for North America as it strives to recover from the recent loss of large clients like Volkswagen of America.     Charlie Rutman, 53, president at Carat USA in New York, part of the Carat division of the Aegis Group, will join MPG on April 1. He succeeds James M. Rose, who stepped down in November to become chief executive at Mosaic Sales Solutions in Irving, Tex.

headline: Israel Pledges to Dismantle 24 West Bank Settlements
Best-selling author's life in the fishbowl
Verizon and Yahoo Team Up to Offer Broadband Service
abstract: Verizon Communications says it plans to work with Yahoo to introduce portal for its high-speed Internet service; Verizon's 3.3 million broadband customers will be able to use co-branded portal at no additional charge (M)

headline: Restraining Regulators From Making Rules Through Enforcement Actions
abstract: IT used to be that going after Goliath meant taking on the banks. Now it means banks taking on the regulators.     Late last week, IFG Network Securities, a broker-dealer subsidiary of the Dutch financial services group ING, won a case against the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the kind of fund shares that were appropriate to sell to investors.

headline: FBI hunts 6 suspects in Boston bomb plot
Now Playing: The Incredible Shrinking Giants
abstract: Giant media companies explore breaking themselves into smaller pieces in effort to generate more interest from investors; Viacom is considering dividing itself into two entities, and Liberty Media plans to dispose of its 50 percent stake in Discovery cable network and other, smaller interests; analysts comment (M)

headline: South Africa raises spending and cuts a key tax
Denouncing Elections, Protesters Gather for Rallies in Kyrgyzstan
abstract: Protesters stage rallies and occupy government offices in several towns across Kyrgyzstan, in one case forcing reinstatement of opposition lawmaker who lost seat in runoff elections widely seen as rigged; Pres Askar A Akayev warns of civil war; demonstrators in Jalalabad denounce elections and accuse Akayev of helping family amass power and money (M)

headline: Technology Chief at Kodak
MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS DRUG SHOWS PROMISE IN TRIAL
abstract: Tysabri, drug developed by Biogen Idec and Elan Corp, is found to slow progression of disability from multiple sclerosis by 42 percent compared with placebo (S)

headline: Europe's Plan to Deregulate Travel Booking Is Criticized
abstract: European Commission will deregulate computer reservations systems for air travel later this year; at present, airlines are required to share their ticket availability and prices with all computer reservation systems; dissenters fear that ending that rule could give Amadeus, already Europe'es biggest computer reservation system, even greater power; opponents of full deregulation of European market include two American computer reservation companies, Galileo, unit of Cendant and Sabre, British Airways, German travel company TUI and European-wide consumer group, Bureau Europeen des Unions de Consommateurs, BEUC; Air France, Lufthansa and Iberia control Amadeus (M)

headline: Success Brings Brazilian Party a Surprise: Disarray
abstract: Brazilian Workers' Party will celebrate its 25th anniversary with Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's popularity at high levels, but with questions being raised about party's principles, policies, methods and structure, accompanied by humiliating political defeat in vote for speaker of house; outsiders see rift between da Silva and his circle--who have learned to deal with realities of exercising power--and other, more traditional factions that cling to Marxist-Leninist program that da Silva has in practice renounced; photos (M)

headline: Gluttons on Wall Street: Is $10 Billion Big Enough?
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin column on pros and cons of investing in supersized private equity funds; notes that some firms are contemplating creating funds of $10 billion; cartoon (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
Baer family is giving up control
EU to start tough rules on rights of fliers
EL PASO PAYS $211 MILLION FOR TEXAS DRILLING PROPERTIES
abstract: El Paso Corp, owner of natural gas pipelines, agrees to buy drilling properties in East and South Texas from two unidentified sellers for $211 million to revive gas production (S)

headline: Not a Palmtop, Not a Laptop, Tiny PC Wields a Lot of Power
abstract: Sony Electronics introduces Windows XP machine even tinier than most portable PC'; has five-inch screen, but enough power to run all standard business programs; photo (S)

headline: Is Bob Iger a New Leading Man for Disney?
abstract: Walt Disney Co president Robert A Iger appears to be front-runner to succeed Michael D Eisner as chief executive; company will let Iger take center stage and highlight Disney's turnaround at its annual meeting on Feb 11 in Minneapolis; is expected to delay contacting potential outside candidates for job until after annual meeting; chart; photo (M)

headline: Witness Says He Wasn't Told Tyco Board Disapproved of Fee
abstract: Former Tyco director Frank E Walsh Jr testifies that he was never told whether other board members disapproved of finder's fee to him by chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski; New York State prosecutors, who are trying Kozlowski and former finance chief Mark H Swartz, contend $20 million payment amounts to theft; Kozlowski's lawyers want to show that payument to Walsh--for helping arrange Tyco's 2001 purchase of CIT Group--was amde with knowledge and consent of directors; Walsh recounts conversations he had with Tyco director Joshua Berman, after Jan 12, 2002, board meeting in which Walsh refused request of directors to give back money, half of which went to charity that Walsh controls (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Executives Departing
abstract: Aer Lingus chief executive Willie Walsh, chief operating officer Deamus Kearney and chief financial officer Brian Dunne move up their departure to Jan 28 from May amid political claims that remaining in their jobs would be conflict of interest; government is trying to sell airline (S)

headline: Canadian Wal-Mart in 2nd Union Effort
abstract: United Food and Commercial Workers Canada files application with local labor board in attempt to form union at Wal-Mart store in Windsor, Ontario; two-week delay resulted when Wal-Mart said unionzed store in Jonquiere, Quebec, would be closed in May (S)

headline: A warning on climate's impact on Africa
Deal Said to Be Near for Stake in Pathmark
abstract: Yucaipa Companies, investment firm run by Democratic fund-raiser Ronald W Burkle, is near deal to take minority stake in Pathmark supermarket chain for about $200 million (M)

headline: Chirac tempers criticism of U.S. policy : A new balancing act by France on Iraq
J.&J. RENAMING ALZHEIMER'S DRUG AFTER MIX-UPS
abstract: Johnson & Johnson plans to change name of Reminyl, drug for treating Alzheimer's disease, after two patients die when they are mistakenly given diabetes drug Amaryl (S)

headline: A Sector Where 'Merger' Can Mean the Start of Something Ugly
abstract: Having trouble naming a big merger among technology companies that ended well?     Well, there aren't many.     With the ousting of Carleton S. Fiorina from Hewlett-Packard yesterday, her much-derided acquisition of Compaq Computer in 2002 was officially added to the long list of disasters.

headline: What's Behind the Procter Deal? Wal-Mart
abstract: Many consumer products and retail experts say Wal-Mart's power and proliferation of store brands is behind Procter & Gamble's decision to buy Gillette; as Procter chief executive Alan G Lafley denies that is the case; giant chains--Wal-Mart chief among them--have increasingly dominated their relationships with manufacturers over last 15 years, flexing their market muscle and seizing pricing power by showing willingness to sell their private label products; turning point in relationship between Wal-Mart and P&G came in November 2003, when Wal-Mart introduced detergent similar to P&G's Tide, but priced lower than Tide; tables show Procter & Gamble and Gillette's large shares of their respective markets; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush Will Name Wolfowitz To Head the World Bank  President Bush said he planned to nominate Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense, to become the next president of the World Bank.    Mr. Wolfowitz has recently been best known for his role as one of the architects of the Iraq invasion, but he has spent years on strategies for development. [Page A1.]    G.M. Expects Large Losses  General Motors' shares plunged after the company said it would report a large loss. [A1.]    Fears About a Ruling on File Sharing  People involved in Internet technology are becoming anxious about a file-sharing case heading toward the Supreme Court, saying a ruling in favor of the music and movie industries could stifle new online services. ''It could be a disaster,'' said Tim O'Reilly, left, a publisher who organized this week's Emerging Technologies Conference in San Diego. [C5.]    J.P. Morgan in $2 Billion Settlement  J.P. Morgan Chase agreed to pay $2 billion to settle claims that it did not investigate WorldCom's finances before selling its bonds. [A1.]    Qwest Communications increased its bid for MCI to $8.45 billion, people close to the situation said. [C3.]    A Call to Tackle Childhood Obesity  Senator Tom Harkin called on food companies to do more to limit the amount of junk food advertising that reaches children. [C7.]    U.S. Need for Foreign Capital Grows  The United States' indebtedness to the rest of the world climbed sharply from October through December, highlighting the country's rising demand for foreign capital. [C7.]    Neiman Marcus Seeks a Buyer  Executives said Goldman Sachs has been talking with potential buyers of Nieman Marcus for the last month. [C8.]    BlackBerry Maker Settles Dispute  Research In Motion, maker of the BlackBerry, settled a patent dispute with a $450 million payment. [C5.]    Warning on a Biogen Idec Drug  In a setback for Biogen Idec, regulators said its multiple sclerosis drug Avonex might cause severe liver damage in rare cases. Biogen is already reeling from the halt in sales of its other multiple sclerosis drug, Tysabri, which was linked to a brain infection. GlaxoSmithKline said it had been told to halt a trial of a similar drug. [C3.]    China Tries to Cool Property Market  China's central bank is raising the interest rate on mortgages amid worries about excessive speculation on real estate. [C4.]    McDonald's as Landlord in Russia  Thanks to an early start in the market, McDonald's has become one of Russia's largest corporate landowners. [C4.]    Another Media Agency Departure  For the second time in two days, a top executive at a media agency owned by Interpublic is leaving. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]    A Tiny Loan Is Enough for Some  The Bush administration may end funding for a microloan program that has helped many entrepreneurs. Small Business. [C7.]    Getting Americans to Save  Requiring families to save money could end the current arms race of spending. Robert H. Frank: Economic Scene. [C2.]

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: 3,000 Seek Refuge After Quake
abstract: One person is killed and 735 others injured after southern Japan earthquake; 3,000 people take refuge in local gymnasiums; Genkaijima is hardest hit with most homes being damaged or destroyed (S)

headline: Iraq rebels kill 8; assembly prepares to choose speaker
LUBRIZOL POSTS 79% RISE IN QUARTERLY EARNINGS
abstract: Lubrizol Corp's profit rose 79 percent in fourth quarter; net income rose to $19.9 million from $11.1 million year earlier; sales rose 80 percent, to record $936.2 million (S)

headline: IPods Act as D.J.'s at Clubs Where Patrons Call the Tunes
abstract: Some nightclubs are turning over their music selection one night per week to customers who play their favorite iPod tunes over sound system, acting as DJ's for night; photos (M)

headline: Ebbers Leans Toward Taking the Stand in His Trial
abstract: WorldCom Inc's former chief executive Bernard J Ebbers indicates that he may testify in his own defense against charges of fraud, conspiracy and filing false financial reports (M)

headline: Entr'acte: French museums take steps away from home
Rebels say they hold U.S. soldier hostage
Mixed Headlines Greet the Commander
abstract: Europeans news media express satisfaction that Pres Bush, once seen as hostile, is showing friendlier, conciliatory side during current visit; still, most of press commentary on Bush's 'new era' speech in Brussels is heavily tinged with skepticism about whether changed tone of American pronouncements will be followed by practical trans-Atlantic cooperation; photo shows anti-Bush demonstrators in Berlin (M)

headline: Text messaging: A tool for disaster warning?
Qwest Expected to Raise Its Bid to Buy MCI
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc is expected to raise its $8 billion bid for MCI Inc in attempt to break up MCI's deal with Verizon Communications; photo (M)

headline: 18 youths found dead after apparent gas leak
GM talks with Fiat go down to the wire
New Year holiday begins travel nightmare in China
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foam Rubber Maker Acquired
abstract: British chemical company Vita approves 668 million pounds sterling ($1.25 billion) takeover from Texas Pacific Group after rejecting three lower bids (S)

headline: Torn From Moorings, Villagers From Sri Lanka Grasp for Past
abstract: Navalady in eastern Sri Lanka, lost at least 620 of about 1,900 inhabitants in tsunami, including wife and four sons of bodybuilder Santosh Chinnathambi Selvam; most of 490 families were related in one way or another; residents waver between vowing never to return and saying they would return if everyone else did; community spirit frayed during refuge at school in Batticaloa, yet according to Hindu custom 30 days after disaster, people returned to Navalady to cook feast for their relatives who had died; photos; map (L)

headline: Copter crash kills 31 U.S. servicemen
Thatcher's son pleads guilty
Search engines battle for Web clickers
Machinists at US Airways Accept Concessions
abstract: Members of International Assn of Machinists and Aerospace Workers union at US Airways vote in favor of $269 million in wage and benefit cuts, completing airline's efforts to win contract concessions; approval comes after bankruptcy court judge said in early Jan that he would set aside contracts for union, allowing US Airways to impose terms; contract calls for pay cuts of up to 18 percent for some mechanics, and will eliminate as many as 2,500 jobs by allowing work to go to outside companies ( M)

headline: In Pursuit of Elite Status, Nothing Is Too Extreme
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on his three-day trip last week on Continental Airlines so he could rack up 11,300 elite-status-qualifying miles, which puts him over top to qualify again this year for Platinum, top level of Continental's OnePass program; drawing (M)

headline: Paraguay Suspects Leftists in a Killing
abstract: Authorities in Paraguay say small left-wing political party with links to guerrillas in Colombia is responsible for kidnapping and killing of Cecilia Cubas, daughter of former Pres Raul Cubas (S)

headline: In Iran, official turns blogger to keep alive reformist views
Bobby Fischer, Facing Charges in U.S., Seeks Icelandic Citizenship
abstract: Bobby Fischer, eccentric chess champion who is being detained in Japan as he fights deportation to United States, is trying to resolve his legal problems by becoming citizen of Iceland; he faces charges in US for violating economic penalties against Yugoslavia by playing exhibition match there in 1992 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: W.P. CAREY & CO., New York, a real estate investment firm, said it bought the office campus of Telcordia Technologies, Piscataway, N.J., a software provider, for $119.3 million, and would lease it to the company.    WYNN RESORTS, the casino company led by Stephen Wynn, said it planned to build a second resort in Las Vegas, called Encore, for $1.4 billion.    FULTON FINANCIAL, Lancaster, Pa., which operates banks in the eastern United States, said its chief executive, Rufus Fulton Jr., would retire at the end of the year and be succeeded by its president, R. Scott Smith Jr.    ACE LTD., Bermuda, a commercial insurer, said it had received 43 requests from state prosecutors and regulators investigating collusion with insurance brokers.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schering Posts Profit Increase
abstract: Schering, the world's biggest maker of birth control pills, said fourth-quarter profit rose 23 percent because of cost cuts, lower taxes and sales growth of high-margin products like its Yasmin and Mirena contraceptives. Net income increased to 118 million euros ($151 million) from 96 million euros a year earlier, the company said on its Web site. Sales slipped 1 percent, to 1.27 billion euros ($162 billion), as growth slowed for its biggest seller, the multiple sclerosis drug Betaseron. The quarterly sales decline was the first since 2003. Profit in the fourth quarter exceeded the median estimate of 115 million euros of 12 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. The chief executive, Hubertus Erlen, above, said the company was on track to raise its operating margin from last year's 15.5 percent. Shares of Schering fell 2.4 percent, to 53.18 euros ($68), at the close of trading in Frankfurt.

headline: People
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: MILES TO GO
abstract: Anne M Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox Corp, and Pete Correll, chief executive of Georgia-Pacific, address issue of discrimination against women in corporate America, Catalyst's annual awards dinner; Catalyst is nonprofit group dedicated to advancing women up corporate ladder (S)

headline: Expected Exit of Hong Kong's Pro-Beijing Chief Stirs Wary Hopes
abstract: Analysts say expected resignation of Hong Kong's unpopular chief executive Tung Chee-hwa may gratify some pro-democracy protesters, but it is far from victory for democracy; note that by stepping down 28 months before his term expires, he could make sure that his successor is chosen by same 800-member Electoral Committee of Beijing supporters who selected him twice for five-year terms (M)

headline: Just Past Midnight, the Game Is in Hand
abstract: Retailers begin selling Son y PlayStation Portable, or PSP, at midnight; retailing specialists note that off-hour shopping extravaganza, at midnight or crack of dawn, has been used to bring out cultish consumers for films, shoes and books; photo (M)

headline: Toyota Reshuffles Top Management, Aiming at Growth
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp will promote executive vice president Katsuaki Watanabe to president, succeeding Fujio Cho, will become vice chairman; chairman Hiroshi Okuda will keep his post at least until his term as Japan Business Federation chairman ends in May 2006; Akio Toyoda, grandson of company's founder, will become executive vice president (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Merger Talks At Drug Concern
abstract: British drug developer Oxford BioMedica is in talks with unidentified third party about potential merger (S)

headline: Think You're Cramped? Try Coach at 400 Pounds
abstract: When C. David Baker gets on an airplane, his seat belt usually fits fine across his stomach. But at 6-foot-9 and ''a couple of Hostess Cup Cakes above 400 pounds,'' as he puts it, Mr. Baker is definitely a very big guy.    Good thing for him that the Arena Football League, which he has headed for eight years, is doing well enough these days to allow him to fly at least occasionally in the front of the plane, where the seats are more forgiving, or to tag along (though infrequently) with rich franchise owners, who tend to fly spacious business jets.

headline: British Man Says He Plotted With 'Shoe Bomber'
Fewer Employers Totally Cover Health Premiums
abstract: Fewer and fewer companies are able to shoulder 100 percent of workers' health insurance premiums; scattering of comapnies in industries with strong unions like telecommunications, steel and autos, as well as few state governments still pay entire premium, but most employees are paying more each year as health costs soar; percentage of large and medium-size employers paying 100 percent of workers' individual premium plummeted to 17 percent in 2004 from 29 percent in 2000; most workers who are required to share premium costs are paying more each year; average share of premium paid by employees in large and medium-size companies is expected to reach $2,800 for family coverage and $800 for individuals this year, increase of 27 percents in family premium for $2,200 in 2003, and 23 percent rise from $650 in individual rate; graph (M)

headline: Never Say 'Game Over'
abstract: Christina A Gold, president of Western Union Financial Services, comments on her childhood and career; list; photo (M)

headline: Some in Germany Oppose Bid for London Exchange
abstract: Deutsche Borse, in its bid to take over London Stock Exchange, is facing some opposition at home; TCI Fund Management, in letter to Deutsche Borse, says it will call meeting of Borse shareholders to try to oust exchange's supervisory board members; TCI, which owns more than 5 percent of Deutsche Borse's stock, wants company to give cash to shareholders rather than make deal (M)

headline: Moldova's hopes rise in border dispute with Russia
Italian Journalist Abucted in Iraq Has Been Released
Profit Strong at Cisco, but Sales Disappoint
abstract: Cisco Systems reports solid growth in profit in its second quarter ended Jan 29; sales were shy of Wall Street forecasts; net income was $1.4 billion compared with $724 million year earlier; revenue was $6.06 billion compared with $5.4 billion year ago; chief executive John T Chambers comments (M)

headline: Fourth-quarter fizz brings a glow to funds
Bernard Ebbers: Victim Himself or Mastermind?
abstract: Fraud trial of former WorldCom Inc chief executive Bernard J Ebbers begins; David Anders, US attorney leading government's case, says Ebbers told 'lie after lie after lie' to cover up company's mounting losses and stave off his own financial downfall; Reid Weingarten, lead defense attorney, says Ebbers is not guilty of any crime and that he had been misled by subordinates he trusted to handle WorldCom's complex finances; photo (M)
