abstract: Technology Briefing: Dreamwor

headline: Exporting Tips
Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo Introduces Mobile System
abstract: TiVoToGo service allows subscribers to transfer television programs to laptop computers as long as copyright protections are in place (S)

headline: FIVE SENIOR EXECUTIVES HAVE LEFT US AIRWAYS
abstract: US Airways says five senior executives have recently left or retired from airline, which is in bankruptcy protection for second time in two years; executives include senior vice president B Ben Baldanza, who joined Spirit Airlines as its president and chief operating officer; Baldanza will be succeeded by Bruce Ashby; other departing are vice presidents Kathleen Harris, William Bozin and Eilif Serck-Hanssen and Richard E Pfennig, president of US Airways Express (S)

headline: Congress Is Reviewing Pentagon on Intelligence Activities
abstract: House and Senate Intelligence Committees begin to review whether Pentagon has met legal requirements to keep them fully informed of its intelligence activities; reviews will focus on what Pentagon officials acknowledged in recent weeks is Defense Dept's widening role in intelligence gathering; expanded Pentagon operations have caused friction with CIA (M)

headline: Southern Kyrgyzstan Under Opposition Control
abstract: Protesters denouncing recent elections as fraudulent complete takeover of southern Kyrgyzstan; all three southern regional capitals, Badken, Jalalabad and Osh are now controlled by largely disorganized and poorly financed opposition movement; authorities score takeover, calling it coup; protesters in northern towns of Talas and Kochkor reportedly occupy main administrative buildings; occupations are largely peaceful, with police officers fleeing in most cases and then pledging allegiance to protesters, who elect replacements for most governors appointed by Pres Askar Akayev; majority at inaugural session of new Parliament vote to urge Akayev to call state of emergency; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Army Accused Of Failing To Care For New Recruits
abstract: Commons Defense Committee panel accuses British Army of failing to care for new recruits and shield them from bullying; four young army recruits died in recent incident at barracks in Surrey, which is still being investigated by military police (S)

headline: Is Online Retailing a Victim of Its Own Success?
abstract: Shares of many companies in online shopping industry, including Amazon.com, eBay and Shopping.com, are trading lower since beginning of year, and professional investors are divided over whether declines are just a glitch in upward trend or start of more serious fall; photo (M)

headline: Mexico's Fallen Party Plans Its Revival With a New Star
abstract: Roberto Madrazo Pintado, president of Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), promotes reformed PRI that more than a third of Mexicans believe will recover presidency in 2006; PRI won plurality in Congress in 2003 and won 7 of 10 elections for governor in 2004; broad sense of disappointment in Pres Vicente Fox has left ample room for PRI comeback, but Madrazo's reputation is tarnished by accusations of fraud and betrayal, and analysts say he behaves like old school 'antidemocrat,' drawing power from desperate masses; photo; map (M)

headline: Simplifying Web Checkouts
abstract: Traditional retailers seek new ways to shepherd online customers smoothly through checkout process, where about half of prospective customers bail out after selecting products; TJX Cos has tested new checkout system that lets customers use single page for all shipping and billing data; found fifty percent more customers completed one-page checkout process than finished multipage process; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sears Canada To Restate Results
abstract: Sears Canada will restate recent results to adjust its accounting for leases and probably reduce earnings for 2003 and 2004 by $10 million each (S)

headline: Plan for Patenting Software Stalls in Europe's Parliament
abstract: European Parliament demands that controversial proposal for law on software patents be scrapped and that debate begin anew; proposed law is intended to harmonize patent rules of 25 countries in European Union; current laws do not permit software patents, but some have been registered in recent years (M)

headline: Profit edges higher as Toyota invests
Contagion: Popular Risings in Former Soviet Zone
abstract: Analysis: government of Kyrgyzstan is latest in former Soviet republic to fall when faced by protesters asserting rights they had been promised when Soviet yoke was lifted: right to express themselves, to elect their representatives, to dream of better life their leaders promised but too often failed to deliver; toppling of leaders has come like contagion, and nowhere is fear and anticipation greater than in Russia, where Pres Vladimir V Putin has steadily strengthened state control even as he presents himself as democrat; photo (M)

headline: New leader of Togo defies criticism over deadly riots
In Stench, Amid Ghosts, Seeking the Tsunami Dead
abstract: Thousands of bodies are being found every day in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, almost month after devastating tsunami; despite money and outside help, even most basic condition for return to normalcy is nowhere near; government says it intends to pick up all bodies by Jan 26, exactly one month after tsunami, but few in Banda Aceh think that is possible; official count of dead buried in Aceh is 92,751; search now is painstaking process of working house-to-house, digging through one heap of rubble to next; at least 10,000 more bodies are believed scattered under collapsed houses, mixed with millions of tons of mud and debris; in fact, no one knows how many bodies remain or even how many died; photos; map (M)

headline: RAYOVAC PLANS TO CHANGE ITS NAME TO SPECTRUM BRANDS
abstract: Rayovac Corp, which completed its acquisition of United Industry Corp, plans to change its name to Spectrum Brands Inc to better reflect its plans to expand its product portfolio; also raises its profit forecast for current year and its shares rise 12 percent (S)

headline: Travels, and Some Detours, With an Innocent Abroad
abstract: Hewlett-Packard vice president David Gee, in Frequent Flier column, on some of his airline travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Marsh Executive Admits Guilt in Bid Case
abstract: Robert Stearns, senior vice president at Marsh & McLennan Companies, pleads guilty to criminal charges, admitting he requested fake bids from insurers, including American International Group, Ace Ltd, Zurich American Insurance and St Paul Travelers, in effort to rig bids for commercial insurance; is first Marsh executive to plead guilty since New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer sued March on Oct 14; Susan Rivera, who is being investigated by Spitzer's office, resigns as chief executive of Ace USA; Rivera has been accused of any wrongdoing, but her name emerted early in probe (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mines Told To Raise Production
abstract: Impala Platinum Holdings and Aquarius Platinum, the owners of Zimbabwe's platinum mines, must increase production or allow rivals into the industry, Zimbabwe's central bank governor, Gideon Gono, said. Zimbabwe, which has endured five consecutive years of economic recession, wants greater platinum output to increase its earnings from exports. The country has the world's second-biggest reserves of the metal, after South Africa. Impala, based in Johannesburg, is the world's second-largest platinum producer. Impala said in November that it might start a $750 million plan by March intended to increase platinum output in Zimbabwe sixfold within 10 years. The company controls Zimbabwe's two platinum mines, Ngezi and Mimosa, through its Zimbabwe Platinum Mines unit and a venture with Aquarius. Ngezi's output would double in the expansion's first phase. Impala shares fell 3 rand, to 535 rand in Johannesburg, cutting the company's market value to 35.6 billion rand ($5.7 billion).

headline: Your Daily Paper, Courtesy of a Sponsor
abstract: Large and small newspapers across nation are delivering papers to over 1.6 million people each week who are not on their subscriber rolls but are still being classified as paying customers; papers are typically paid for by advertisers; Audit Bureau of Circulations rule change three years ago lets papers include third-party sales in total circulation; change has kept circulation from falling at far faster rate; New York Times analysis finds combined average paid circulation of 669 newspapers fell 0.2 percent in six months ended Mar 2004 from six months ended Mar 2002, but would have fallen nearly 2 percent had third-party sales been excluded; advertisers and some newspaper analysts score industry's increased reliance on papers paid for by others; graph and table of third-party sales; photos (M)

headline: Some Exclusive Listings Moving to a Central Exchange
abstract: In a significant change in the way commercial properties are listed for sale or lease in the New York area, the Real Estate Board of New York, working with some of the city's largest real estate firms, has started a computerized listing of properties that will be widely available to many real estate firms.     Most commercial space available in the New York area -- and virtually all Manhattan office properties -- are now listed as exclusives, meaning that the owner signed a written agreement giving just one broker primary responsibility for finding a tenant or buyer. That broker is guaranteed a commission even if another broker ultimately brings in the new tenant or buyer.
